Subsection Title: IMPORTANT: You must read the following disclaimer before continuing. The following applies to

You are therefore advised to read this disclaimer carefully before reading, accessing or making any other use of the Preliminary Offering Memorandum. In accessing the Preliminary Offering Memorandum, you agree to be bound by the following terms and conditions, including any modifications to them anytime you receive any information from us as a result of such access. The Preliminary Offering Memorandum has been prepared in connection with the proposed offer and sale of the notes described therein. THE NOTES HAVE NOT BEEN, AND WILL NOT BE, REGISTERED UNDER THE U.S. SECURITIES ACT OR THE SECURITIES LAWS OF ANY STATE OF THE UNITED STATES OR ANY OTHER JURISDICTION, AND THE NOTES MAY NOT BE OFFERED OR SOLD WITHIN THE UNITED STATES, EXCEPT PURSUANT TO AN EXEMPTION FROM, OR IN A TRANSACTION NOT SUBJECT TO, THE REGISTRATION REQUIREMENTS OF THE SECURITIES ACT AND APPLICABLE LAWS OF OTHER JURISDICTIONS. THE PRELIMINARY OFFERING MEMORANDUM MAY NOT BE FORWARDED OR DISTRIBUTED TO ANY OTHER PERSON AND MAY NOT BE REPRODUCED IN ANY MANNER WHATSOEVER. ANY FORWARDING, DISTRIBUTION OR REPRODUCTION OF THIS PRELIMINARY OFFERING MEMORANDUM, IN WHOLE OR IN PART, IS UNAUTHORIZED. IF YOU HAVE GAINED ACCESS TO THIS TRANSMISSION CONTRARY TO ANY OF THE FOREGOING RESTRICTIONS, YOU ARE NOT AUTHORIZED AND WILL NOT BE ABLE TO PURCHASE ANY OF THE NOTES DESCRIBED HEREIN.

Subsection Title: Confirmation of your representation: In order to be eligible to view this Preliminary Offering
Subsubsection Text: Memorandum or make an investment decision with respect to the notes described therein, you must be (1) a QIB (within the meaning of Rule 144A) or (2) purchasing in offshore transactions outside the U.S. in reliance on Regulation S, provided that investors resident in a Member State of the EEA must be a qualified investor (within the meaning of Article 2(1)(e) of Directive 2003/71/EC and any relevant implementing measure in each Member State of the EEA). This Preliminary Offering Memorandum is being sent at your request, and by accepting this electronic transmission and accessing the Preliminary Offering Memorandum, you shall be deemed to have represented to us and the initial purchasers set forth in the Preliminary Offering Memorandum (collectively, the “Initial Purchasers”) that you consent to the delivery of such Preliminary Offering Memorandum by electronic transmission and either: (1) you and any customers you represent are QIBs; or (2) you and any customers you represent are outside of the United States, and the e-mail address that you gave us and to which this Preliminary Offering Memorandum has been delivered is not located in the United States, its territories and possessions (including Puerto Rico, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, Wake Island and the Northern Mariana Islands), any state of the United States or the District of Columbia, and if you are resident in a Member State of the European Economic Area, you are a qualified investor; and (3) if you are a resident in a Member State of the EEA, you are a qualified investor (within the meaning of Article 2(1)(e) of Directive 2003/761/EC), as amended, and any relevant implementing measure in each member state of the EEA). Prospective Purchasers that are QIBs are hereby notified that the seller of the notes may be relying on the exemption from the provisions of Section 5 of the Securities Act pursuant to Rule 144A. The materials relating to the offering do not constitute, and may not be used in connection with, an offer or solicitation in any place where offers or solicitations are not permitted by law. If a jurisdiction ----- requires that the offering be made by a licensed broker or dealer and the Initial Purchasers or any affiliate of the Initial Purchasers is a licensed broker or dealer in that jurisdiction, the offering shall be deemed to be made by the Initial Purchasers or such affiliate on behalf of the Issuer in such jurisdiction. Under no circumstances shall the Preliminary Offering Memorandum constitute an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy, nor shall there be any sale of, these securities in any jurisdiction in which such offer, solicitation or sale would be unlawful. The Preliminary Offering Memorandum has not been approved by an authorized person in the United Kingdom and is for distribution only to persons (i) who have professional experience in matters relating to investments (being investment professionals falling within Article 19(5) of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Financial Promotion) Order 2005 (as amended or superseded, the “Financial Promotion Order”)), (ii) falling within Article 49(2)(a) to (d) (“high net worth companies, unincorporated associations, etc.”) of the Financial Promotion Order, (iii) who are outside the United Kingdom or (iv) to whom an invitation or inducement to engage in investment activity (within the meaning of section 21 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000) in connection with the issue or sale of any securities may otherwise lawfully be communicated or caused to be communicated (all such persons together being referred to as “relevant persons”). The Preliminary Offering Memorandum is directed only at relevant persons and must not be acted on or relied on by persons who are not relevant persons. Any investment or investment activity to which the Preliminary Offering Memorandum relates is available only to relevant persons and will be engaged in only with relevant persons. No part of the Preliminary Offering Memorandum should be published, reproduced, distributed or otherwise made available in whole or in part to any other person. No person may communicate or cause to be communicated any invitation or inducement to engage in investment activity (within the meaning of Section 21 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000) received by it in connection with the issue or sale of the notes other than in circumstances in which Section 21(1) of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 does not apply to us. The Preliminary Offering Memorandum has been sent to you in electronic form. You are reminded that documents transmitted via this medium may be altered or changed during the process of electronic transmission and consequently none of the Initial Purchasers, any person who controls any of the Initial Purchasers, the Issuers, the Guarantors (each term, as defined in the Preliminary Offering Memorandum) for any of their respective directors, officers, employees or agents or affiliates of any of the foregoing entities or persons, accepts any liability or responsibility whatsoever in respect of any difference between the Preliminary Offering Memorandum distributed to you in electronic form and any version that will be provided to you at a later date on request from the Initial Purchasers. Neither the Initial Purchasers nor any of their respective affiliates accepts any responsibility whatsoever for the contents of the Preliminary Offering Memorandum or for any statement made or purported to be made by any of them, or any on their behalf, in connection with the Issuer, the Guarantors, the Trustee or the offer. The Initial Purchasers and their respective affiliates accordingly disclaim all and any liability whether arising in tort, contract or otherwise which they might otherwise have in respect of the Preliminary Offering Memorandum or any such statement. No representation or warranty, express or implied, is made by any of the Initial Purchasers or their respective affiliates as to the accuracy, completeness, verification or sufficiency of the information set out in the Preliminary Offering Memorandum. The Initial Purchasers are acting exclusively for the Issuers and the Guarantors and no one else in connection with any offer of the notes described in the Preliminary Offering Memorandum. They will not regard any other person (whether or not a recipient of the Preliminary Offering Memorandum) as their client in relation to any offer of the Notes described in the Preliminary Offering Memorandum and will not be responsible to anyone other than the Issuers or the Guarantors for providing the protections afforded to their clients nor for giving advice in relation to any offer of the notes described in the Preliminary Offering Memorandum or any transaction or arrangement referred to herein.

Subsection Title: Professional Investors and ECPs Only Target Market
Subsubsection Text: Solely for the purposes of the product approval process of Goldman Sachs International and Credit Suisse Securities (Europe) Limited (collectively, the “Manufacturers”), the target market assessment in respect of the debt securities described in the attached Preliminary Offering Memorandum has led to the conclusion that (i) the target market for such debt securities is eligible counterparties and professional clients only, each as defined in Directive 2014/65/EU (as amended or superseded, “MiFID II”), and (ii) all channels for distribution of such debt securities to eligible counterparties and professional clients are appropriate. Any person subsequently offering, selling or recommending such debt securities (a “distributor”) should take into consideration the Manufacturers’ target market ----- assessment; however, a distributor subject to MiFID II is responsible for undertaking its own target market assessment in respect of such debt securities (by either adopting or refining the Manufacturers’ target market assessment) and determining appropriate distribution channels.

Subsection Title: Prohibition of Sales to EEA Retail Investors
Subsubsection Text: The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to, and should not be offered, sold or otherwise made available to, any retail investor in the EEA. For these purposes, a retail investor means a person who is one or more of (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II, (ii) a customer within the meaning of Directive 2002/92/EC (as amended or superseded, the “Insurance Mediation Directive”), where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II or (iii) not a qualified investor as defined in Directive 2003/71/EC (as amended or superseded, the “Prospectus Directive”). Consequently, no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (as amended, the “PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes described in the Preliminary Offering Memorandum or otherwise making them available to retail investors in the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling such Notes or otherwise making them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the PRIIPS Regulation. You are reminded that this Preliminary Offering Memorandum has been delivered to you on the basis that you are a person into whose possession this Preliminary Offering Memorandum may be lawfully delivered in accordance with the laws of the jurisdiction in which you are located and you may not, nor are you authorized to, deliver this Preliminary Offering Memorandum to any other person. If you receive this document by e-mail, you should not reply by e-mail to this announcement. Any reply e-mail communications, including those you generated by using the “Reply” function on your e-mail software, will be ignored or rejected. If you receive this document by e-mail, your use of this email is at your own risk and it is your responsibility to take precautions to ensure that it is free from viruses and other items of a destructive nature.

Each Initial Purchaser will represent and agree that it will not cause the Issuers to breach the provisions of section 175 of the Companies Law (as amended), which prohibits it from making any invitation to the public in the Cayman Islands to subscribe for any of its securities, unless such securities of the Issuers are listed on the Cayman Islands Stock Exchange at the time of such invitation.

There shall be no invitation to the public in Jersey to apply for any Notes and there shall be no circulation in Jersey of any offer for subscription, sale or exchange of the Notes. ----- **SUBJECT TO COMPLETION, DATED 18 JULY 2019** PRELIMINARY OFFERING MEMORANDUM # $800,000,000 $ % Senior Secured Notes due 2026

# issued by GEMS MENASA (CAYMAN) LIMITED GEMS Education (Delaware) LLC GEMS MENASA (CAYMAN) LIMITED, incorporated as an exempted company under the laws of the Cayman Islands (the “Company”, the “Cayman Co-Issuer” or “GMCL”), and GEMS Education (Delaware) LLC, a limited liability company incorporated under the laws of the State of Delaware (the “U.S. Co-Issuer” and, together with the Cayman Co-Issuer, the “Issuers”), are offering $ in aggregate principal amount of their % senior secured notes due 2026 (the “Dollar Notes”) and € in aggregate principal amount of their % senior secured notes due 2026 (the “Euro Notes” and, together with the Dollar Notes, the “Notes”) (the “Offering”). The Notes will mature on 2026. Interest on the Notes will accrue from 2019 and will be paid semi-annually in arrears on each and . The first interest payment date will be 2020. The proceeds from the Offering will be used as described under “Use of Proceeds.” The Issuers may redeem some or all of the Notes at any time on or after 2022 at the redemption prices set forth in this offering memorandum (the “Offering Memorandum”), plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. At any time prior to 2022, the Issuers may also redeem up to 40% of the Notes using the proceeds of certain equity offerings, at redemption prices set forth in this Offering Memorandum, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (not including any additional Notes) remains outstanding after the redemption. See “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption.” In addition, at any time prior to 2022, the Issuers may redeem some or all of the Notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, plus a “make-whole” premium. The Notes may be redeemed at a price equal to their principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest upon the occurrence of certain changes in applicable tax law. Upon the occurrence of certain change of control events, the Issuers may be required to offer to redeem the Notes at 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the date of the redemption. The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuers and will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the Guarantors (as defined herein) as more fully described elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum (the “Guarantees”). The Senior Facilities (as defined herein) will also be guaranteed by the Guarantors. The Notes will be secured by a first priority security interest in the same assets that secure the Issuers’ and the Guarantors’ obligations under the Senior Facilities on a pari passu basis (as more fully described elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum), in each case subject to the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein), permitted liens and applicable local law limitations. The Notes and the Guarantees will rank equally in right of payment with all of the Issuers’ and Guarantors’ existing and future senior debt. The Notes and the Guarantees will be effectively senior to any of the Issuers’ and Guarantors’ existing and future unsecured debt, to the extent of the value of the assets securing the Notes. In addition, the Notes and the Guarantees will rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuers’ and Guarantors’ future subordinated debt and will be structurally subordinated to the liabilities of any non-Guarantor subsidiaries of the Issuers. The Collateral (as defined herein) may also secure certain additional indebtedness in the future, including on a super priority basis, pursuant to the terms and limitations set forth under the Indenture (as defined herein) as more fully described elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. If any such super senior indebtedness is incurred after the Issue Date, in the event of an enforcement of the Collateral, pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral only after such super senior indebtedness has been repaid in full. The validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor will be subject to significant limitations, as described in “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of _the Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_ There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”) for the listing of the Notes on the Official List of the International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”) and permission to deal in the Notes. There can be no assurance that the application will be accepted or that there will be a market for the Notes if the application is accepted. Consummation of the offering of the Notes is not contingent upon obtaining such listing.

Subsection Title: PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION General
Subsubsection Text: The historical financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, including the financial information discussed in “Summary—Summary Financial and Operating Information”, “Selected _Historical Financial Information” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”, has been derived from the audited consolidated financial statements of_ GMCL and its subsidiaries (the “Group”) as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and the interim unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements of the Group as at and for the nine months ended 31 May 2019, which includes, as comparative financial information, the audited consolidated financial data of the Group as at and for the nine months ended 31 May 2018 (together, the “Financial Statements”), each included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. We prepare our annual financial statements in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (“IFRS”). The condensed consolidated interim financial statements as at and for the nine months ended 31 May 2019 were prepared in accordance with International Accounting Standard (IAS) 34—“Interim Financial Reporting.” There could be significant differences between IFRS and generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America (“U.S. GAAP”), as applied to us. We neither describe the differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP nor reconcile our IFRS financial statements to U.S. GAAP. Accordingly, such information is not available to investors, and investors should consider this in making their investment decision. Certain comparative amounts as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 presented in the audited consolidated financial statements as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 have been reclassified to conform to the presentation of the audited consolidated financial statements as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. The non-current and current portions of deferred lease liabilities of $0.2 million and $54.8 million, respectively, have been reclassified as separate line items in the consolidated statement of financial position as at 31 August 2018. These amounts had been classified under accounts payables and accruals prior to the reclassification. This reclassification does not affect previously reported total equity and profit or loss as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2017. Furthermore, in the audited consolidated financial statements for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, the Group changed its definition of Adjusted EBITDA presented as part of segment information to also add back certain costs that were considered to be one-off costs, with an adjustment of $0.6 million of one-off costs made to the comparative segmental information to be consistent with the 31 August 2018 presentation. Financial information as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 appearing in this Offering Memorandum are based on amounts appearing as comparatives in the audited consolidated financial statements as at for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 found elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. In this Offering Memorandum, we present financial information on the basis of the segments presented in our Financial Statements. These segments are (i) School Operations, (ii) School Support Services and (iii) Corporate head office and others (“Corporate”). In this Offering Memorandum, we present financial information on the Guarantors’ contribution to revenue, operating profit, and total assets of the Group which is calculated on the basis of each Guarantor’s consolidated operating results and financial condition for the relevant period. In this Offering Memorandum, we also present summary unaudited financial data for the twelve months ended 31 May 2019. The unaudited financial data for the twelve months ended 31 May 2019 has been derived by subtracting audited consolidated statement of profit and loss data for the nine months ended 31 May 2018 from audited consolidated statement of profit and loss data for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 and adding interim unaudited consolidated statement of profit and loss data for the nine months ended 31 May 2019. The financial information for the twelve months ended 31 May 2019 has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and is not necessarily representative of our results of operations for any future period at any future date, is not prepared in the ordinary course of our financial reporting and has not been audited or reviewed by our independent auditors. The U.S. Co-Issuer was incorporated on 4 June 2019 for the purposes of facilitating the Transactions. The U.S. Co-Issuer has no material assets or liabilities and has not engaged in any activities other than those related to its incorporation and participation in the Transactions. Consequently, we have not included any financial information relating to the U.S. Co-Issuer in this Offering Memorandum. iii -----

Certain new accounting standards and interpretations that were not effective as of the date of issuance of our financial statements for periods covered in this Offering Memorandum are disclosed below and will be adopted where applicable when they become effective. For a description of other accounting changes not yet effective see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition_ _and_ _Results_ _of_ _Operations—Critical_ _accounting_ _policies—Recent_ _accounting pronouncements.”_ IFRS 16—Leases was issued in January 2016 and replaces IAS 17—Leases. The new standard brings most leases on the statement of financial position for lessees under a single model, eliminating the distinction between operating and finance leases. Under IFRS 16, a lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset and a lease liability. The right-of-use asset is treated similarly to other non-financial assets and is depreciated accordingly. The lease liability is initially measured at the present value of the lease payments payable over the lease term, discounted at the rate implicit in the lease if that can be readily determined. If that rate cannot be readily determined, the lessee shall use their incremental borrowing rate. Lessor accounting remains largely unchanged and the distinction between operating and finance leases is retained. IFRS 16 is expected to have a significant impact on the amounts recognized in our consolidated financial statements. On adoption of IFRS 16, we will recognize within the consolidated statement of financial position a right of use asset and lease liability for all applicable leases. Within the consolidated statement of profit or loss, rental- operating leases expense will be replaced by depreciation and finance costs. The standard will also impact a small number of measures such as operating profit and cash generated from operations, and alternative performance measures used by us. The full impact of IFRS 16 is currently under review, including understanding the practical application of the principles of the standard. It is therefore not practical to provide a reasonable estimate of the financial effect until this review is complete. We plan to adopt the new standard from the financial year beginning on 1 September 2019.

Subsubsection Title: EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
Subsubsection Text: - “EBITDA”: We define EBITDA as profit for the fiscal year/period before income tax expense, net finance costs, and depreciation, impairment and amortization. - “Adjusted EBITDA”: We define Adjusted EBITDA as EBITDA before one-off costs (which includes IPO expenses and other one-off costs), gains on disposal of subsidiaries and pre-operative expenses. - “Adjusted EBITDA Margin”: We define Adjusted EBITDA Margin as Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue. - “Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA”: We define Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to reflect certain normalization adjustments, the estimated pro forma EBITDA contributions from the acquisition of Bellevue Education, the estimated pro forma rental savings from the repurchase of two school building leases in Qatar and adjustments to add back the negative EBITDA generated by our greenfield investments in four new schools during their rampup phase. iv ----- EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA are not defined by or presented in accordance with IFRS, are not a measure of performance and should not be considered as alternatives to: - profit for the fiscal year/period (as determined in accordance with IFRS), or as a measure of operating performance; - cash flows from operating, investing or financing activities (as determined in accordance with IFRS), or as a measure of our liquidity; or - any other measures of performance under IFRS. EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as presented in this Offering Memorandum may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies due to differences in the way these measures are calculated. EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA have limitations as analytical tools, and an investor should not consider these measures in isolation from, or as a substitute for, analysis of our results of operations as reported under IFRS. Some limitations of EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as a measure are that: - EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments; - EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements, for our working capital needs; - EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA do not reflect the significant interest expense or the cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal repayments, in respect of any borrowings; - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized will often have to be replaced in the future and EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements; and - EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA may not be indicative of our historical operating results, nor are they meant to be a projection or forecast of future results. We believe that EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA provide useful information to investors because these measures allow for an analysis of our core performance which excludes the impact of certain non-operating factors. These measures can differ significantly from company to company depending on long-term strategic decisions regarding capital structure, the stage of growth development, capital expenditure requirements and the jurisdictions in which certain Group companies operate and make capital investments. In addition, we believe that EBITDA is a measure commonly used by investors, analysts and other interested parties in our industry. EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin and Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA are not subject to audit or review by any independent auditors.

Management uses certain additional non-IFRS financial measures to evaluate our operating performance. These measures include: - “ARPS”: We define ARPS for a given fiscal year/period as revenue for the fiscal year/period divided by the number of students as at the end of the fiscal year/period. - “Net secured debt”: We define net secured debt as total debt (or aggregate principal amount of debt outstanding) less bank balances and cash. - “Operating Cash Conversion Rate”: We define Operating Cash Conversion Rate as the ratio of (x) Recurring Operating Free Cash Flows to (y) Adjusted EBITDA. - “Recurring Operating Free Cash Flows”: We define Recurring Operating Free Cash Flows as Adjusted EBITDA, less income tax expense and maintenance and other non-discretionary capital expenditure. v ----- - “School ARPS”: We define School ARPS as ARPS attributable to the School Operations division. For additional detail on these measures, see “Summary—Summary Financial and Operating _Information—Operating Data and Non-IFRS Financial Information” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.”_

This Offering Memorandum contains certain measures that would be considered non-IFRS financial measures, as described below. There are no generally accepted accounting principles governing the calculation of such non-IFRS measures and the criteria upon which they are based can vary from company to company. We consider certain non-IFRS measures to be useful to better understand our trading performance. Such measures by themselves do not provide a sufficient basis to compare our performance with that of other companies and should not be considered in isolation, or as a substitute for, or as an alternative to, any other measures of performance under IFRS. For a reconciliation of these non-IFRS measures to IFRS financial information, see “Summary financial and operating _information—Operating Data and Non-IFRS Financial Information”._

The non-financial operating data included in this Offering Memorandum has been extracted without material adjustment from our management records and/or publicly available reports and are unaudited. These measures include: - “Enrollments”: We define enrollments as fee-paying students enrolled in school at period end. - “Capacity”: We define capacity as the total currently built enrollment capacity at period end. - “Capacity utilization”: We define capacity utilization as the ratio of enrollments to capacity. - “Pupil teacher ratio” or “PTR”: We define PTR as the ratio of enrolled students to teachers, measured at period end. For detail on these measures, see “Summary financial and operating information—Other operational _data”._

Unless otherwise indicated, all references in this Offering Memorandum to “sterling”, “pounds sterling”, or “£” are to the lawful currency of the United Kingdom. All references to “euro” or “€” are to the lawful currency of the European Monetary Union. All references to “AED” are to the lawful currency of the United Arab Emirates. All references to “dollars”, “$” or “US dollars” are to the lawful currency of the United States. The Company prepares its financial statements in dollars.

Percentages and certain amounts in this Offering Memorandum, including financial, statistical and operating information, have been rounded. As a result of the rounding, the totals of data presented in this Offering Memorandum may vary slightly from the actual arithmetic totals of such data. Percentages in tables have been rounded and accordingly may not add up to 100%. In addition, where the figure “0” appears in a table, it means that the relevant amount has been rounded to zero. Where the symbol “-” appears in a table, it means that no amount exists for the relevant item.

Unless otherwise indicated, such information is based on our customer feedback and internal surveys, third-party market research and reports, and government and other publicly available information, including information sourced from the government of the UAE, the UAE National Bureau of Statistics, the UAE Ministry of Education, the National Center for Education Statistics, the Dubai Statistics Centre, the Knowledge and Human Development Authority (the “KHDA”), the Abu Dhabi Department of Education and Knowledge (“ADEK”), the United Kingdom Department of Education, the World Bank, Oxford Economics, Boston Consulting Group, the Independent Schools Council, GSV Advisors LLC, Business Monitor International and L.E.K. We do not intend, and do not assume any obligation, to update industry or market data set forth in this Offering Memorandum. We are the world’s leading provider of private K-12 English-language education by revenues, operating in the UAE and Qatar. We are particularly focused on the UAE, the largest private education market in the world by revenue. Concurrently with the Offering, we are acquiring a 92.9% shareholding in Bellevue Education (“Bellevue”) from an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of the Varkey Group, one of our indirect shareholders (the “Acquisition”). Bellevue operates 15 schools, of which 14 are in the United Kingdom, and one is in Switzerland. Founded by Mr. Sunny Varkey (the “Founder”) and beginning with a single school in Dubai, we have been a pioneer of the UAE’s education system. As at 31 May 2019, we offered a diverse range of educational choices through 48 schools across three price points, Premium, Mid-Market Plus and Mid-Market, and four curricula, British, Indian, American and International Baccalaureate (“IB”). While over half of our schools teach the British curriculum, our students come from more than 170 countries, with British nationals representing only approximately 2% of our current students. As at 31 May 2019, 123,368 students were enrolled in our schools. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, students paid tuition fees ranging from $2,000 to $30,000 per student per annum and, for the twelve months ended 31 May 2019, we generated ARPS of $8,494. We also provide a comprehensive range of school support services, including school bus transportation, school uniform sales, sports management services, after-school activities, school catering, school security services and teacher training. We pride ourselves on providing consistently high-quality education and student outcomes, irrespective of a school’s price point, and our students have consistently outperformed their global peers in standardized examinations. For example, as at the date of this Offering Memorandum, 93% of our rated schools in Dubai (collectively, “Rated Schools”) were designated as “outstanding,” “very good” or “good” by the KHDA, the Dubai education regulator. As at 31 August 2018, the last period when comparable data was available, only 61% of non-GEMS schools were so rated in Dubai. According to data provided by the KHDA, we had a market share by enrollment in Dubai of 27.3% for the 2018-2019 academic year and our school portfolio had over three times the number of students as the Dubai public education system. Our commitment to providing high quality education through all of our curricula and price points has helped to drive our uninterrupted growth in enrollment and revenues for over 15 years. We have grown enrollment and revenues consistently, including during and after the global financial crisis in 2008, and during periods of regional conflict. From the twelve months ended 31 August 2006 to the nine months ended 31 May 2019, student enrollment grew at a CAGR of 8.1% and school revenue grew at a CAGR of 17.5%, in each case exceeding the CAGR of UAE GDP and the UAE’s population growth of 5.3% and 5.1% over the same period, respectively. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018, we had revenue of $789.7 million, $926.2 million and $1,022.5 million, respectively. Over the same periods, our Adjusted EBITDA was $212.8 million, $262.2 million and $282.6 million, respectively. In the nine months ended 31 May 2018 and 2019, we had revenue of $904.9 million and $928.0 million, respectively. Over the same periods, our Adjusted EBITDA was $306.0 million and $302.2 million, respectively. We currently operate through three business divisions corresponding to our financial reporting segments: (i) School Operations; (ii) School Support Services; and (iii) Corporate. Once we complete the Acquisition, we will operate Bellevue Education as a fourth division.

On 10 July 2019 we signed a $1.65 billion senior facilities agreement (the “Senior Facilities Agreement”) with Goldman Sachs Bank USA, Citigroup Global Markets Limited, Credit Suisse Loan Funding LLC, Credit Suisse AG, London Branch and HSBC Bank Middle East Limited. For additional details, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities.” 1 -----

Subsubsection Title: Acquisition of Bellevue from Varkey Global
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the Offering, we are acquiring a 92.9% shareholding in Bellevue from an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of the Varkey Group, one of our indirect shareholders. Bellevue operates 15 schools, of which 14 are in the United Kingdom, and one is in Switzerland. As at 31 May 2019, Bellevue educated 2,717 students. In connection with this acquisition, we expect to acquire £11 million of bank balances and cash held by Bellevue and assume £25 million of debt under Bellevue’s senior term and revolving facilities agreement, as further described under “Capitalization.” For further information on Bellevue, see “Business—Bellevue.”

We have exchanged contracts to buy Farlington School, an independent day and boarding school for pupils between ages four and eighteen in Horsham (“Farlington School”). We will pay approximately £0.9 million at completion on a debt-free cash free basis to the current owners, a charitable trust. Farlington was originally founded in 1896 and educates 233 students. The acquisition will be funded from existing cash resources and we anticipate completing in early September 2019. The property is leased, but we have an option to buy it within three years.

Subsubsection Title: Announcement of new KHDA fee framework and exceptional fee increases in the UAE
Subsubsection Text: In April 2019, the KHDA announced a revised fee framework for Dubai Schools. The fee framework allows schools with a rating of Acceptable or higher to increase fees by 2.07% for the 2019-2020 academic year. We will apply this fee increase to 26 of our 28 Dubai schools where we are eligible to do so. In one school we will apply the increase for only junior grades. For further information on fee frameworks, see “Regulation Overview—United Arab Emirates.” In addition, we have received permission for exceptional fee increases for the 2019-2020 academic year outside of the KHDA framework in seven schools in total, of which four are in Dubai, two are in Sharjah and one is in Abu Dhabi.

Subsubsection Title: Start of the 2019-2020 academic year in Indian curriculum-based schools
Subsubsection Text: In April 2019, our Indian curriculum-based schools started the 2019-2020 academic year. Even though capacity utilization within our Indian curriculum-based schools is the highest in our portfolio, we managed to increase the enrollment where there was capacity to do so. In April 2019 we also merged two schools, Our Own Boys School (“OOB”) and New Our Own English Private School (“EPS”), both mid-market Indian curriculum-based schools, on the site of EPS, in Sharjah. This merger allowed us to better utilize the newer facilities of the EPS site, which was developed during the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. We intend to refurbish the school buildings of the former OOB site into a new mid-market British curriculum-based school at a higher price point, which is scheduled to open in September 2019. We believe that the mid-market British curriculum-based offering is increasingly favored by parents in the UAE over monocultural Indian schooling. In addition, in April 2019 we reduced capacity, and therefore opening enrollment, at the Indian curriculum-based school Our Own Girls School (“OOS”) at the request of that school’s regulator, the Sharjah Private Education Authority (“SPEA”). Concurrently, we secured an exceptional fee increase for this school. In the aggregate, the impact of the merger of OOB and EPS and the reduction of capacity at OOS largely offset enrollment growth in our expanding Indian curriculum-based schools. As a result, we anticipate that the net enrollment in our Indian curriculum-based schools will remain largely flat between the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 and 2019.

Funds advised by CVC Capital Partners (“CVC Funds”) have led a consortium (the “CVC Consortium”) which has agreed to acquire a significant minority stake in GMHL. Upon completion of the transaction, the CVC Consortium will acquire a 30.5% stake from existing shareholders for an aggregate consideration of approximately $1.3 billion. The transaction is anticipated to close by the end of July 2019. 2 ----- The transaction will result in the exit by a consortium led by Fajr Capital Limited (“Fajr”), including Tactical Opportunities funds managed by Blackstone Tactical Opportunities Management Associates (“Blackstone”) and Bahrain Mumtalakat Holding Company B.S.C. (“Mumtalakat”), the sovereign wealth fund of the Kingdom of Bahrain, which acquired a significant minority stake in GMHL in 2014. Existing minority investor Teluk Kalung Investments Limited, a subsidiary of Khazanah Nasional Berhad (“Khazanah”), a sovereign wealth fund of Malaysia, which invested in January 2018, will retain its 3% stake in GMHL.

Subsubsection Title: Outlook for the twelve months ending 31 August 2020
Subsubsection Text: As at the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have largely completed the 2019-2020 academic year re-enrollment campaign for our British, American and IB curricula-based schools. During this campaign, parents are asked to pay a re-enrollment fee in order to be allocated a position in the coming academic year. This re-enrollment fee is generally offset against the coming semester’s tuition fee invoice. On a like-for-like basis, as at the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have secured a higher number of re-enrollment intentions for these schools than at the same date in the prior academic year. In particular, the absolute number of re-enrollment indications, and the percentage of students seeking to re-enroll in our Premium schools segment, is higher than in the prior year. As such we anticipate a lower churn rate in our British, American and IB curricula-based schools than in the prior academic year. Additionally, we continue to market our schools to new students (“new joiners”). We calculate new joiners based on the twelve months ending 30 June. The overall number of new joiners as of 30 June 2019 was slightly ahead of the number of new joiners as of 30 June 2018, and we additionally expect further new joiners to be attracted to our new school GCS, which we intend to open in September 2019. Nevertheless, we anticipate that the number of students in our Premium schools will be modestly lower in the twelve months ending 31 August 2020 than in the twelve months ending 31 August 2019, given subdued volumes of new joiners into the premium segment.

Subsubsection Title: We operate a leading global K-12 English-language education platform with significant competitive advantages and high barriers to entry
Subsubsection Text: We are the world’s largest provider of private K-12 English-language education. In Dubai, where the majority of our operations are based, we had approximately 80,000 students in the nine months ended 31 May 2019, making us more than six times larger than our next nearest competitor. We have also grown faster than our nearest rival in Dubai, with an enrollment CAGR from the 2010-2011 academic year to the 2018-2019 academic year of 7.0%, as compared to 3.8% for our nearest rival and 5.3% for the Dubai market as a whole. 3 ----- The following graphs set out our size as compared to our competitors and enrollment CAGR data for us and our nearest competitors in Dubai:

Subsubsection Title: Number of Students, thousands_** **_2011 – 2019 enrollment CAGR
Subsubsection Text: _Source: KHDA, 2019_ The large scale of our operations provides numerous benefits, including: - a high degree of market insight driven by our detailed visibility over the large numbers of students in our schools, as well as the volume of enquiries we receive; - the ability to efficiently allocate excess demand for our schools into other GEMS schools with available capacity; - the ability to rapidly spread best practices throughout our school portfolio, in particular through cost management and performance benchmarking; - the cost-effective use of centralized support functions, such as finance, legal, information technology, business development, recruitment, maintenance and human resources, to support large numbers of schools simultaneously; and - the ability to attract talented teaching professionals from around the world. We believe that we have a long-term track record of, and reputation for, delivering high-quality education. Although most of our students do not use English as their first language, they have consistently outperformed their global peers in standardized examinations across our curricula, including for UK A levels, average IB diploma score, Indian Central Board of Secondary Education (“CBSE”) pass rates and results in the Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study (“TIMSS”). Our graduates have been accepted to all eight Ivy League universities, all of the top 50 UK universities and 1,050 universities in 53 countries. This track record of academic outperformance has strengthened our brand and reputation in our markets, allowing us to fill available capacity at new schools, maintain high levels of student re-enrollment and further improve our academic profile. Our teachers and senior administrative staff are highly qualified and experienced, and are recruited through a rigorous hiring process which we manage centrally. We are one of the largest employers of British, North American and Indian teachers outside of their respective home countries, and in the nine months ended 31 May 2019, we received approximately 65,000 applications for the approximately 1,300 teaching positions we had available, enabling us to be highly selective in hiring staff. This selectivity has allowed us to recruit a diverse and talented teacher base, with teachers coming from over 90 countries and a wide variety of specialist fields. We attract this quantity of high quality teaching applications because of our international scale, strong brand, reputation for quality and competitive compensation packages. We emphasize ongoing professional development through our teacher training program, operated by TELLAL, a GEMS brand and the first fully accredited teacher training institute in the UAE, which is certified to grant teaching qualifications recognized both in the UAE and globally. Over half of our teachers have been with us for more than three years, and our teacher turnover rates are below the industry average for Dubai, and we believe that our commitment to professional development is key to maintaining these strong teacher retention rates. We are a trusted partner for key stakeholders in the education sector, including regulatory bodies, teachers, parents and real estate developers. In particular, our net promoter score (“NPS”) from 4 ----- parents has doubled over the past year to 14, with 37% of our students’ parents scoring their child’s school as a nine or ten out of ten. Our reputation and credibility with these stakeholders provide numerous benefits, including high demand for our services, access to high quality teachers and access to strategically located land for school construction. We benefit from the strategic location of our schools in proximity to residential areas in the UAE. Furthermore, our reputation and relationships with stakeholders provide us with early access to desirable locations for the development of new schools, and our land bank allows us to strategically hold properties at a low cost until the development opportunity matures. Our existing scale, financial resources, operational experience and deep institutional knowledge allows us to better address certain structural hurdles in expanding in existing markets and entering new markets compared to other operators. For instance, significant financial resources are required in order to invest in new school facilities or to acquire existing schools. Our broad experience coupled with our strong understanding of the local markets facilitates our ability to meet legal, financial and other requirements in securing government licenses and regulatory approvals in multiple jurisdictions. Additionally, centralized expertise and local knowledge helps us address the issue of the scarcity of suitable sites in key markets and the tendency of property developers and landlords to prefer operators with a strong track record and financial resources. Our long and positive track record and established reputation underpins our ability to recruit and retain high quality teachers, particularly in expatriate markets.

Subsubsection Title: We operate in the largest private K-12 market in the world with the most attractive growth trends
Subsubsection Text: The UAE private K-12 market is large and growing. In total, the estimated revenue of the UAE private K-12 education market in 2017 was $4.4 billion. In 2018, revenue for the private international K-12 segment was $3.4 billion, and this segment is forecast to grow by approximately 10% per year for the next five years. Of this $3.4 billion, Dubai represented $2.3 billion of the market value and Abu Dhabi represented $1.1 billion. This growth has been driven by several economic and political growth trends, including historic population growth and economic expansion, a young, skilled population, increasing population stickiness, government focus on quality education and ongoing price and cost inflation. The UAE has several structural advantages with respect to the education sector, including: - a high degree of private school penetration in K-12 education; - private schools provide the highest quality of education; - UAE private schools focus on residents, who generally stay longer than non-residents; and - most students in the UAE are young and, because of this, private school enrollments generally ramp up from the lowest grades onwards. The following graph sets out private K-12 enrollments by country:
We believe that our competitive strengths are as follows:

Subsubsection Title: We operate a vertically integrated business model, offering a wide variety of services which drive revenue diversification and expand our addressable market
Subsubsection Text: We have a diversified business model, generating revenue through our School Operations division as well as our School Support Services division. In addition, on completion of the Acquisition, we will also generate revenue through our Bellevue division. Our School Operations division provides a diversified offering across multiple curricula (British, Indian, American and IB) and price points (Premium, Mid-Market Plus and Mid-Market). This diversity of offering expands our addressable market by allowing us to provide offerings that are attractive to parents across a variety of socioeconomic groups. This diversity also decreases our reliance on any one socioeconomic group, thereby decreasing volatility in enrollment numbers. The following chart illustrates the differences between our Mid-Market, Mid-Market Plus and Premium schools: The School Operations division is complemented by our School Support Services division, which offers a variety of education-related support services to our students as well as third parties. We are able to provide services and drive revenue throughout the school day, from selling school uniforms, to transporting children to and from school, to providing sports management services and other extracurricular activities after education has ended for the day. The acquisition of Bellevue, which operates 15 schools, of which 14 are in the United Kingdom and one is in Switzerland, as well as the acquisition of Farlington School in the United Kingdom, will further diversify our schools offering and provide us with a more geographically diversified revenue base.

Subsubsection Title: Our attractive and profitable business model delivers high revenue visibility and sustained profitability and cash flow conversion
Subsubsection Text: We have high visibility over student enrollment levels for upcoming academic years well before they begin. We initiate our re-enrollment campaigns for British, American and IB curricula-based schools in February, far ahead of the start of the school year in September. Historically, we have achieved a re-enrollment rate of approximately 80% by May for these curricula. Moreover, at a majority of our schools, the terms and conditions of enrollment require a full term’s notice of withdrawal for a refund of prepaid tuition. 6 ----- The following graph, based on representative data from prior year results, demonstrates our build-up of the enrollment budget for the 2019 academic year. It demonstrates how we progressively build visibility over opening enrollment levels for the upcoming academic year by collecting both re-enrollment intentions from existing students, and securing enrollments from new joiners.

Subsubsection Title: We benefit from a well-invested portfolio with low capital intensity, which is positioned for growth
Subsubsection Text: Between September 2013 and February 2019, we opened 18 schools. Since 1 September 2015, we have invested approximately $1.1 billion in capital expenditures on the construction and development of these schools. These Maturing Schools and New Schools are now built and require no further significant investment to maintain current capacity levels. As of 31 May 2019, these schools had an aggregate unfilled capacity of approximately 22,000 seats, leaving substantial room for additional student enrollments without the need for further investment in capacity expansion. Furthermore, ARPS at these Maturing Schools and New Schools are generally higher than those at Mature Schools, even within similar price brackets, reflecting the overall fee inflation across the market. Taken together, these factors are expected to allow Maturing Schools and New Schools to contribute material Adjusted EBITDA growth at minimal incremental cost. The following graphs set forth our capacity utilization of Maturing schools by cohort year of opening, as at 31 August 2017 and as at 31 May 2019:

Subsection Title: May c.80% of re-enrolment indications achieved + Start of Indian curriculum September 100% of opening enrolment
Subsubsection Text: Oct Nov Dec Jan Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jul Aug Sep Our market share in Dubai allows us a high degree of visibility over the shape of demand across the market (e.g., by price point). In the last three fiscal years, approximately half of our revenue growth was driven by regulated yearly fee increases, which are in turn dependent (in Dubai, our largest market) on the ECI and the school ratings published by the KHDA. As the ECI for an academic year is published in advance and the DSIB typically publishes school ratings for the upcoming academic year in April or May, we generally have time to plan for the permitted fee levels at each of our schools and manage our cost base accordingly. See “Business—Our Business—The School Operations division— _Tuition fee increases”. For example, we learned in June 2018 that we were not permitted to increase_ fees in our Dubai schools for the following academic year and, as a result, we focused on reducing our cost base in advance of the following academic year. We benefit from strong Adjusted EBITDA margins, which reflect the significant benefits of our scale, our high degree of revenue visibility and our efficient and controlled cost base. Fifteen of our schools began operating between September 2013 and August 2017 (“Maturing Schools”) and three of our schools began operating in September 2017 or later (“New Schools”). Both those schools which began operating prior to September 2013 (“Mature Schools”) and Maturing Schools have grown enrollment year-on-year between the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019. Occupancy levels for our Maturing Schools increased year-on-year over the same period. We benefit from low non-discretionary capital expenditures (mainly in relation to maintenance investments and support services, primarily transportation). We enjoy favorable working capital dynamics, due to parents prepaying tuition fees for the upcoming school semester or year, although the year-end position can be impacted by the start date of the new school year. We also benefit from a favorable tax regime, as the UAE does not currently impose income or corporate tax on our business. Furthermore, we benefit from a zero VAT-rating for school fees and certain other services we provide. 7 -----

Subsubsection Title: We are Founder-sponsored and led by an experienced, professional executive management team
Subsubsection Text: We were founded by the Varkey Family in 1968 and have benefited from their deep knowledge and understanding of the education sector, which has allowed us to take advantage of the growth opportunities in our markets. In particular, we have benefited from our Executive Vice Chairman, Sunny Varkey’s, deep knowledge of the sector and strong relationships with relevant education stakeholders in the UAE. Our school management team has deep educational and operational management expertise at the corporate and school levels. Our entire corporate education team has held positions of leadership responsibility in schools and/or regulatory education authorities. Our principals and other senior administrative staff also have an exceptional track record of teaching in leading academic institutions and are supported by our Academic Council of leading educators from around the world.

Subsection Title: Current Capacity Utilization of Maturing Schools, by Year of Opening, as at 31 May 2019
Subsubsection Text: 7 Schools Opened in 12 Months to 1-Aug-2014 3 Schools 2 Schools 3 Schools Opened in FY 2015 Opened in FY 2016 Opened in FY 2017 Utilization of Opening Capacity Utilization of Total Current Built Capacity We have multiple opportunities for further profitable growth, including growth through expansion of existing schools, greenfield site development of new schools and acquisitions. We have a clear investment framework, allowing us to efficiently and profitably expand into new locations, as well as a proven track record of successfully developing new schools, having opened 18 new schools between September 2013 and February 2019. Our efficient construction process and strong ties with CMC have enabled us to consistently meet our construction timelines for new schools, and we have always been able to open new schools at the beginning of the school year. We expect to open one school in September 2019 and another in September 2020, with additional schools to open in the following years. We also have a land bank of 16 additional sites across the UAE. Taken together, these projects give us various options for further capacity expansion, subject to market demand, over which we have good visibility and can choose a school’s price point nearer the time of opening. This record of successful and ongoing development is supported by additional factors, including our access to prime locations, our strong relationship with local authorities, our flexible approach and extensive experience in opening schools, our disciplined investment framework and our ability to benefit from our scale which provides us with high visibility of market conditions. 8 ----- Our growth opportunities are also not restricted to our current core UAE markets, as demonstrated by the Acquisition, which expands our offering in the UK and Switzerland, and our plan to develop a new school site in the United Kingdom. We also have the potential to grow by investing in our School Support Services division, both by increasing the penetration of this business among our existing students and by providing these services to non-GEMS schools and other clients. We can also grow this business by acquiring additional school support service businesses, such as the Hamilton Aquatics swim academy, which we acquired in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, and integrating them into the larger framework of School Support Services.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to deliver high-quality education and strong outcomes for students
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our commitment to the provision of a high quality educational experience to our students is the foundation of our operating performance and growth. Our educational model focuses on our students, with parents and teachers contributing to student success, and strong school leadership teams setting school direction, overseeing improvement plans and resources and ensuring quality of teaching, learning and the wider student offering. We intend to continue to offer our students an excellent education by recruiting and retaining experienced and highly qualified principals and teachers and striving to help each student achieve high academic performance. We have shown strong academic results to date, with our students outperforming their global peers in terms of UK A levels, average IB diploma scores, Indian CBSE pass rates and TIMSS results, and we intend to continue to build upon our strong academic results. We believe that our reputation for quality and our desire to exceed the expectations of our students and parents are key to strengthening our position as the world’s leading provider of private K-12 English-language education.

Subsubsection Title: Increase student enrollment at schools with available capacity
Subsubsection Text: We aim to continue to increase enrollment by applying our systematic processes for generating inquiries, converting inquiries to enrollments and retaining existing students. We have a centralized enrollment team that works in parallel with dedicated admissions officers at each school. This allows us to leverage demand and enquiry data from across our portfolio of schools, and to refer demand from schools operating at full capacity to schools with available capacity. We intend to focus our efforts on increasing enrollments at our Maturing Schools and New Schools, which have greater levels of available capacity.

Subsubsection Title: Increase capacity in existing markets and evaluate new markets
Subsubsection Text: We intend to expand at our existing schools where market demand supports additional capacity development. We also intend to relocate and transplant certain existing schools to new locations, as this can allow existing schools to be redeveloped on sites with greater expansion capacity and also 9 ----- resets the baseline fee level for existing schools which, due to the regulatory cap on yearly fee increases, are below the current market rate for a school of that type. To support this strategy, we intend to continue developing our relationships with real estate developers and landlords, who we expect will continue to be key stakeholders in relation to our expansion of capacity at existing schools. We intend to continue to open new schools in the UAE and potentially in other new markets. In the UAE, we intend to open one new school in the twelve months ended 31 August 2020, and will continue developing new schools at greenfield sites at a more moderate rate than in prior years, largely focused on relocation and expansions of existing successful schools. While we have primarily grown organically in our existing markets to date, we may also seek to acquire single schools or portfolios of schools that meet our acquisition criteria, as demonstrated by our acquisition of Wesgreen International School in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 and our ongoing acquisition of Bellevue. We seek to acquire existing schools when there is no overlap with existing GEMS schools, there is an opportunity to improve the school’s operational or financial model and there is scope for school expansion on the existing site. Acquiring existing Mature Schools also allows us to benefit from an immediate, large increase in enrollments without needing to wait for enrollment levels to increase year over year, as we would for a Maturing School or New School. We regularly evaluate opportunities in adjacent markets in the GCC, which are characterized by lower political risk, strong underlying economic growth, large youth populations and a lack of public-sector education provisions. We believe that we may have a competitive advantage in these markets due to our deep experience in the K-12 educational sector and our ability to leverage the benefits of our portfolio of established schools, school support services and high-quality staff.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to recruit and develop exceptional teachers
Subsubsection Text: We emphasize the recruitment and development of high quality teachers. Our teachers are drawn from 90 countries and a wide variety of specialist fields, and we intend to continue recruiting teachers who can provide our students with globally recognized qualifications. We seek experienced teachers who are learners themselves, and who are experts in classroom organization and flexible in their teaching approach, as well as up to date on their subject knowledge and IT. We also seek teachers who are respectful of students and their community, and who aim to instill character, ambition and values in students, together with knowledge and understanding. We also seek to continuously improve our teachers through the teacher training that we provide through TELLAL. TELLAL is KHDA-approved, and the only institution in the UAE able to offer postgraduate teacher training, including for specialist Arabic teachers. Through TELLAL, we intend to continue developing and delivering proprietary training programs, including for teacher training, teacher and leader licensing preparation, leadership and management training, professional development and learning, and Arabic teacher training. We intend to continue using TELLAL to steer high quality teachers to our schools. To date, 90% of participants who have completed a TELLAL program have gone on to be teachers.

Subsubsection Title: Further grow our School Support Services division
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue expanding our School Support Services division by investing in the services it provides and acquiring additional school support service businesses. In particular, we intend to seek out acquisitions of businesses that provide services related to additional parts of the school day that we currently do not cover, such as our recent acquisition of Hamilton Aquatics, which allowed us to provide additional aquatics-related services to students. We currently provide many of our School Support Services to third parties, in addition to our own students, and intend to expand this division by providing our offering to additional third parties, as well as by leveraging our existing student base.

We expect to receive gross proceeds from the Offering of approximately $800.0 million (equivalent) before deducting the Initial Purchasers’ discount and the estimated fees and expenses and before giving effect to any original issue discount. We intend to use the proceeds from the Offering, together with the proceeds from the Term Loan B Facility, (i) to repay in full the amounts outstanding under the Existing Senior Facilities, (ii) to finance the acquisition of Bellevue,[,] (iii) to repurchase certain school leases in Qatar, (iv) to make a distribution to our holding companies and shareholders, (v) to pay fees and expenses associated with the Transactions and (vi) for general corporate purposes. We expect no amounts to be drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Issue Date. The expected estimated sources and uses of the funds necessary to consummate the Transactions, including the Offering and the use of proceeds therefrom, are shown in the table below. Actual amounts may vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including actual fees and expenses, the actual amount of indebtedness and the actual Issue Date.

As used in this Offering Memorandum, the term “Transactions” means, collectively, (i) the Offering of the Notes and the use of proceeds therefrom; (ii) the entry into the Senior Facilities, the borrowing thereunder and the use of proceeds therefrom; (iii) the termination of, and repayment in full of, the outstanding amounts under the Existing Senior Facilities; (iv) the acquisition of Bellevue from Varkey 10 ----- Global; (iv) the repurchase of certain leases related to two school buildings in Qatar that are currently subject to sale and leaseback arrangements; (v) the distribution of $115.0 million to holding companies and shareholders; and (vi) the payment of fees and expenses in connection with the foregoing. See “—Recent Developments” and “Use of Proceeds”.

GEMS MENASA (CAYMAN) LIMITED was incorporated and registered in the Cayman Islands as an exempted company on 19 February 2007, with registration number 181964. The registered address of the Cayman Co-Issuer is PO Box 309, Ugland House, Grand Cayman, KY1 – 1104, Cayman Islands. The principal activities of the Cayman Co-Issuer and its subsidiaries are to invest in, manage and operate K-12 schools and to provide associated educational services. 11 -----

GEMS Education (Delaware) LLC is a Delaware limited liability company (file number 7451167) and is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Cayman Co-Issuer. The U.S. Co-Issuer was incorporated and registered in the state of Delaware on 4 June 2019. The registered address of the U.S. Co-Issuer is 1209 Orange Street, Wilmington, Delaware 19801. The U.S. Co-Issuer was formed solely for the purpose of serving as a U.S. organized co-issuer of the Notes of the Cayman Co-Issuer in order to facilitate the offering of the Notes. Other than acting as co-issuer of the Notes, the U.S. Co-Issuer will not have any operations or assets and will not have any revenue. As a result, prospective purchasers of the Notes should not expect the U.S. Co-Issuer to participate in servicing the principal, interest and other obligations on the Notes.

CVC Capital Partners is a leading private equity and investment advisory firm. Founded in 1981, CVC today has a network of 24 offices and over 500 employees throughout Europe, Asia and the US. To date, CVC has secured commitments of over US$123 billion from some of the world’s leading institutional investors across its private equity and credit strategies. In total, CVC currently manages approximately US$76 billion of assets. Today, funds managed or advised by CVC are invested in 75 companies worldwide, employing c.300,000 people in numerous countries. Together, these companies have combined annual sales of over approximately US$100 billion. 12 -----

No later than the later of the date falling 10 business days after the Issue Date or 10 business days after the date on which a notary public in the United Arab Emirates has approved the share pledge, the Notes will be secured by share pledges over the entire issued share capital of each UAE Guarantor (together with the Initial Collateral, the “Collateral”). The Collateral will also secure on a first-ranking basis the Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations and may also secure certain future indebtedness. 17 ----- The Collateral may also secure certain additional indebtedness in the future, including on a super priority basis, pursuant to the terms and limitations set forth under the Indenture, as further described under “Description of Notes.” If any such super senior indebtedness is incurred after the Issue Date, in the event of an enforcement of the Collateral, pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral only after such super senior indebtedness has been repaid in full. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes _Guarantees and Our Structure—The Notes will be secured only to the extent of the value of the assets that have been granted as security for the Notes” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.”_ The security interests in the Collateral will be granted subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and the Agreed Security Principles and may be limited by applicable law or certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability. See “Description _of_ _Notes—Security,” “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees _and the Security Interests” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and Our Structure.”_ The security interests in the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description _of_ _Certain Indebtedness—New_ _Intercreditor_ _Agreement”_ and “Description of Notes—Security—Release of Liens.” Additional Amounts . . . . . . . . . . .** All payments that a Payor (as defined herein) makes with respect to the Notes will be made without withholding or deduction for, or on account of, any present or future taxes in any relevant taxing jurisdiction unless required by applicable law. If withholding or deduction for such taxes is required to be made with respect to a payment on the Notes, subject to certain exceptions, the Payor will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by the holders of the Notes after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of Notes— _Withholding Taxes.”_

Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Prior to 2022, the Issuers will be entitled at their option to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes plus the applicable “make-whole” premium described in this Offering Memorandum and accrued and unpaid interest to but excluding the redemption date. At any time prior to 2022, the Issuers may on one or more occasions redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes, using the net proceeds from certain equity offerings at a redemption price equal to % of the principal amount of the Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, to but excluding the date of redemption; provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Notes (not including any 18 ----- additional notes) remains outstanding after the redemption. See “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption.” The Issuers may redeem all or part of the Notes at any time on or after 2022, at the redemption prices described under “Description of Notes—Optional Redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to but excluding the date of redemption.

Reasons . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuers may redeem the affected series of Notes, in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to but excluding the date of redemption. See “Description of Notes—Redemption for _Taxation Reasons.”_ Change of Control . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Issuers may be required to make an offer to purchase the outstanding Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of their principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to but excluding the date of purchase. See “Description of Notes— _Change of Control.”_ Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture, among other things, will restrict the ability of the Issuers and its restricted subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make certain investments; - make certain other restricted payments; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of the restricted subsidiaries to pay dividends; - transfer or sell certain assets; - merge or consolidate with other entities; - enter into certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if the Notes obtain and maintain an investment-grade rating. Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description _of_ _Notes—Certain _Covenants.”_ Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange and permission to deal in the Notes. The Exchange is not a regulated market pursuant to the provisions of Directive 2004/39/EC. There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange or that such permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange will be granted. 19 ----- Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Transfer Restrictions.” We have not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the Notes (including by way of an exchange offer).

Subsection Title: Absence of a Public Market for
Subsubsection Text: the Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will be new securities for which there will be no established trading market. Accordingly, we cannot assure you as to the development or liquidity of any market for the Notes. Furthermore, the Notes will not have registration rights under the Securities Act. Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture, the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Intercreditor Agreement will be governed by English law. The security documents will be governed by the laws of the Cayman Islands, the United Arab Emirates and the State of Delaware, respectively. Trustee . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** GLAS Trustees Limited.
