The following summary of the Offering of the Notes contains basic information about the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral. It is not intended to be complete and it is subject to important limitations and exceptions. It may therefore not contain all the information that is important to you. For a more complete understanding of the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral, including certain definitions of terms used in this summary, please refer to the sections of this Offering Memorandum entitled “Description of Notes” and “Description of Certain Indebtedness.” Issuers . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** GEMS MENASA (CAYMAN) LIMITED and GEMS Education (Delaware) LLC. Notes Offered . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** $800,000,000 (equivalent) aggregate principal amount of Senior Secured Notes due 2026 consisting of: $ aggregate principal amount of % Senior Secured Notes due 2026 (the “Dollar Notes”); and € aggregate principal amount of % Senior Secured Notes due 2026 (the “Euro Notes” and, together with the Dollar Notes, the “Notes”). Maturity Date . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .**, 2026. Issue Date . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .**, 2019 (the “Issue Date”). Issue Price . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Dollar Notes: %, plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date, if any. Euro Notes: %, plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date, if any. Interest Rate . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Dollar Notes: % per annum. Euro Notes: % per annum. Interest Payment Dates . . . . . . . . . .** Semi-annually in arrears on each and, commencing on 2020. Form and Denomination . . . . . . . . .** Dollar Notes: Global notes in denominations of $200,000 and integral multiples of $1,000 in excess of $200,000. Notes in denominations less than $200,000 will not be available. Euro Notes: Global notes in denominations of €100,000 and integral multiples of €1,000 in excess of €100,000. Notes in denominations less than €100,000 will not be available. Ranking of the Notes . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will: - be general senior obligations of the Issuers, secured as set forth under “Description of Notes—Security”; - rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future Indebtedness of the Issuers that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the Senior Facilities; - be secured on a first-priority basis by the Collateral, along with obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility; - rank senior in right of payment to any future Indebtedness of the Issuers that is expressly subordinated to the Notes; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness or obligation (including obligations to trade 15 ----- creditors) of the Issuers and its Subsidiaries that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such Indebtedness; - be effectively subordinated to any existing or future Indebtedness of the Subsidiaries of the Issuers that are not Guarantors; and - be unconditionally guaranteed on a senior basis by the Guarantors, subject to the limitations described herein and in “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Notes, the _Notes_ _Guarantees_ _and_ _Our_ _Structure—Each_ _Notes Guarantee and security interest will be subject to certain limitations_ _on_ _enforcement_ _and_ _may_ _be_ _limited_ _by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit its validity and enforceability” and “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_ Guarantees . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will not be guaranteed on the Issue Date. No later than 60 days after the Issue Date the Notes will be guaranteed, jointly and severally on a senior basis, by the UAE Guarantors (Premier School International LLC, School Transport Services LLC and GEMS Wellington Academy FZE) and GEMS Menasa IPCO (Cayman) Limited (together, the “Guarantors”). Each of the Guarantors is also be a guarantor under the Senior Facilities. The validity and enforceability of the Notes Guarantees will be subject to significant limitations, as described in “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of _the Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_ As of and for the twelve months ended 31 May 2019, the Guarantors represented 92.6%, 130.9% and 89.7% of the Group’s consolidated revenue, operating profit and total assets, respectively. On an as adjusted basis giving effect to the Transactions as of 31 May 2019, the subsidiaries of the Issuers that will not guarantee the Notes would have had $31.5 million in outstanding debt.

We define EBITDA as profit for the fiscal year/period before income tax expense, net finance costs and depreciation, impairment and amortization. We define Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to reflect certain normalization adjustments, the estimated pro forma EBITDA contribution from the acquisition of Bellevue Education, the estimated pro forma rental savings from the repurchase of two school building leases in Qatar and adjustments to add back the negative EBITDA generated by greenfield investments in four new schools during their ramp-up phase. Investors should not consider EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA or Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA (a) as an alternative to operating profit/(loss) as a measure of our operating performance, (b) as an alternative to net cash outflows or inflows from operating, investing and financing activities as a measure of our ability to meet cash needs or (c) as an alternative to any other measure of performance under IFRS. EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA as presented in this Offering Memorandum may not be comparable to similarly titled measures reported by other companies due to differences in the way these measures are calculated. Some of the factors that could result in the newly acquired or existing schools’ results of operations not achieving the anticipated Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA include the failure to adequately integrate new acquisitions into our network or slower integration than expected, adverse macroeconomic conditions in the regions where the new schools are located, increased competition from local or other international school operators and the failure to retain existing students at the school and/or increase enrollments to meet unfilled capacity. Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business and reputation are dependent on maintaining appropriate child safeguarding and health and safety practices, and we may suffer adverse consequences as a result of accidents or other events that affect our students, employees or third parties for which we are responsible.
Subsubsection Text: We are required to maintain the highest standards of child safeguarding, health and safety, and are required to comply with extensive laws and regulations relating to child protection and the health and safety of children attending our schools or using the ancillary services provided by our Schools Support Services division. We must also comply with teacher and staff health and safety and child safeguarding training obligations and maintain our schools to applicable standards. A breach of these standards could result from, among other things, any of the following: - members of staff behaving or being perceived to be behaving inappropriately or illegally; - members of staff failing to appropriately supervise students under their care; - a failure to conduct proper checks on members of staff who come into contact with children; and - accidents, physical or emotional abuse or bullying or other events occurring at our schools or in the course of school-sanctioned outings that adversely affect students or other individuals. Our business is exposed to liability for the actions of our principals, teachers, other staff and students on and off our schools’ premises, as well as for any accidents, injuries or incidents resulting from activities organized by or for us at other locations. We may also be held responsible for the health and safety of our students, staff or third parties at schools or at events supervised by our staff. In addition, as part of the School Support Services division, we provide school bus transportation services, which entail certain risks for which we could be held responsible, including those mentioned above, as well as traffic accidents and related injuries. We also rent out our facilities for sports, aquatics, tutoring and other co-curricular activities to third parties. We could be held responsible for injuries or accidents at our facilities, even when the related activities are being run by third parties. This risk is increased for activities such as sports and aquatics, which place participants at higher risk of injuries or accidents. Furthermore, we also provide catering services, which entail risks relating to labelling and allergies. Moreover, while we require third party providers to confirm that their employees are suitably qualified and, where required, certified, to provide their services, we are unable to undertake the same type of background checks and other safeguarding activities for individuals employed by these third-party service providers that we do for our own employees, exposing us to an increased risk of an adverse incident. 30 ----- If personal injuries, accidents or losses occur, we may face claims from parents, government authorities or other parties alleging that we were negligent, provided inadequate supervision or were otherwise responsible for causing injury, death, accident or loss. We may also face allegations that teachers or other personnel committed unlawful acts. If any of these events occur, we could also face regulatory sanctions, loss of licenses and educational permits, fines or other financial or reputational harm. The occurrence or alleged occurrence of any event that negatively impacts our students or that otherwise exposes us to liability could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our financial performance depends on our ability to attract new students and retain existing students.
Subsubsection Text: Our financial performance depends on our ability to attract new students, retain existing students and maximize school occupancy rates. Factors affecting student recruitment and retention rates include competition from other private education providers (particularly with respect to our Premium schools), our ability to maintain our pricing levels at competitive levels, competition from public sector schools, economic downturns, political instability in the Middle East and North Africa (“MENA”) region, declines in school academic performance, teacher quality, infrastructure and facilities quality or reputation, a failure to maintain curricula that are attractive to students and parents, or disruptive events which cause a temporary or permanent closure of any of our schools. Each year students leave our schools for a variety of reasons, including expatriate relocations, relocations to other countries to complete their secondary education, enrollment in competitors’ schools and graduation from the highest grade at their school. While we seek to grow our overall student base to support re-enrollment and offset losses by recruiting new students, net enrollment may decline if we are unable to do so. If we are unable to recruit new students and retain current students, our revenue would decline, which would have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Demand for our services is affected by macroeconomic conditions and education policies and trends in our markets, particularly Dubai and Abu Dhabi.
Subsubsection Text: Demand for our services is affected by economic and political conditions in or affecting our chosen markets, particularly Dubai and Abu Dhabi, where a significant proportion of our operations are located. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, 74% and 85% of our revenues and Adjusted EBITDA, respectively, were attributable to our operations in Dubai and Abu Dhabi. As substantially all of our revenues are derived from our operations in these locations, any changes in the political, social, economic or other conditions in the UAE, particularly events which impact Dubai’s or Abu Dhabi’s attractiveness as jurisdictions in which to do business and as markets for expatriates, as well as any factors that result in a decline in the expatriate population of the UAE, may lead to a significant fall in enrollment demand at our schools, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Although economic growth rates in the UAE remain significantly above those of more developed markets as well as regional markets, the UAE has experienced slowing economic growth in recent years. In addition, the economy of the UAE is heavily dependent on expatriate workers and consumers, and any reduction in their numbers or their compensation or benefits, or increase in the taxes they pay, could materially adversely affect demand for our services. The finances of the federal government and certain of the emirates are highly impacted by revenue from oil and oil-based products, the prices for which declined sharply during the economic crisis and have continued to remain volatile, with significant decreases experienced since 2014, and a period of significant volatility since 2018. In addition to the oil and gas sector, the economy of the UAE, and Dubai in particular, is also exposed to trends in regional and international tourism. There can be no assurance that economic growth or performance in Dubai, Abu Dhabi and the UAE in general, as well as our other markets, will be sustained. If the economies of any of these markets or their major industries suffer a decline, or if government intervention in these economies restricts or limits economic growth, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. 31 ----- Demand for our services is also affected by factors relating to education policies and trends in our markets, principally: - the current lack of public education services in languages other than Arabic and for non-national children in the UAE and Qatar, and attendant government policies that encourage the growth of private-sector education; - the trend for nationals in each of the UAE and Qatar to switch from public-sector education to private-sector education; - policies governing tuition fees and other education-related costs; and - demand from parents for high-quality private education for their children. A change in government education policy or education trends among our target client base could reduce the demand for private-sector education, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Regulators may limit our ability to increase our fees.
Subsubsection Text: Tuition fee levels for private schools in the UAE are regulated by the UAE Education Regulators (as defined below). For example, in Dubai, the KHDA regulates, among other things, the annual tuition fee increase applicable to private schools. New private schools are not permitted to increase their tuition fees in the three years following the date of commencement of their educational activity, and existing schools cannot increase fees without first receiving approval from the KHDA. Therefore, pursuant to the “School Fees Framework” which applies to all private schools that have been operating in Dubai for more than three years (including, as at 31 May 2019, 28 of our schools), private schools can only increase tuition fees at a rate based on: (a) the Dubai Education Cost Index (the “ECI”); and (b) a multiplier linked to changes in individual school inspection ratings awarded by the KHDA, with schools securing an upgrade in their ratings being allowed to increase their fees by a pre-determined multiple of the ECI. School inspections focus on factors such as academic performance and class size, and underperformance in any of the factors that are considered during the inspection can lead to a ratings downgrade, which in turn reduces the permitted level of fee increases for the following academic year. The KHDA and other governmental entities can also decide, as they have done on two occasions in the past, that tuition fees cannot be increased for reasons not related to inspection results, such as inflation or general economic conditions. For example, for the 2018-2019 academic year, the Dubai Executive Council decreed that private schools in Dubai were not permitted to increase school fees at all for that year. Furthermore, in the 2013 academic year, the KHDA decided to set the ECI at negative 1% due to low inflation, thereby effectively disallowing tuition fee increases in that year. In both instances, certain exceptional fee increases for individual schools were still permitted. There can therefore be no assurance that the KHDA or any other government organizations will not set the ECI below inflation again in the future, grant any exceptions if it were to do so, or permit future school fee increases. Moreover, the new regulatory framework introduced in Dubai for the 2019-2020 academic year includes new punitive provisions linked to downgrades to Dubai School Inspections Bureau (“DSIB”) inspection outcomes for specific schools, and generally allows lower fee inflation than the prior framework. From the 2019-2020 academic year onwards, Dubai schools that have their ratings downgraded by the DSIB will not be permitted any increase in fees for the following academic year. In addition, while the fees we charge for services provided through our School Support Services division are not currently subject to regulatory limits, there can be no assurance that this will remain the case. The KHDA or another government organization could, in the future, subject ancillary services, such as those we provide through our School Support Services division, to separate fee caps, or take the cost of these services into account when deciding on permitted fee increase levels for schools, which, in either case, could reduce our revenues. In the Northern Emirates, a school rating system based on the Unified Schools Inspection Framework (as defined in “Regulation Overview—United Arab Emirates”) was created in 2018, with the first round of school ratings confidentially sent to schools, but not publicly released, in May 2018. As the 32 ----- Northern Emirates have not used this type of school rating system in the past, the relevant regulators may be less experienced in determining school ratings, and there can be no certainty that our schools will receive ratings which we believe accurately reflect their quality or which are comparable to the ratings of our schools in Dubai or Abu Dhabi. There can be no assurance that other regulatory authorities in the UAE or other jurisdictions in which we operate will not impose restrictions on the level of tuition fees charged by our schools in the future. Changes in such regulations, which can often occur at short notice, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. In addition, market revenue growth forecasts are driven in part by expected increases in tuition fee levels. If these increases do not materialize, or grow at a slower rate than expected, the associated market revenue growth forecasts described elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum may not be achieved. If regulators do not grant us permission to raise our tuition fees, or if tuition fee regulatory frameworks are altered in a manner which negatively impacts our tuition fee structure, or if our schools’ ratings are downgraded by the relevant regulator, our operating margins could be adversely affected, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Furthermore, we believe that recently the pace at which school operators have been able to secure school ratings upgrades has slowed and the expected management intensity required to secure upgrades has increased. As such, we may not be able to raise the ratings, and therefore the fee levels, of our schools as quickly as we have done in the past. This could impact our revenues, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our financial performance depends in part on our ability to maintain or increase our tuition fees.
Subsubsection Text: Since the introduction of the current tuition fee regime in Dubai in the 2012 academic year, we have increased tuition fees at our schools each year, with exceptions in the 2013 and the 2019 academic years, when the ECI was set at negative 1% and at 0%, respectively, and at one school in Dubai in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, when we chose to maintain fees for school-specific reasons. However, certain factors could have an adverse impact on our ability to maintain or increase our tuition fees within the permitted regulatory framework. These factors include: - negative perceptions of the quality of education offered at our schools; - resistance to tuition fee increases by tuition payers (parents and employers) due to difficult economic conditions or previous fee increases in recent academic years; - reductions or discounts of tuition fees by other schools that seek to compete with us; - with respect to our Dubai schools, a nil or a negative ECI; - a determination by the KHDA or another government body to restrict fee increases; - the extent of any fee increase implemented in the immediately preceding two years for our schools in Abu Dhabi; and - lower fees at new competitor schools. The inability to raise tuition fees as a result of these or other factors could adversely affect our operating margins, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to various licensing and accreditation requirements in the jurisdictions in which we operate, and our failure to comply with these requirements could expose us to financial losses and lead to loss of students.
Subsubsection Text: Our activities are subject to various licensing requirements in each of the markets in which we operate. Our licenses and educational permits could be terminated, suspended, revoked or not renewed for various reasons, including failure to comply with applicable laws and regulations. Any termination, suspension, revocation or non-renewal of any of our licenses and educational services permits could result in the temporary or permanent cessation of the business being conducted pursuant to that license and/or permit, curtail our ability to enroll new students or provide certain 33 ----- services in the affiliated schools, adversely affect our reputation or cause us to incur unanticipated costs to fulfill our obligations. Penalties for failing to obtain or comply with the required licenses and/or permits may include fines, civil or criminal actions and temporary or permanent school closures. We are not currently in compliance with the licensing requirements of ADEK and the Abu Dhabi government in respect of the ownerships and/or tenancy arrangements of three of our schools in Abu Dhabi, which accounted for less than 5% of revenue and Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, as these schools were all established before the current requirements were imposed. Notwithstanding this non-compliance, ADEK has verbally confirmed that it will continue to renew the education licenses and no objection certificates required to operate these three schools, thus effectively granting an indefinite grace period for compliance with these requirements. However, there can be no assurance that this grace period will not be withdrawn. If the grace period were to end, this could result in ADEK not issuing or renewing necessary education licenses and/or certificates, unless the ownership and/or tenancy arrangements relating to these schools could be restructured to ensure compliance with the requirements. In respect of two of these schools, any restructuring is expected to be limited to amending the existing tenancy arrangements. For the third school, compliance would require the transfer of shares to a Local Sponsor and the entry into Local Sponsor Documentation, and there can be no guarantee that this would be achievable prior to the expiry of any grace period. As a separate matter, we must also generally maintain various accreditations from curriculum providers and permits from examination bodies. The loss of these accreditations and/or permits may negatively affect our ability to provide our curricula, which could have a material adverse effect on our reputation and the attractiveness of our school portfolio and, consequently, our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. In addition, the jurisdictions in which we operate, in particular the Northern Emirates, may impose additional laws, regulations or licensing regimes which constrain our ability to operate our business or require us to hold additional licenses, permits or accreditations, which could result in our having to incur additional expenses or otherwise adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Furthermore, our transport activities are regulated by the Roads and Transport Authority of Dubai (the “RTA”) as to safety and standards of service provision in Dubai, and we are required to obtain a license from the RTA for our activities and our drivers. Any inability to obtain or maintain the required licenses could negatively impact our ability to provide our transport services, which could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We face competition, particularly in respect of our Premium schools, and if we do not compete effectively, our results of operations may be adversely impacted.
Subsubsection Text: The private K-12 English-language education sectors in our primary markets are competitive. Our schools compete with other private K-12 English-language schools and other education providers, including providers that offer the same curricula at similar or lower price points. We may also experience increased competition if new private K-12 English-language schools enter our markets, or if the public education provisions in our markets expand in size or increase in quality. Our existing and potential competitors may be able to devote greater resources to the development and construction of schools and respond more quickly to changes in parents’ demands, admissions standards, market needs or new technologies. In particular, we are facing increased competition from both local and international operators of schools that compete with our Premium schools, which are typically our most profitable schools. Our competitors may also increase their capacity in any of our markets to an extent that leads to an over-supply of capacity. We may also experience increased competition if the industry undergoes consolidation. Furthermore, if we are unable to meet demand for enrollments at our schools, or if we are unable to shift demand from schools which do not have available capacity to schools with excess capacity, students may choose to enroll in competitors’ schools instead. If we are unable to differentiate our schools from those of our competitors and successfully market our schools to parents and students, we may be unable to attract and/or retain students, which could reduce our enrollment levels and profitability, or we could be required to increase our operational or capital expenditure, including on marketing or educational inputs, to increase or retain enrollment 34 ----- levels. If our enrollments fall, we may be required to reduce our tuition fees or increase spending to attract and retain students. Pricing strategies by competitors, such as lowering fees, could also result in downward pricing pressures on us. Any decrease in fee levels or increase in spending due to competitive pressure could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Our School Support Services business provides certain services to third parties, and we face competition in the provision of these services, particularly with respect to our transport business, which faces competition from both private competitors and the RTA, which, in addition to acting in a regulatory capacity, also provides a school transport service for education providers in Dubai. If we are unable to effectively compete to provide our School Support Services to third parties, we could lose revenue, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Significant proportions of our school revenue and Adjusted EBITDA are generated by our Premium schools.
Subsubsection Text: We define Premium schools as schools that generally provide our highest-quality facilities and smallest class sizes, and which typically charge at least $15,000 per year in tuition fees. As at 31 May 2019, we had 16 Premium schools. While only 22% of our students were enrolled in Premium schools in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, these schools generated 49% of the School Operations division’s revenue for the year. Revenue from Premium schools is directly related to enrollment, which can be negatively impacted by a variety of factors, including expatriate relocations, students switching to a competitor’s school and students switching to one of our schools at a lower price point. Our Premium schools are also among our schools that generate the highest Adjusted EBITDA Margins, as they are more likely to be Mature schools with higher enrollment levels and better capacity utilization. In addition, in our experience, Premium schools have historically been subject to lower levels of re-enrollment than Mid-Market Plus and Mid-Market schools, because parents of students at Premium schools are typically more mobile and reside in Dubai for shorter time periods. As such, any decline in Premium school enrollments could have a proportionally higher impact on our revenue and margins than a similar decline in Mid-Market Plus or Mid-Market enrollments. If revenue from our Premium schools were to decline for any reason, it could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, results of operations or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to attract, employ and retain qualified and experienced teachers and senior administrative staff, which could impact the quality of instruction at our schools, thereby compromising academic performance, school ratings, our reputation and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to recruit, employ and retain qualified, experienced and appropriately licensed teachers and senior administrative staff (including principals, school administrators and other senior school management personnel) is critical to maintaining the quality of instruction provided at our schools. We hire approximately 1,500 new teaching staff annually to fill new positions and replace teachers who have left. We face competition to attract and retain teachers who possess the necessary experience and accreditation to teach at our schools, particularly in key functions and subjects. In particular, we face intense competition to attract and retain suitably qualified teachers in certain subject areas, such as physics, and for teachers specializing in Arabic language and Islamic studies. Moreover, the introduction of teacher licensing may result in more competition for a smaller pool of licensed teachers across all subjects, and Arabic and Islamic studies teachers in particular, and could result in our teachers who have completed teacher licensing being recruited by competing schools that pay higher salaries. In addition, we may face challenges in attracting teachers for schools located outside of metropolitan Dubai and Abu Dhabi, as schools in smaller cities are generally viewed as less desirable to work in. To effectively compete for and retain staff, we must provide competitive compensation packages. However, we pay salaries and bonus packages which we believe are competitive but not typically market-leading. This has in the past and could in the future affect our ability to attract and retain qualified personnel and/or require us to increase our salary and benefit packages. The average turnover rate of our teaching staff was 20.3%, 19.8% and 15.6% in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively. Turnover requires us to devote resources to 35 ----- attracting and recruiting new staff. Although we have been able to effectively manage our business with turnover rates in this range, an increase in the turnover rate could adversely affect our ability to attract and recruit sufficient staff in key areas and lead to ineffective delivery of the curricula, which could affect students’ academic performance and the brand and reputation of our schools. Furthermore, our turnover rate may make it more difficult to maintain consistency in the quality of instruction. We have also experienced, and may in the future experience, changes in our school senior leadership teams and senior administrative and senior teaching leadership staff for a variety of reasons, including school restructuring, medical problems, retirement and resignations. Although we use non-competition clauses in our standard employment contracts for staff, these employees may also leave us and subsequently join our competitors. Any turnover in senior staff at a school could adversely affect the management of that school. Any inability by us to recruit, or any shortage of, teaching and senior staff, or a decrease in the quality of teachers’ classroom performance, whether actual or perceived, could reduce the overall quality of education at our schools, which could lead to parents choosing to remove their children from our schools, or a decrease in a school’s rating, which would in turn reduce the amount that that school could increase tuition fees. A significant increase in the compensation we must pay to retain qualified teachers could also increase our expenses. Any of the above circumstances could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are closely associated with the Varkey Family, and adverse developments relating to the Varkey Family could have a negative effect on us.
Subsubsection Text: Sunny Varkey, Sherly Varkey, Dino Varkey and Jay Varkey (together, the “Varkey Family”) are large shareholders of our Group, and in combination own a majority of our ordinary shares. Concurrently with the Transactions, Sunny Varkey and Sherly Varkey, through GEMS Global (Cayman) Ltd., will own 36.1% of our ordinary shares, and Dino Varkey and Jay Varkey, through DJ Invest Co, will own 30.3% of our ordinary shares (in each case through wholly-owned intermediate holding companies). As such, we are publicly associated with the Varkey Family. The Varkey Family’s education business activities outside of the MENA region may increase the public perception of a link between us and the Varkey Family, particularly as the Varkey Family is currently using, and will continue to use, the “GEMS” brand name for certain schools operated by the Varkey Group outside of the MENA region. Any failure by these schools to maintain the academic, operational and other standards of our brand, a requirement which is imposed on the Varkey Group by the Trade Mark License Agreement in all jurisdictions in which it operates “GEMS” branded schools, other than India, or any other event that negatively affects the Varkey Family and/or the Varkey Group, could also have an adverse impact on our brand and reputation. In addition, we could be named in lawsuits relating to the Varkey Family. Furthermore, certain outstanding debt agreements to which we are a party contain change of control provisions which allow lenders to accelerate the debt should certain members of the Varkey Family cease to be, in concert or individually, the beneficial owner of 50% or more of the Company. Any of these developments could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Finally, adverse changes to the financial condition of any of our shareholders, including the Varkey Family, could have an adverse impact on our reputation and access to capital, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may face challenges in growing our operations and developing future schools, both in the UAE and abroad.
Subsubsection Text: We have opened 24 net new schools since 2010, including one acquisition, with additional schools to follow in subsequent years. However, we will face both short-term and long-term risks in connection with any expansion. In the short term, we face execution risks with respect to the schools we have already chosen sites for and are currently developing. These risks include: - failing to open new schools on a timely basis due to delays in obtaining government approvals or licenses, shortages of supplies and skilled labor, construction accidents or natural disasters; 36 ----- - failing to adequately staff new schools or successfully integrate and retain acquired schools’ teachers, senior staff and other employees; - failing to integrate new schools into our portfolio without disrupting our current operations or diverting management’s attention; - incorrectly estimating demand from parents to enroll their children at a new school; and - the strain on our financial and other resources, management, information and reporting systems and financial controls. We may also seek to acquire new schools in the UAE, Qatar or other markets. There can be no assurance, however, that we will be able to find schools available for sale that satisfy our requirements or, if we do, that we would be able to finance the acquisition costs on acceptable terms or at all. In addition, we may incorrectly evaluate the potential of acquired schools. In addition, we have a significant market share in the UAE. Consequently, we may not be able to grow as quickly in the UAE in the future as we have in the past, either because market opportunities may be more limited and/or regulations are introduced which restrict our ability to expand further in the UAE. Moreover, we have limited experience expanding internationally. We are currently in the process of acquiring Bellevue, which owns schools in the United Kingdom and Switzerland. There can be no assurance that we will be able to successfully manage schools in these countries. In addition, our shareholder GEMS MENASA Holdings Limited (“GMHL”), in conjunction with joint venture partners, acquired four schools in Egypt and 13 schools in the KSA. While GMHL is outside the Restricted Group, our management team will be responsible for supporting the management of these schools, and they may require significant attention that our management team would otherwise be devoting to schools within the Restricted Group. In addition, these schools will use the GEMS brand, and as such any negative reputational events may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. A failure to effectively support the growth strategy of GMHL, and the risks that we may encounter while expanding our operations, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions may expose us to integration challenges and unknown liabilities.
Subsubsection Text: We are currently in the process of acquiring Bellevue, which comprises 15 schools, 14 of which are in the United Kingdom and one of which is in Switzerland. We also acquired the Wesgreen International School, in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017. We may also undertake additional school acquisitions in the future. We have also acquired companies which provide school support services and may undertake additional support services acquisitions in the future. In addition, our shareholder GMHL, in conjunction with joint venture partners, acquired four schools in Egypt and 13 schools in the KSA for which we are responsible for supporting the management. Acquisitions can expose us to integration challenges such as negative parental reactions, additional regulatory scrutiny, system integration challenges, financial or operational performance issues, and cultural challenges, particularly for acquisitions in jurisdictions with which we are less familiar. When we acquire a school, parents of students enrolled at the school may react negatively to the change in ownership, potentially choosing to send their children elsewhere. Consequently, a decrease in enrollment could follow any such acquisition, reducing revenue. A proposed acquisition could also expose us to additional regulatory scrutiny. If a regulator delays, or imposes conditions on, any acquisition, it may prevent the acquisition from occurring or negatively affect the operations and/or profitability of the newly acquired school or business. Furthermore, system integration challenges have arisen in the past and may arise in the future, as the newly acquired school or business is brought into our school portfolio. These challenges can include various obstacles from financial, management information services and human resources perspectives. Our management team may also be required to devote substantial amounts of time to acquire and integrate new schools, which could reduce their ability to focus on other issues. This may be true even for schools outside the Restricted Group that our management team is responsible for supporting, such as the schools acquired by GMHL in Egypt and the KSA. The failure to overcome these challenges could lead to operational problems. In addition, acquired schools could fail to perform as expected, from either a financial or operational perspective. Further challenges may also arise with respect to acquisitions in 37 ----- jurisdictions with which we are less familiar, such as the United Kingdom and Switzerland, due to factors such as lack of cultural familiarity or relationship with the regulators. In addition, we may become subject to regulatory, licensing, litigation, tax and other liabilities based on circumstances we fail to discover in the due diligence review we conduct in connection with an acquisition. When we discover potential liabilities during our due diligence review, neither the valuation adjustment nor the contractual protections we negotiate may be sufficient to fully protect us from losses. Although we generally seek to negotiate rights to indemnification, our rights may be limited by survival periods for bringing claims and limitations on the nature and amount of losses we may recover. We cannot be certain that any indemnification will be collectible or sufficient in amount, scope or duration to fully offset any loss we may suffer. The occurrence of any of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to access sufficient capital to fund growth initiatives or to operate our business.
Subsubsection Text: We operate in a capital-intensive industry, and significant investment is required to maintain our existing schools and to build and acquire new schools. In addition to cash flows from operations, we may seek to access the capital markets, property funds and/or development finance to raise the funds required to finance working capital requirements, expand our operations, invest in new business initiatives or make strategic acquisitions. We may have to limit our growth initiatives, alter our strategic plans or take other actions if adequate funds are not available on acceptable terms or at all, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to open schools in time for the start of the school year, or may incur additional costs, if the construction of our schools is delayed or subject to other issues.
Subsubsection Text: Historically, we have expanded our operations primarily through the construction of our own schools, rather than by acquiring existing schools operated by third parties, and we intend to continue pursuing this strategy. Therefore, our success depends in large part on the timely and efficient construction of our schools, whether by CMC, a contractor we have historically relied upon and which is controlled by the Founder, or a third party. There are various construction, operating and governance risks associated with the development of new schools in a timely manner or at all. These risks include: - delays or refusals to grant the necessary building, occupancy and other required governmental permits, licenses, approvals and authorizations; - operational, financial (including bankruptcy), regulatory or legal issues impacting a contractor; - shortages of, or defective, materials and/or equipment, labor shortages and/or disputes and disputes with subcontractors; - unforeseeable physical conditions (natural physical conditions or other physical obstructions, including sub-surface and hydrological conditions); - natural disasters and accidents, including force majeure; - changes to the requirements of governmental authorities; - delays in signing lease agreements and finalizing contracts; and - delays caused by governmental authorities or master developers. If a new school is completed beyond a specified contractually agreed deadline, regulators may not grant the licenses necessary to allow the school to open for the scheduled academic year. A delay in the opening of a new school could also lead to other adverse consequences, including delays in student enrollment, missed teaching time, increased teacher and regulatory costs, reputational damage and breached obligations to landlords and master developers in the communities in which the school is to open. For instance, one of our schools which was developed by a third-party construction company was opened in a partially complete state in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 and, as a result, the school faced operational challenges in its first year. 38 ----- Furthermore, given that places at new schools in certain of our markets are reserved by prospective students prior to their opening, and that in most cases a portion of annual tuition fees are paid in advance, any failure to complete construction on time and prior to the start of the academic year could result in us refunding these pre-paid tuition fees. In addition, the cost of construction materials and/or labor may increase, and construction projects may require additional development efforts to ensure their timely completion that may result in significant additional costs. To the extent that these additional costs cannot be recouped through contractually agreed mechanisms, they may result in the expected return on the investment in the school not being realized. The occurrence of any of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business is affected by customer recognition of our brands and reputation, as well as that of particular schools and groups of schools.
Subsubsection Text: Our business and future growth are highly dependent on our target market’s awareness and recognition of the “GEMS Education” brand, as well as the separate brands and reputations of particular schools and groups of schools. We believe that maintaining and enhancing these brands allows us to differentiate ourselves from our competitors and drives word-of-mouth referrals, and is therefore critical to our competitive advantage and the growth of our business. Our reputation and that of our individual schools could be adversely affected by a number of factors, including: - adverse ratings from the KHDA, ADEK, the MoE or another regulatory body that publicly rates the quality of our schools; - the loss of a license, permit, accreditation or other authorization required to operate any of our schools or School Support Services division businesses; - an inability to maintain consistent levels of service as we expand our business into new jurisdictions or provides new services through our School Support Services division; - our school facilities not meeting the standards expected by parents or students; - a closure of one or more of our schools; - a failure to safeguard students or otherwise protect the health and safety of staff and students; - negative publicity relating to litigation or other disputes that we are involved in; - our inability to produce the educational outcomes required under any contractual arrangements in connection with the schools we manage for third parties; and - other business dealings of the Varkey Group, GEMS Global or any of our other shareholders, including the operation of schools in India and three schools in the UK under the “GEMS” brand, over which we have no control, that result in negative publicity for us. The occurrence of one or more of these events could have a material adverse effect on our brand and reputation and could influence the way our business is viewed not only by parents and students, but also by other constituencies in the education sector, including the UAE Education Regulators. Moreover, an event that damages the reputation of one of our schools could adversely affect the reputation and operations of our other schools. If our brand or reputation declines, or if the brand or reputation of certain schools or groups of schools declines, it could lead to a decrease in enrollments at our schools, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We must commit to hiring a proportion of our new staff for a school year before we have visibility on corresponding enrollment levels.
Subsubsection Text: Many direct and indirect costs within our business are incurred based on anticipated enrollment levels at our schools, which may not be achieved. There can be a lag between when we incur these costs, and when we can take corrective action to reduce the costs in the event of a change in business circumstances. For example, we typically begin to contract with new staff in our British, American and 39 ----- IB curricula-based schools in November, nearly 11 months ahead of the start of the academic year the following August/September, and aim to have made commitments for up to two-thirds of new planned staff by late February, six months ahead of the following academic year. We will recruit the number and type of teachers that we expect will be required based on anticipated enrollment levels. If the level of student enrollment is subsequently lower than anticipated, we could incur proportionally higher levels of staff costs and have more teachers than necessary for the number of enrolled students, or be compelled to rescind offers already made to new teaching recruits. For instance, in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, we hired more teachers than necessary due to an overestimation of enrollment levels for the upcoming academic year and, as a result, our PTR was lower than we had planned. Furthermore, there may also be operational circumstances in which, to maintain particular standards, it may be impractical or impossible to reduce or reallocate teaching staff in proportion to a decline in student enrollment numbers. Any failure to accurately predict enrollment levels or adjust costs such as staff expense in a timely manner could negatively impact our operating margins, which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to expand the facilities of our existing schools, for operational, financial, regulatory or other reasons.
Subsubsection Text: Expanding the facilities of our existing schools can lead to a number of challenges, including: - the relevant leasehold land and buildings may not have the capacity to accommodate the necessary or desired changes for further expansion; - the existing facilities may not be configured to provide for the required renovations; - the expansion costs may be uneconomic and the anticipated benefits of the new facilities may not be realized; - we may not be able to successfully negotiate amendments to the terms of the relevant lease from the landlord to allow the works to be undertaken or, if permitted, to negotiate acceptable terms with the landlord or developer and make the required changes within acceptable timeframes; and - we may experience difficulties in obtaining governmental approvals, permits or licenses for further expansion. Our inability to expand school facilities could negatively affect our growth strategy and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our transport business depends on maintaining a reputation for safety, and we could be liable for accidents or other child safeguarding events that our school buses and other vehicles are involved in.
Subsubsection Text: We provide school bus and car transportation services through our School Support Services division. As at 31 May 2019, we operated more than 2,500 school buses carrying more than 80,000 students to our schools each day, and additional buses provided transportation services to a number of thirdparty schools. We also provide corporate bus and car hire services to third parties. The safe operation of motor vehicles requires the maintenance of vehicles and the training of drivers, and any failure to do so raises the risk of unsafe operation. Furthermore, any operation of motor vehicles involves an inherent risk of traffic accidents, injuries or other incidents. We may be held responsible for any accidents, injuries or other incidents relating to the transportation services we provide for students at our own schools, as well as to other schools. In addition, under the terms of the standard KHDA school-parent contract for schools in Dubai, we may be liable for actions on buses transporting children to our schools, even if we do not operate those buses. If our school buses or cars were to be involved in an accident or other incident, parents could refuse to let their students use our transportation services, transportation contracts with third parties could be lost, we could be subject to the loss of a school license, civil or criminal liability, and we could suffer reputational damage. The occurrence or alleged occurrence of any of these events could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to continually enhance our educational services and adapt them to rapid pedagogical innovations and evolving test methods, student needs and preferences.
Subsubsection Text: The quality of our educational services as well as parent and student satisfaction rates are vital to the success of our business. The educational services market is characterized by rapid pedagogical 40 ----- innovations and evolving teaching and test methods, advances in educational technology (“EdTech”) and changing student needs and preferences, with respect to which we must react quickly to identify areas for change, improvement and enhancement of our programs and services. We must also effectively train our teachers to react to and take advantage of such changes. The regulatory authorities in the markets in which we operate determine, and may modify, the content of the K-12 English-language curriculum that we are required to teach at our schools. Therefore, applicable school curricula will likely undergo changes and we will need to adapt to such changes. These changes may require us to update and enhance our curricula, educational materials and/or teaching methods, and could require additional expenditure by us to comply with the changes. An inability to track and respond to changes in the educational field in a timely and cost-effective manner could make our educational services and programs less attractive to students, which may affect our students’ academic performance, our brand and reputation, and our ability to continue to attract and retain students, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may seek to renegotiate and/or terminate the leases underlying our land bank, which could be costly.
Subsubsection Text: We have entered into 16 long-term leases for vacant land plots in the UAE with a view to constructing new schools on these plots. See “Business—Our Business—The School Operations division— _Approach to operation of our schools–Land bank”. Construction has either not commenced or is at a_ very early stage on these sites. Due to current market conditions in the UAE, we have decided either to postpone or cancel plans to construct new schools on these sites, or to relocate existing schools (the leases of which will shortly expire) to certain of these sites. Accordingly, we are currently in the process of either: - seeking to re-negotiate more favorable lease terms with the relevant landlords, including extensions of rent free periods and/or removal of construction obligations; - determining the viability of relocating existing schools (the leases of which will shortly expire) to certain of these sites; or - terminating the leases. By pursuing any of the above options, we may incur significant costs, including loss of deposits, payment of ongoing rent, liquidated damages awards for early termination of the lease and/or the costs of closure and relocation of existing schools. We may also incur liabilities for breach of the terms of the lease if a landlord elects to pursue us for breach of our obligations under the relevant leases. While we have written-off certain of these costs, there can be no assurance that our write-offs will be adequate to cover actual losses. Any of these outcomes could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our schools are mainly constructed on leasehold land and the leases are held by a limited number of landlords, who consequently have increased bargaining power when negotiating lease terms with us.
Subsubsection Text: Many of our landlords own multiple school sites. In addition, the Government of Dubai is consolidating existing undeveloped sites which have been zoned for education into the ownership of the “Knowledge Fund,” a government education land agency, and we may increasingly need to negotiate with this entity as our counterparty to new leases. A good working relationship with the landlords of our schools’ properties is therefore important to the successful operation of our schools. Our relationships with our current and prospective landlords depend on several factors, including conditions in the real estate market, competition for desirable properties and other factors that may not be within our control. If we are unable to maintain good working relationships with our landlords, it could prevent the successful implementation of our growth strategy and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. At the time of lease renewal, we are exposed to the risk that landlords could seek to impose unfavorable terms on us due to their significant negotiating leverage. If we are unable to negotiate 41 ----- acceptable lease terms with these entities, it could affect our ability to operate our business. For example, we recently relocated a school to a new site when the school’s lease term ended and we could not agree acceptable terms for a new lease at the original site. In addition, since the death of the Local Sponsor and landlord of one of our schools in Fujairah, Our Own English High School (“OOF”), we have been in a dispute regarding the ownership of the professional license to operate the school and the terms of a renewal of a long-term lease with the former Local Sponsor’s heir. This school accounted for less than 1% of our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. There can be no assurance that we will be able to satisfactorily resolve our dispute regarding OOF and agree acceptable lease terms for a new long-term lease with the landlord, which may result in us needing to relocate the school to an alternative site or withdrawing from the school altogether if an economically viable alternative cannot be found. If we must seek alternative lessors, we may be unable to obtain satisfactory replacement premises or services on economically attractive terms, on a timely basis, or at all, which could require us to close a school, increase costs and/or disrupt our operations, any of which could harm our reputation, subject us to claims from parents and adversely affect our results of operations. Moreover, in certain markets in which we operate such as the UAE, landlords can demand that any improvements constructed by the tenant, such as buildings, be removed from a site upon the termination of a lease. Alternatively, the landlord may be able to pay the tenant compensation for the improvement, although this payment will not necessarily cover the improvement’s full market value. Consequently, it is possible that we will not receive full or any compensation for our improvements to leasehold sites with respect to which leases expire and are not renewed, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our landlords may terminate our leases and we may be unable to renew our leases on acceptable terms.
Subsubsection Text: The weighted average remaining lease term of our lease arrangements as at 31 May 2019 was 14.1 years. Eight of our leases are due to be renewed in the next five fiscal years. In addition, at OOF we are negotiating renewal terms for a lease which has expired, although we continue to operate the school despite an ongoing rental dispute with the landlord. While some of our current leases contain priority renewal provisions which provide that we have the right of first refusal to renew the lease upon the expiration of the lease, subject to a pre-agreed lease rate determination mechanism, this may not always be the case. Under the terms of many of our leases, the lessor’s termination rights are limited. However, there can be no assurance that a lessor will not endeavor to unilaterally terminate a lease prematurely or that the courts will protect our rights in these disputes. If our leases are terminated by a landlord for any reason or are not otherwise renewed on acceptable terms, we may be exposed to certain risks, including: - damages payable to the landlord, if the landlord terminated the lease for cause; - an inability to renew the professional license to operate the relevant school or to find a new property with the amenities and in the location required, which could lead to closure of the affected school(s) or a decline in the breadth of the offering; - the incurrence of costs associated with our obligation to return the land to its original state prior to the construction of our school on the premises; - the incurrence of costs to identify, secure and relocate to a new location, and to develop the new facility to the required standards; - reputational damage; and - the relocation to a school in a less desirable location. In addition, because we have our origins as a family business, the lease of the land for certain of our existing schools has historically been entered into between the relevant landlord and the Founder (“Legacy Leases”). Although most of the Legacy Leases have subsequently been assigned or subleased to the relevant corporate entities within the Group, there are Legacy Leases pursuant to which our schools are operating which have not yet been assigned or subleased to entities within our 42 ----- Group. Accordingly, in respect of these Legacy Leases, the continued use of the relevant land by us is subject to the relevant landlord not terminating the lease and continuing to allow us (rather than the Founder) to use such land.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The success of our longer-term growth strategy depends on our ability to locate and secure land suitable for development at attractive prices.
Subsubsection Text: Our growth and profitability to date have been attributable, in part, to our ability to locate and lease land at attractive prices, and the success of our business strategy and future profitability in the longer term depends upon our continued ability to do so. Among other challenges, available sites may be too small, prohibitively expensive or subject to zoning restrictions that do not permit school facilities. Furthermore, we face the risk that competitors and other third parties may anticipate and capitalize on potential land acquisition opportunities in advance of us doing so. Our inability to locate appropriate land on which to build new schools, relocate existing schools or to secure leases on attractive terms, could, in the longer term, have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be required to pay fines and/or additional fees in relation to the registration of certain of our lease arrangements and freehold interests in Dubai.
Subsubsection Text: Under Dubai law, freehold and long-term leaseholds in designated areas in Dubai are required to be registered with the Dubai Land Department (the “DLD”). We currently operate eight schools on land in respect of which we have registered our real property rights with the DLD (including one on freehold land we own and seven with long-term registered leases). Of these eight, one was subject to a sale and leaseback transaction, and we are currently in the process of registering the transfers to and from the sale and leaseback investor. We also operate two additional schools on land subject to existing long-term leases which can be registered with the DLD, although we have not yet done so, one of which is under re-negotiation with the landlord. In relation to our schools under development in Dubai that are on properties required to be registered with the DLD, we own one freehold plot and lease three additional plots. All of these property interests have been registered with the DLD. Of the three leases, one has recently been terminated, and the remaining two are under re-negotiation with the landlords. We are currently in discussions with the DLD in relation to the registration of the as yet unregistered lease described above. The registration of such lease will trigger liability for payment of a registration fee, the exact quantum of which cannot be determined with absolute certainty and is subject to the assessment of the DLD. The deadline for the registration of the registrable interests set out above has passed and there is a possibility that, in addition to the applicable registration fees, the DLD may seek to impose late penalty fines at the time of registration of the interest by us. The DLD may also seek to retrospectively impose transfer fees in respect of historic direct or indirect share transfers of our entities which are parties to this lease, or seek to impose additional fees that are not published.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Certain of our long-term lease arrangements may be subject to challenge under UAE law and we may face certain operational risks in relation to the registration of our short-term lease agreements.
Subsubsection Text: The majority of our properties are subject to long-term leases outside designated or investment areas. As a matter of UAE law, long-term leases outside such areas may only be entered into with GCC nationals or 100% GCC owned entities. Given that we are not a 100% UAE owned entity, our longterm lease agreements outside these areas cannot be registered with the relevant land departments in the UAE. If any of these long-term lease agreements are challenged, there is a risk that a UAE court could determine that one or more of them are void. In order to mitigate this risk, and due to the fact that a registered lease is required to obtain the relevant commercial and educational licenses for each of our schools, we seek to enter into parallel short-term leases, which can be entered into with foreign companies and registered with the relevant authorities. Although we have taken steps to limit the need to obtain the consent of the underlying landlords to renew these parallel short-term leases, we are dependent on the underlying landlords in respect of long-term leases at five schools, and two land bank sites to renew the relevant parallel 43 ----- short-term leases for us to renew our commercial and educational licenses. At the time of renewal of such parallel short-term leases, we are exposed to the risk that landlords could seek to renegotiate terms agreed in the underlying long-term leases and impose unfavorable terms on us due to their significant negotiating leverage. This could affect our ability to operate the schools subject to these leases on economically attractive terms, on a timely basis, or at all, which could increase costs or cause disruptions to our operations. Any of these consequences could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The loss of one or more of our key personnel could harm our business.
Subsubsection Text: We currently depend on the continued services and performance of our key personnel, including Mr. Sunny Varkey and other members of our executive management team. As our founder, Mr. Sunny Varkey has been with us since our inception, and has significant experience with the Group and within the education industry. Mr. Sunny Varkey is expected to continue to have significant influence as an indirect shareholder of the Group and as Executive Vice Chairman of the Group. We do not maintain key person life insurance on Mr. Sunny Varkey or other members of our executive management team. The loss or diminution of the services of Mr. Sunny Varkey, in particular his knowledge of the sector and long-standing relationships with landlords, regulatory authorities and Local Sponsors, or the loss of service of any of the members of the executive management team, or a failure to attract and retain other qualified and experienced personnel on acceptable terms and in a timely manner, or at all, could impair our ability to successfully sustain and grow our business, which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not have adequate protection for our intellectual property, and we may infringe upon the intellectual property of others.
Subsubsection Text: Our trademarks, copyrights, trade secrets and other intellectual property rights distinguish our schools and the services provided through our other businesses from those of our competitors and are critical to our ability to continue to develop and enhance our brand. In particular, we have registered or are registering 97 trademarks, including “GEMS Education”, and have registered 114 domain names. We rely on trademark protection in selected jurisdictions to protect our rights to the mark “GEMS Education” and our distinctive logos and other marks associated with our services. We cannot be certain that these measures will be adequate, that we have secured, or will be able to secure, appropriate protection for all of our proprietary rights in selected jurisdictions or that third parties will not infringe upon or misappropriate our trademarks and brand name. Policing the unauthorized use of our trademarks and brand names can be difficult and expensive, and litigation may be necessary to enforce or protect our brand name or determine the validity and scope of the proprietary rights of others. Moreover, some of our trademark or other intellectual property applications may not be successful. If we do not secure registrations for our trademarks or other intellectual property, it may be more difficult to enforce them against third parties. We have entered into the Trade Mark Licence Agreement with GEMS Global pursuant to which GEMS Global is permitted to use the “GEMS” trademarks, logos and designs (the “Marks”) in connection with the operation of schools in certain jurisdictions outside the MENA region in which the Varkey Group currently operates schools under the “GEMS” brand (but excluding India) (“Licensed Schools”). The use of the Marks is subject to certain conditions which include mandatory compliance with our brand guidelines and directions and undertakings not to harm the goodwill of the Marks and/ or use the Marks outside the authorized activities. In addition, the licensing arrangement allows us to protect the Marks through obligations imposed on GEMS Global in relation to the operation of the Licensed Schools and the right to inspect each Licensed School on a regular or ad hoc basis to ensure compliance with such obligations. Nonetheless, we remain subject to reputational risks if the Marks are misused or if there is any adverse publicity through actions taken by or against the ex-MENA business. If this were to occur, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Furthermore, GEMS Global is the owner of several “GEMS” registered trademarks in India which it uses in the schools which it operates in India. Its use of the “GEMS” brand is not therefore regulated by the terms of the Trade Mark License Agreement and so there are no conditions attached to its use of the brand in India. The “GEMS” brand is also used by three schools in the UK which are independently governed by the GEMS Learning Trust, an independent academy trust over which we 44 ----- have no control. Any adverse event at these schools could therefore have a material adverse effect on our brand and reputation and could influence the way our business is viewed not only by parents and students, but also by other constituencies in the education sector, including the UAE Education Regulators. Moreover, an event that damages the reputation of one of our schools could adversely affect the reputation and operations of our other schools. If our brand or reputation declines, or if the brand or reputation of certain schools or groups of schools declines, it could lead to a decrease in enrollments at our schools, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. In addition, third parties may accuse us of infringing their intellectual property, including their branding. Third party intellectual property rights may be extremely broad, and it may not be possible for us to conduct our operations without infringing those intellectual property rights. For instance, an unaffiliated third-party school could object to us giving one of our schools a name similar to that third-party school’s name. Any infringement or alleged infringement of intellectual property rights could lead to legal claims or negatively impact our reputation and branding, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have historically relied on CMC, a single contractor that is controlled by the Founder, to build substantially all of our schools in the UAE and expect to continue using CMC to build the majority of our UAE schools in the future.
Subsubsection Text: We have historically relied on CMC, a single contractor that is controlled by the Founder, to build substantially all of our schools in the UAE, and we intend to continue to do so. As CMC is controlled by the Founder, transactions with CMC are related party transactions. At the conclusion of the Transactions, we will enter into a framework agreement with CMC to govern construction of new schools, as well as refurbishments, alterations and extensions of existing schools, based on pre-defined specifications, pricing and terms. Under this framework agreement, we will negotiate terms with CMC on an arms-length basis and CMC will be required to match the pricing of third-party suppliers. As a result, while we have historically achieved preferential construction terms with CMC (including in relation to payment arrangements and pricing), there can be no assurance that we will be able to do so in the future.
