In addition, we have historically not received market standard construction guarantee or defect liability periods from CMC, as a result of which we are exposed to potential postconstruction costs which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have recently implemented a number of policies, processes, systems and controls which have a limited operating history.
Subsubsection Text: We began as a family business and, to date, have operated as a private company with policies, processes, systems and controls appropriate for a company of our size and nature. In addition, we have historically operated with a significant number of related party transactions between us on the one hand and the Varkey Group, the Founder and Varkey Group Affiliates on the other hand. Most of these related party transactions have recently been terminated. We have recently implemented a number of policies (including anti-bribery and anti-money laundering policies), processes, systems and controls in line with international best practices. While we believe we comply with such standards, we have a limited operating history with regard to which we can assess the performance of these policies, processes, systems and controls or the analysis of their outputs (including in respect of our ability to identify and police transactions with related parties). Any material inadequacies, weaknesses or failures in our policies, processes, systems and controls could result in non-compliance with the applicable requirements and have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Unauthorized disclosure of personal data that we collect and retain due to a systems failure or otherwise could damage our business.
Subsubsection Text: We maintain records that include personal data, such as academic and medical records, addresses and family information. If the security measures we use to protect personal data are ineffective due to a systems failure or for other reasons, we could be liable for claims of invasion of privacy, impersonation, unauthorized purchases or other claims. In addition, we could be held liable for the misuse of personal data, fraudulent or otherwise, by our employees, independent consultants or third-party contractors. 45 ----- Furthermore, the EU General Data Protection Regulation (the “GDPR”) entered into force on 25 May 2018. While the GDPR does not apply in certain of the jurisdictions in which we operate, we are in the process of acquiring Bellevue, a school operator based in the United Kingdom. Bellevue operates in compliance with the GDPR and following the Acquisition, the GDPR could subject us to additional regulatory compliance burdens and liability. In addition, the UAE is considering implementing data protection laws similar to the GDPR. While these laws are still in the process of being drafted and neither their scope nor effective date is yet known, any such law could apply to us and our business and require us to change our policies and procedures. In addition, while we are currently drafting our data protection policies and procedures, if any such new law comes into effect earlier than we expect, we could be required to accelerate the pace at which we put relevant new policies and procedures into place. We could incur significant expense in preparing for or complying with such new laws, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Furthermore, we could incur significant expenses in connection with remedying any security breaches, settling any resulting claims and providing additional protection to prevent additional breaches. In addition, any failure to protect personal information may adversely impact our ability to attract and retain students, harm our reputation and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The efficient operation of our business is dependent on our information technology, network and communications systems.
Subsubsection Text: We depend on our information technology infrastructure and systems that support our data-driven approach to the management of our business and the provision of education to our students. Any failure or significant disruption to these could have an adverse effect on the proper functioning of our businesses, and particularly on our ability to monitor and analyze data relating to key operating metrics. Notwithstanding efforts to prevent an information technology, network or communications system failure or disruption, our systems may be vulnerable to damage or interruption from fire, telecommunications failures, floods, physical or electronic break-ins, computer viruses or hacking, power outages and other malfunctions or disruptions. There can be no certainty that our disaster recovery and contingency plans will be effective or sufficient if they need to be activated. As we expand our operations we may make further investments in our information technology and related systems. There can be no assurance that we will be able to upgrade or install technology in a timely manner, train our employees effectively in the use of our technology or obtain the anticipated benefits of our technology. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations or prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Any of the education programs employed by our schools could be perceived by parents or the public as not being of sufficiently high quality and students at our schools may experience poor academic performance.
Subsubsection Text: The success of our business depends on our ability to maintain the quality of education, which includes students’ satisfactory learning experience and academic performance. Our schools may not be able to meet parents’ and students’ expectations for academic performance, help our high school graduates achieve their college admissions goals or ensure that graduates obtain jobs upon graduation which they consider satisfactory. A student may not experience expected academic improvement and his or her performance may otherwise decline due to reasons beyond our control. There is no assurance that we can provide school learning experiences that are satisfactory to all of our students. Parent and student satisfaction with our educational programs may decline. We may also experience negative publicity or a decrease in word-of-mouth referrals if our education programs are not perceived to be of a sufficiently high quality. Any such negative developments could result in students’ withdrawal from or unwillingness to apply for our schools, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The Local Sponsor Documentation may be subject to challenge under UAE law.
Subsubsection Text: It is possible that the Local Sponsor Documentation could be unilaterally challenged before a UAE court on the basis of UAE Federal Law no. 17 of 2004 in respect of Commercial Concealment (the “Concealment Law”) or other general public policy related provisions under other UAE legislation, and 46 ----- that a UAE court could decide that the Local Sponsor Documentation is in breach of the Concealment Law or otherwise in violation of public policy, morals or other UAE law. The prevailing legal interpretation in the UAE is that the restrictions under the Concealment Law only apply to activities which are strictly reserved for UAE nationals and/or entities wholly owned by UAE nationals under UAE law and licensing requirements, and do not prohibit sponsor arrangements in respect of entities subject to restrictions on foreign ownership in the UAE (the “UAE Ownership Requirement”) if the activities conducted by such entities are not strictly reserved for UAE nationals and/or entities wholly owned by UAE nationals. Although the provision of education services are not strictly reserved for UAE nationals and/or entities wholly owned by UAE nationals, certain of our subsidiaries conduct activities that are reserved for UAE nationals under UAE law (being nurseries, transportation services and labor supply services), and we exercise control over and derive 100% of the economic benefit from such subsidiaries on the basis of sponsor agreements with Local Sponsors. There is a higher risk that sponsor agreements such as these (as compared to sponsor agreements in respect of our subsidiaries conducting activities which are not reserved for UAE nationals and/or entities wholly owned by UAE nationals) may be found to breach the Concealment Law if successfully challenged. Some of these entities are non-revenue generating or loss-making holding companies. As at the date of this Offering Memorandum, to our knowledge, the provisions of the Concealment Law have not been enforced against any UAE company, nor are we aware of such arrangements having been unilaterally or in any other manner challenged, by the Government of the UAE or any Emirate thereof. However, there can be no certainty as to the approach that the UAE courts would take in the event of any enforcement action being taken in relation to the application of the Concealment Law or other laws or policies to the Local Sponsor Documentation. There could be a number of adverse implications for us if any aspect of the Local Sponsor Documentation were to be successfully challenged in respect of any of our subsidiaries that are subject to such arrangements, including, among others: - the Local Sponsor Documentation being deemed void, which would result in: - the loss of the right to claim the full economic benefit of the affected operating businesses; - the loss of the right to acquire the shares held by the Local Sponsors in the affected subsidiaries or to require the shares held by the Local Sponsors in the affected subsidiaries to be transferred to a third party; - the loss of our right to be appointed as a proxy for the Local Sponsors during shareholder meetings of the affected subsidiaries; and/or - the loss of the right to prevent the Local Sponsors from selling or transferring their shares in the affected subsidiaries; - the suspension of operating licenses and educational services permits of the affected subsidiaries by the UAE Education Regulators (which could require us to close or suspend the operations of the affected subsidiaries and related activities carried out by them); - having to adopt an alternative ownership or operating structure that could be disadvantageous to us and the affected subsidiaries; or - the imposition of material fines. While we are not aware of arrangements such as those under the Local Sponsor Documentation ever having been challenged in the UAE and believe that it is unlikely that a UAE court would give a broad application of the Concealment Law, as this would likely have a severe adverse effect on foreign investment in the UAE and would be counter to recent UAE federal initiatives to more broadly permit foreign ownership, the possibility of a successful claim cannot be completely excluded. The occurrence of one or more such events could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to counterparty risks associated with our ownership structure in the UAE.
Subsubsection Text: The laws of the UAE contain local ownership requirements which provide that a UAE company (unless it has been granted an exemption) must be majority (i.e. 51% or greater) owned by UAE nationals. We 47 ----- and certain of our affiliates are not considered UAE nationals for these purposes and are therefore subject to the UAE Ownership Requirement. With respect to our businesses to which the UAE Ownership Requirement applies, we have implemented a corporate structure pursuant to which up to 49% of the outstanding share capital of each Minority Subsidiary is owned indirectly by us and the remaining 51% or more of the outstanding share capital is owned by a Local Sponsor, and the entire share capital of each Third Party Subsidiary is owned by a Local Sponsor. In order to protect our interests and ensure that we have the full benefit of, and control over, the operating businesses of our subsidiaries that are held under these structures (including their educational services permits and operating licenses), we have put in place the Local Sponsor Documentation with the Local Sponsors. While we are not aware of any circumstances where the relevant Local Sponsors would wish to do so, there is a risk that a Local Sponsor may intentionally breach the terms of the Local Sponsor Documentation or substantially equivalent contractual arrangements (including by seeking to unilaterally terminate or amend the terms of such arrangements), respectively. In such a situation, we may lose the full benefit of, and/or control over, the relevant operating businesses, which would have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have limited contractual protection in respect of our interests in certain Third Party Subsidiaries.
Subsubsection Text: As at the date of this Offering Memorandum, it has not been possible for us to put in place contractual arrangements similar to the Local Sponsor Documentation with the Local Sponsors that hold 100% of the share capital of the Third Party Subsidiaries that own and operate two schools in Abu Dhabi, one school in Fujairah and one services business in Dubai. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, less than 5% of our revenues and Adjusted EBITDA were attributable to these schools and businesses. Our ability to control, and derive 100% of the economic benefit from, the relevant subsidiaries that own and operate these schools and business is largely subject to informal business arrangements with the relevant Local Sponsors. If one or more of the relevant Local Sponsors formally challenges the existing business practices by which we exercise such control and derive such economic benefit, we may lose our entitlement to operate the schools and business and to obtain our 100% share of the profits generated thereby. The occurrence of one or more such events could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may face difficulties obtaining and retaining the educational services permits required to operate our schools in the UAE (excluding Dubai).
Subsubsection Text: Under UAE laws and regulations, educational services permits are required to operate our schools. These permits are issued by the UAE Education Regulators in the name of the shareholders of the relevant company operating the schools (jointly, where there is more than one shareholder). A portion of the shares in each of our schools subject to the Local Sponsor Documentation is owned by a Local Sponsor to comply with the UAE Ownership Requirement (or, in the case of (a) three of our Abu Dhabi schools, 100% owed by Local Sponsors due to historical commercial requirements, and (b) one of our Dubai based nurseries, 100% owned by Local Sponsors in order to meet MOE requirements applicable to nurseries). If a Local Sponsor ceased to be a UAE national or 100% owned by UAE nationals, or if there were a deterioration in our relationship with a Local Sponsor, or if the UAE Education Regulators require that permits be held in the name of a natural person instead of a corporate entity or that permits be held by UAE nationals only, there can be no assurance that our ability to continue to operate the affected schools would remain unimpaired. The relevant subsidiary would need to obtain new educational services permits that include the name of a different individual or corporate entity willing to act in the Local Sponsor’s place. The process of changing the name included on the educational services permits issued by the relevant UAE Education Regulators involves the submission of certain documentation with the UAE Education Regulators or other relevant authorities, and any new name included on the educational services permits will generally need to align with the shareholding of the relevant subsidiary of ours. In our experience, it usually takes between four and six weeks for new educational services permits to be 48 ----- obtained from the date of application. There can be no assurance, however, that we would be able to obtain new educational services permits in a timely manner, on acceptable terms or at all. Any delay in identifying a new individual or corporate entity whose name could be included on the educational services permits or obtaining new educational services permits could result in the temporary or permanent closure of the affected school(s) and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our ability to control the majority of our educational services permits is subject to the Local Sponsor Documentation.
Subsubsection Text: Some of our educational services permits are held in the name of the shareholders of the relevant companies operating the schools. The educational services permits in respect of 29 of our schools are therefore held either directly by, or jointly with, the Local Sponsors that are party to the Local Sponsor Documentation. If we are unable to enforce our rights through the Local Sponsor Documentation, there can be no assurance that our ability to operate our business in reliance on the licenses would not be adversely affected. We consider the probability of the risks outlined above occurring to be highly unlikely. Each Local Sponsor typically has existing long-term relationships with us, whether by previously acting in their own name as a sponsor in respect of one of our subsidiaries, being a landlord in respect of any school lease or otherwise. Therefore, each Local Sponsor or (where applicable) its shareholders have an interest to ensure the continued effectiveness of the proposed structure and adherence to the arrangement. Furthermore, the contractual rights in each co-operation agreement are designed to provide an additional layer of protection that ensures our continuing control (through GMCL) over the educational services permits. Each co-operation agreement also imposes obligations on the Local Sponsor in our favor to sign, execute and re-issue, if expired, a new power of attorney. Furthermore, as an additional protection (where applicable), the shareholders of each Local Sponsor have also granted a power of attorney appointing us to represent them, and to do all things on their behalf in relation to dealings with governmental authorities, including the relevant UAE Education Regulators, including signing and submitting documentation in relation to the relevant schools’ educational services permits. However, should any of these risks crystallize, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have more limited control over the schools which we manage but do not own, despite having certain contractual rights.
Subsubsection Text: We provide management services to, but do not own, two third-party schools in Abu Dhabi. We may pursue similar arrangements in the future as a means of expanding our business. We cannot fully control the operations or the assets of these schools, nor can we unilaterally make major decisions with respect to these schools. This lack of control constrains our ability to cause these schools to take actions that would, in our view, be in such school’s best interests, or cause these schools to refrain from taking action that could be materially adverse to our interests. This could expose us to financial, legal and reputational risks, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our Qatari business is subject to risks associated with foreign ownership restrictions.
Subsubsection Text: In the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, less than 5% of our revenues and Adjusted EBITDA were attributable to our operations in Qatar. Although our ownership of our Qatar schools is currently exempt from requirements under Qatar law with respect to foreign investment (which generally restricts ownership by non-Qatari nationals in Qatari companies to 49%), there can be no assurance that the way in which we are permitted to own our Qatar schools will not be subject to changes. If we are no longer permitted to own 100% of our Qatar schools, there can be no assurance that we would be able to find a viable alternative to our current structure and implement any changes that we are required to comply.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may face certain risks in the event of the death of any of our Local Sponsors.
Subsubsection Text: Our corporate structure includes a number of Local Sponsors that are natural persons. In the event of a Local Sponsor who is a natural person passing away, the Local Sponsor Documentation existing between the Group and such person would automatically terminate in accordance with UAE 49 ----- succession law. The assets held by the Local Sponsor would pass to his/her heirs and any shares would remain subject to any protections set out in the articles of association of the relevant company. Where the relevant Local Sponsor is also a landlord under a lease agreement with us, the rights and obligations under the lease agreement will pass to the Local Sponsor’s heirs. For example, since the death of the Local Sponsor and landlord of OOF, we have been in a dispute regarding the ownership of the professional license to operate the school and the terms of a renewal of a long-term lease with the former Local Sponsor’s heir. This school accounted for less than 1% of our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. There can be no assurance that we will be able to satisfactorily resolve our dispute regarding OOF and agree acceptable lease terms for a new longterm lease with the landlord, which may result in us needing to relocate the school to an alternative site or withdrawing from the school altogether if an economically viable alternative cannot be found. The risks set out in this Offering Memorandum in relation to the Local Sponsor arrangements within our corporate structure may be increased where we are required to enter into contractual and/or other arrangements with a successor to any of the existing Local Sponsors with which we have no established relationship. There can be no guarantee that we would be able to agree equivalent documentation to the Local Sponsor Documentation with any successor to the deceased Local Sponsor.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be required to restructure the ownership and/or tenancy arrangements of certain schools in Abu Dhabi in order to comply with requirements imposed by ADEK.
Subsubsection Text: Circular No. 11 of 2014 issued by the Abu Dhabi Executive Council requests all Abu Dhabi Government entities (including ADEK) and companies fully owned by the Abu Dhabi Government to commit to a standard form musataha agreement (effectively a ground development lease). While it is not clear whether the requirement applies only to new arrangements or requires a transition of existing arrangements to the standard form, ADEK’s interpretation and practical application of the Circular is to impose the requirement in relation to all Government land, regardless of the current status of development and nature of the tenant’s interest. ADEK also requires the relevant tenant to be a UAE national and/or a 100% UAE national-owned entity, and only that tenant may hold an ADEK education license. We are not currently in compliance with, and have been deemed by ADEK not to be in compliance with, the requirement to enter into a standard form musataha agreement in respect of three of our schools in Abu Dhabi. One of these schools, The Cambridge High School, is operated by a Third Party Subsidiary that is wholly owned by UAE nationals who are also the joint holders of the relevant education license. The second of these schools, GEMS United Indian School, is operated by a Minority Subsidiary, the shareholders of which hold the relevant education license. We are also deemed by the Al Ain Municipality and ADEK not to be in compliance with respect to Our Own English High School, Al Ain, although the rationale for this is not clear given that the school is situated on private land. These three schools together accounted for less than 5% of our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. Notwithstanding this non-compliance, ADEK has verbally confirmed that all necessary education licenses and/or no objection certificates will continue to be renewed, thus effectively granting an indefinite grace period for compliance with these requirements by these three schools. However, there can be no assurance that the grace period will not be withdrawn. If the grace period were to end, this could result in ADEK not issuing or renewing necessary education licenses and/or certificates, unless the ownership and/or tenancy arrangements relating to these schools could be restructured to ensure compliance with the requirements in time. If required, we intend to complete any required restructuring. The Cambridge High School in Abu Dhabi and Our Own English High School in Al Ain are already held by Third Party Subsidiaries and compliance is therefore expected to be limited to amending the existing lease arrangements. GEMS United Indian School in Abu Dhabi is currently held by a Minority Subsidiary and compliance, among other things, would require it to be held by a Third Party Subsidiary. However, a failure to complete any required restructuring in order to comply with ADEK’s requirements prior to the expiry of this grace period could lead to ADEK not issuing or renewing necessary education licenses and/or certificates in respect of the relevant school(s). 50 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our insurance coverage may be inadequate or our premiums may increase substantially.
Subsubsection Text: We currently maintain insurance coverage which we believe is adequate and consistent with industry practice. It is possible, however, that our insurance coverage may be inadequate for all risks and/or eventualities to which we may be exposed and that claims may be rejected by our insurers. Furthermore, there can be no assurance that we will be able to obtain future insurance coverage on acceptable terms or at all. Claims against us, regardless of their merit or eventual outcome, may increase the premiums payable by us or result in the denial of future coverage. A successful claim against us which is not covered by, or is in excess of, our insurance coverage could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business may be affected by the occurrence of epidemics or other adverse public health developments, natural disasters or unanticipated catastrophic events.
Subsubsection Text: If an epidemic or other outbreak of disease occurs in one of our schools, parents may withdraw their children from school to protect them from the possibility of infection, faculty and staff may become ill or avoid coming to work to protect themselves from the outbreak, or the government may order the affected school or schools to close to contain the epidemic or outbreak. Similarly, the occurrence of natural disasters or unanticipated catastrophic events could result in material disruptions to our business, especially if the events require halting construction for significant amounts of time on, or the closure of, certain schools, requiring children to be moved to a different location. Additionally, these events may have a material adverse effect on the reputation of the affected school or us as a whole, even where the event was not caused by a failing on the part of us or the school’s management generally. Furthermore, it may take a significant amount of time for our business to recover our prior levels of student enrollment and revenues, as we may not be able to transfer affected students to our other schools due to capacity or other practical concerns.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not realize any or all of our anticipated pro forma adjustments to Adjusted EBITDA included in this Offering Memorandum.
Subsubsection Text: We have prepared Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA on the basis of certain estimates and assumptions to present an estimate of our Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended 31 May 2019 after giving pro forma effect to reflect certain normalization adjustments, the estimated pro forma EBITDA contribution from the acquisition of Bellevue Education, the estimated pro forma rental savings from the repurchase of two school building leases in Qatar and adjustments to add back the negative EBITDA generated by our greenfield investments in four new schools during their ramp-up phase. See “Summary—Summary Financial and Operating Information—Operating Data and Non-IFRS Financial _Information.”_ Each of the adjustments is based on our current estimates, and involve risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that may cause actual results, performance or achievements to be materially different from any anticipated future results. In particular, the pro forma adjustments intended to give effect to the full year impact on our Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months ended 31 May 2019 of the acquisition of Bellevue Education, which we expect to complete in conjunction with this Offering (see “Use of Proceeds”), is based upon financial information, including budgeted data, that was made available to us in connection with the acquisition together with our management’s assumptions and estimates. Therefore, we have included in this Offering Memorandum certain financial information related to the schools that is based on estimated figures for such periods which have been prepared by their previous management together with external advisors in connection with the acquisition process. Moreover, these schools have historically been operated by separate entities and, as such, their historical financial performance may not be indicative of their financial performance both on a standalone basis and within our Group. The Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA has not been reviewed by our auditors and the adjustments and assumptions used in preparing the metrics may prove to be inaccurate or may be affected by other factors that have not been accounted for. The Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA should not be considered in isolation or be used as a substitute for an analysis of the operating results of our Group and no undue reliance should be made in respect of such information. Moreover, pro forma adjustments related to transactions that have not yet been completed (such as the acquisition of Bellevue Education or the repurchase of certain school leases in Qatar) carry the 51 ----- risk that the transactions and the associated EBITDA contribution and savings may never be realized. Such transactions are independent and the signing and closing of any such opportunity is not conditional on the signing and closing of any of the other opportunities. There can be no assurances that all or any of such transactions will take place. The transactions may not be completed for any number of reasons, including, among others, default by the sellers under the purchase agreements or memoranda of understanding, as applicable, or failure by us or them to meet the relevant conditions for any such transaction. We have also made further adjustments based on a number of assumptions related to the impact to EBITDA of our greenfield investments in four new schools that are currently in ramp-up stage and negative EBITDA. These adjustments assume that such greenfield investments will not continue to negative EBITDA in the future. We cannot assure you that these schools will become profitable or cease to generate negative EBITDA in the near term or at all.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Geographical, Political and Economic Conditions
Subsubsection Title: Governments in the MENA region have exercised and continue to exercise significant influence over their respective economies, and legal and regulatory systems in the MENA region may create an uncertain environment for investment and business activities.
Subsubsection Text: The governments in the MENA region, including the UAE, have frequently intervened in the economic policy of their respective countries. This intervention has included, but not been limited to, regulation of market conditions, including foreign investment, foreign trade, financial services and educational services. Any unexpected changes in the political, social, economic or other conditions in the MENA region or neighboring countries could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. These changes include: - an increase in inflation and government measures to curb such inflation, including through policies such as price controls; - governments’ actions or interventions, including tariffs, protectionism, foreign exchange and currency controls and subsidies for certain students or schools; - regulatory and legal structure changes, including foreign ownership restrictions, cancellation of contractual rights, expropriation of assets and potential lack of certainty as to title to real estate property in certain jurisdictions where we operate; - changes to the availability of, requirements for, and cost to secure, employment and residence visas for expatriate staff and their dependents; - income and other taxation (including, for example, the introduction of a value added tax payable on tuition fees); - policies of nationalization of assets and requirements to employ local national employees; - difficulties and delays in obtaining new permits and consents for new operations or renewing existing permits; and - an inability to repatriate profits and/or dividends. Unexpected changes in these policies or regulations could lead to increased operating or compliance expenses and could have the effect of decreasing access to K-12 education. Any such changes could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Geographical, Political and Economic Conditions
Subsubsection Title: Continued geopolitical instability and civil unrest in the MENA region may adversely affect the economies in which we operate.
Subsubsection Text: Since late 2010, there have been significant civil disturbances and political turmoil affecting a number of countries in the MENA region, including Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Libya, Syria, Tunisia and Yemen. The forms of this unrest vary from public demonstrations to, in extreme cases, armed conflicts, and have given rise to increased political uncertainty across the region. This, combined with the continuing state of unrest in Syria and Iraq and the rise of ISIS, have further exacerbated the risk of a larger regional conflict or acts of terrorism in the region. In addition, in June 2017, the KSA, the UAE, and Bahrain, together with certain other states in the MENA region, moved to cut diplomatic ties, as well as 52 ----- trade and transport links with Qatar (the “Qatar developments”). More recently, in June and July 2019, there has been a resumption of tensions between Iran and other countries over the Strait of Hormuz, which is located in the direct vicinity of the UAE. Regional unrest has implications for the wider global economy and may negatively affect market sentiment towards other countries in the region, including the countries in which we operate. Such unrest may also have negative implications on securities issued by companies operating in the region, including those in the UAE. It is not possible to predict the occurrence of events or circumstances such as war or hostilities, or the impact of such occurrences. The occurrence of any of the above factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Although the UAE has not been directly adversely affected by the surrounding unrest, this continuing instability may significantly impact the UAE, including both its financial markets and the real economy. Such impacts could occur through a lower flow of foreign direct investment into the region, emigration of expatriate residents, capital outflows or increased volatility in the global and regional financial markets. Regional volatility could also lead to higher refugee population inflows to the UAE, which the country might not be able to easily absorb, leading to increased social unrest. Furthermore, while the Qatar developments have not affected our operations to date, there can be no assurance that this will continue to be true. If, and to the extent that, this regional volatility leads to an outflow of expatriate residents or capital, or to potential instability or government change in the UAE, Qatar or any other country in which we operate or begin operating, it could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Geographical, Political and Economic Conditions
Subsubsection Title: Our results of operations could be materially adversely affected by changes in the application of value added tax or the introduction and/or change of a corporation tax in the markets in which we operate.
Subsubsection Text: On 1 January 2018, the UAE introduced a value added tax (“UAE VAT”) at the federal level at the standard rate of 5%. While the supply of education and education-related goods and services are generally subject to UAE VAT at the zero rate, the standard rate of 5% applies on certain school support services and real estate services. Moreover, in consultation with professional advisors, we have applied UAE VAT to certain services in accordance with our understanding of the regulatory framework. However, as the UAE VAT is newly introduced and our application and interpretation has so far been untested, there can be no certainty that our application will not be subsequently challenged, or that the federal tax authority will not seek to recover VAT for certain services, or fine us for perceived failures to appropriately levy VAT. We have accounted for VAT (where applicable) and included UAE VAT in our prices where relevant, in respect of the goods and services that we provide in the UAE. Over time, this may result in a decrease in utilization rates and/or demand. Furthermore, given that the services we provide are largely zero-rated and we typically are in a VAT refund position, any delay in the processing of UAE VAT refunds could adversely impact our cash flows. In addition, any imposition of a tax on corporate earnings could also reduce our net profit. Although the individual Emirates where we operate do not impose corporate tax, and at the federal level, the UAE currently does not impose corporate tax on the education sector, there have been periodic and recent discussions about introducing a federal corporate tax regime in the UAE. Any change in UAE tax laws or a significant increase in tax rates could reduce our net profits. With regard to our operations in Qatar, although Qatar is a signatory to the GCC Common VAT Framework Agreement, it does not currently implement VAT. However, Qatar generally imposes a 10% income tax on corporate earnings generated in Qatar. Other tax obligations include, for instance, a requirement to withhold tax on certain payments made to non-resident persons and an obligation to comply with Qatari transfer pricing regulations. Any change in the Qatari tax laws, their interpretation or enforcement by the Qatari tax authorities, or an increase in tax rates, could adversely impact our net profits. Furthermore, we are in the process of acquiring Bellevue, which operates schools in the United Kingdom and Switzerland. Once the Acquisition completes, we will have operations, and generate revenue, in these locations. As such, we will be exposed to tax obligations in these countries. Both the United Kingdom and Switzerland impose corporate taxes, which could reduce our net profit. In addition, we lack experience complying with the tax laws of these jurisdictions, and could face difficulties in complying with the taxation and reporting obligations in these countries. Any such issues 53 ----- could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Geographical, Political and Economic Conditions
Subsubsection Title: Our business may be adversely affected if the U.S. dollar/AED-pegged exchange rate were to be removed or adjusted.
Subsubsection Text: Although the U.S. dollar/AED, U.S. dollar/QAR, and the U.S. dollar/SAR exchange rates are currently pegged, these arrangements may not continue in the future. The existing fixed U.S. dollar rates may be adjusted in a manner that increases the costs of our business. In addition, certain of our borrowings are denominated in U.S. dollars, and the removal or adjustment of the fixed U.S. dollar rates could negatively impact our ability to repay those borrowings. The removal or adjustment of the fixed U.S. dollar rates could also cause the reported results of our operations and financial condition to fluctuate due to currency translation effects, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Geographical, Political and Economic Conditions
Subsubsection Title: Fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates could increase our operating costs.
Subsubsection Text: We prepare our financial statements in U.S. dollars but, after the Acquisition completes, we will derive revenue and incurs costs in pounds sterling and Swiss francs. Foreign exchange rates may fluctuate, and the pound sterling has been particularly volatile since the United Kingdom announced its intention in June 2016 to leave the European Union. Any movements in exchange rates between these currencies and the U.S. dollar that creates a mismatch between our earnings in any foreign currency and our costs that are denominated in that currency could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. In addition, the results of operations and financial condition of Bellevue will not be denominated in U.S. dollars. Having a financial position presented in U.S. dollars could result in foreign exchange translation fluctuations depending on the relative strength of local currencies as compared to the U.S. dollar during any given period. If the U.S. dollar strengthens relative to the local currencies, our financial position as reflected in our Financial Statements will decrease. Any significant increases in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to the functional currencies of our operations could have a material adverse effect on our reported financial results.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Geographical, Political and Economic Conditions
Subsubsection Title: The Issuers and Guarantors are subject to changes in applicable legal, regulatory and tax regimes.
Subsubsection Text: As the global regulatory and tax environment and economic substance requirements evolve, the Issuers and the Guarantors may be subject to new or different statutory and regulatory requirements. It is difficult to predict what impact the adoption of new laws or regulations, or changes in the interpretation of existing laws or regulations, could have on the Issuers and the Guarantors. For example, compliance with various additional obligations may create additional costs, administrative burdens and may adversely affect the management and operation of the Issuers and the Guarantors. In particular, in respect of the Cayman Co-Issuer and GEMS Menasa IPCO (Cayman) Limited, which are incorporated in the Cayman Islands, it should be noted that the Cayman Islands Government has in 2019 introduced the International Tax Co-operation (Economic Substance) Law, 2018, together with related regulations and guidance (together, the “Economic Substance Requirements”). The Economic Substance Requirements, which are part of the evolving global business environment for compliance with the OECD’s BEPS Inclusive Framework, represent a new and evolving area of Cayman Islands law. The Issuers and/or the Guarantors may need to incur additional costs in order to comply with the Economic Substance Requirements and while it is the intention of the aforementioned Cayman Islands entities to be fully compliant, there is a risk of inadvertent non-compliance and the payment of associated penalties. Any such changes to laws, regulations and tax regimes and associated risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects and on those of the Issuers and/or the Guarantors, respectively.

Subsubsection Title: Our substantial leverage and debt service obligations could adversely affect our business and prevent us from fulfilling our obligations with respect to the Notes and the Notes Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: After the issuance of the Notes, we will be highly leveraged. As of 31 May 2019, on an as adjusted basis after giving effect to the Transactions, including the Offering and the use of proceeds therefrom, 54 ----- we would have had as adjusted net secured debt of $1,559.5 million and $200.0 million of undrawn debt available under our Revolving Credit Facility. In addition, we may be able to incur substantial additional debt in the future, including indebtedness in connection with any future acquisition. The terms of the Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement permit us and our subsidiaries to do so, in each case, subject to certain limitations. The degree to which we will be leveraged following the issuance of the Notes could have important consequences to holders of the Notes in the Offering, including: - making it difficult for us to satisfy our obligations with respect to our debt obligations; - increasing our vulnerability to, and reducing our flexibility to respond to, general adverse economic and industry conditions; - requiring the dedication of a substantial portion of our cash flow from operations to the payment of principal of, and interest on, indebtedness, thereby reducing the availability of such cash flow to fund working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, joint ventures, product research and development or other general corporate purposes; - limiting our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business and the competitive environment and the industry in which we operate; - placing us at a competitive disadvantage compared to our competitors, to the extent that they are not as highly leveraged; and - limiting our ability to borrow additional funds and increasing the cost of any such borrowing. Any of these or other consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to satisfy our debt obligations, including the Notes.

Subsubsection Title: We will be subject to restrictive debt covenants that may limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and to pursue business opportunities and activities.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will, and the Senior Facilities Agreement does, among other things, restrict our ability to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - create or incur certain liens; - make certain payments, including dividends or other distributions; - prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity; - make certain investments; - create encumbrances or restrictions on the payment of dividends or other distributions, loans or advances to, and on the transfer of, assets to the Restricted Group; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets, including stock of restricted subsidiaries; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - enter into unrelated businesses or engage in prohibited activities; - consolidate or merge with other entities; and - impair security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. All of these limitations will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of _Notes—Certain Covenants” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities.”_ The covenants to which we are subject could limit our ability to finance future operations and capital needs and our ability to pursue business opportunities and activities that may be in our interests. The Senior Facilities will in addition require us to comply with a springing leverage ratio with respect to the Revolving Credit Facility. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities.” Our ability to meet this financial covenant test can be affected by events beyond our control, and we cannot assure you that we will meet it. A breach of this test could result in an event of default under the Senior Facilities Agreement. Upon the occurrence of any event of default under the Senior 55 ----- Facilities Agreement, subject to applicable cure periods and other limitations on acceleration or enforcement, the relevant creditors could cancel the availability of the facilities and elect to declare all amounts outstanding under the Senior Facilities, together with accrued interest, immediately due and payable. In addition, any default under the Senior Facilities could lead to an event of default and acceleration under other debt instruments that contain cross-default or cross-acceleration provisions, including the Indenture. If our creditors, including the creditors under the Senior Facilities, accelerate the payment of those amounts, we cannot assure you that our assets and the assets of our subsidiaries would be sufficient to repay in full those amounts to satisfy all other liabilities of our subsidiaries which would be due and payable and to make payments to enable us to repay the Notes, in full or in part. In addition, if we are unable to repay those amounts, our creditors could enforce against any Collateral granted to them to secure repayment of those amounts.

Subsubsection Title: We will require a significant amount of cash to meet our obligations under our indebtedness and to sustain our operations, which we may not be able to generate or raise.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on our indebtedness, including the Senior Facilities and our obligations under the Notes, and to fund our ongoing operations, will depend on our future performance and our ability to generate cash, which, to a certain extent, is subject to general economic, financial, competitive, legislative, legal, regulatory and other factors, as well as other factors discussed in these “Risk Factors,” many of which are beyond our control. The Notes will mature in 2026 (while the Term Loan B Facility and the Revolving Credit Facility mature in 2026 and 2025, respectively). At the maturity of the Notes and any other debt which we incur, if we do not have sufficient cash flows from operations and other capital resources to pay our debt obligations, or to fund our other liquidity needs, or we are otherwise restricted from doing so due to corporate, tax or contractual limitations, we may be required to refinance our indebtedness. The type, timing and terms of any future financing will depend on our cash needs and the conditions prevailing in the financial markets. If we are unable to refinance all or a portion of our indebtedness or obtain such refinancing on terms acceptable to us, we may be forced to reduce or delay our business activities or capital expenditures or sell assets or raise additional debt or equity financing in amounts that could be substantial. We cannot assure you that we will be able to accomplish any of these measures in a timely manner or on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Indenture and any future debt may limit our ability to pursue any of these measures.

Subsubsection Title: Despite our current level of indebtedness, we may still be able to incur substantially more debt in the future, which may make it difficult for us to service our debt, including the Notes, and impair our ability to operate our businesses.
Subsubsection Text: We may incur substantial additional debt in the future. Any debt that our subsidiaries incur could be structurally senior to the Notes, and other debt could be secured or could mature prior to the Notes. In addition to the Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations, we may incur additional indebtedness that is permitted to share in proceeds from enforcement of the Collateral. Although the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Indenture will contain restrictions on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, these restrictions are subject to a number of significant qualifications and exceptions, and under certain circumstances, the amount of indebtedness that could be incurred in compliance with these restrictions could be substantial. If new debt is added to our and our subsidiaries’ existing debt levels, the related risks that we now face would increase. Increases in our total indebtedness could also lead to a downgrade of the ratings assigned to the Group or the Notes, which could negatively affect their trading price. In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Indenture will not prevent us from incurring obligations or entering other arrangements that do not constitute indebtedness under those agreements, such as receivables securitization financings.

Subsubsection Title: The loans under the Senior Facilities Agreement bear interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow.
Subsubsection Text: The loans under the Senior Facilities Agreement bear interest at floating rates of interest per annum equal to LIBOR, as adjusted periodically, plus a margin. These interest rates could rise significantly in the future. To the extent that interest rates were to increase significantly, our interest expense would correspondingly increase, reducing our cash flow. 56 ----- Although we may enter into and maintain certain hedging arrangements designed to fix a portion of these rates, there can be no assurance that hedging will continue to be available on commercially reasonable terms. Hedging itself carries certain risks, including that we may need to pay a significant amount (including costs) to terminate any hedging arrangements. To the extent interest rates were to rise significantly, our interest expense would correspondingly increase, thus reducing cash flow. Following allegations of manipulation of LIBOR, various interest rate benchmarks (including LIBOR) are the subject of recent national and international regulatory guidance and proposals for reform. Some reforms are already effective while others are still to be implemented, including the EU Benchmark Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/1011). In addition, the sustainability of LIBOR has been questioned by the FCA as a result of the absence of relevant active underlying markets and possible disincentives (including possibly as a result of regulatory reforms) for market participants to continue contributing to such benchmarks. On November 29, 2017, the Bank of England and the FCA announced that the market Working Group on Sterling Risk-Free Rates would have an extended mandate to catalyze a broad transition to the Sterling Over Night Index Average rate (“SONIA”) across sterling bond, loan and derivatives markets so that SONIA is established as the primary sterling interest rate benchmark by the end of 2021. The Bank of England and FCA have stated that a key near-term priority for the Working Group will be to make recommendations relating to the potential development of SONIA reference rates. A public consultation was launched in July 2018 in relation to specific queries related to the operations of SONIA reference rates. On April 23, 2018, the Bank of England took over administration of SONIA and issued a series of reforms as part of its implementation as a replacement to LIBOR. From April 2018, the Bank of England has been setting the interest rate benchmark using SONIA, meaning that banks are no longer compelled by the FCA to submit LIBOR rates beyond 2021. These reforms and other pressures may cause such benchmarks to disappear entirely, to perform differently than in the past (as a result of a change in methodology or otherwise), create disincentives for market participants to continue to administer or participate in certain benchmarks or have other consequences which cannot be predicted. The potential elimination of the LIBOR benchmark or any other benchmark, changes in the manner of administration of any benchmark, or actions by regulators or law enforcement agencies could result in changes to the manner in which LIBOR is determined, which could require an adjustment to the terms and conditions, or result in other consequences, in respect of any debt linked to such benchmark (including but not limited to, the Senior Facilities whose interest rates are linked to LIBOR). Any such change, as well as manipulative practices or the cessation thereof, may result in a sudden or prolonged increase in reported LIBOR, which could have an adverse impact on our ability to service debt that bears interest at floating rates of interest.

Subsubsection Title: Our hedging and other derivative arrangements may not effectively or sufficiently offset the negative impact of interest rate fluctuations.
Subsubsection Text: We may use a combination of natural hedging techniques and financial derivatives to protect against certain interest rate risks. Historically, we have made use of hedging arrangements to protect our business against interest rate fluctuations, and may continue to do so in the future, including in respect of the Term Loan B Facility. Such hedging activities may be ineffective or may not offset more than a portion of the adverse financial impact resulting from foreign currency variations. Gains or losses associated with hedging activities also may negatively impact operating results.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Issuers are holding companies with no independent operations and are dependent on payments from its operating subsidiaries in order to provide it with funds to meet its obligations.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuers are holding companies and conduct no business operations of their own and are not expected to engage in any activities other than holding the shares of their subsidiaries (if any) and those related to issuing the Notes, the Senior Facilities, the security documents related thereto to which they are a party, the Intercreditor Agreement and the other transactions contemplated thereby and consummating the Transactions generally. As at the Issue Date, the Issuers have no material assets. Therefore, the Issuers will be dependent upon payments from other members of the Group to meet their obligations, including their obligations under the Notes. The amounts available to the Issuers from the other relevant members of the Group will depend on the profitability and cash flows of such members of the Group and the ability of such members to make payments to them under 57 ----- applicable law or the terms of any financing agreements or other contracts that may limit or restrict their ability to pay such amounts. Applicable tax laws may also subject such payments to further taxation. In addition, the members of the Group that do not guarantee the Notes have no obligation to make payments with respect to the Notes. If the Issuers are unable to receive sufficient distributions or dividends or other payment from other members of the Group, they may be unable to service their obligations under the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will be structurally subordinated to the liabilities of non-Guarantor subsidiaries.
Subsubsection Text: Generally, claims of creditors of a non-Guarantor subsidiary, including trade creditors, and claims of preference shareholders (if any) of the subsidiary, will have priority with respect to the assets and earnings of the subsidiary over the claims of creditors of its parent entity, including claims under any intercompany loans and claims by holders of the Notes under the Notes Guarantees. As of 31 May 2019, after giving effect to the Transactions, including the Offering and the use of proceeds therefrom, on a consolidated basis, our subsidiaries that will not guarantee the Notes would have had $31.5 million in outstanding debt. Moreover, the Indenture does not prohibit us from constituting or acquiring new subsidiaries and such subsidiaries may not be required to become Guarantors under the Notes. Additionally, the Indenture provides for a Notes Guarantee to be released in certain circumstances. Unless any such future subsidiary of the Issuers becomes a Guarantor, such subsidiary will not have any obligation to pay amounts due under the Notes or to make funds available for that purpose. The Indenture, subject to some limitations, will permit our future non-Guarantor restricted subsidiaries to incur substantial amounts of indebtedness, and such indebtedness could be secured, subject to the applicable lien capacity, and additionally, the Indenture will not restrict the amount of other liabilities that may be incurred by these subsidiaries. In the event that any non-Guarantor subsidiary becomes insolvent, enters examinership, is liquidated, reorganized, or dissolved or is otherwise wound up other than as part of a solvent transaction: - the creditors of the Issuers (including the holders of the Notes) and the Guarantors will have no right to proceed against the assets of such company; and - creditors of such non-Guarantor company, including trade creditors, will generally be entitled to payment in full from the sale or other disposal of the assets of such company before any Guarantor, as a direct or indirect shareholder, will be entitled to receive any distributions from such subsidiary. As such, the Notes and each Notes Guarantee will each be structurally subordinated to the creditors (including trade creditors) and preference shareholders (if any) of our non-Guarantor subsidiaries for the Notes. Any of the debt that our non-Guarantor subsidiaries incur in the future in accordance with the Indenture will rank structurally senior to the Notes and each Notes Guarantee and any debt we incur that is secured on property or assets that do not form part of the Collateral securing the Notes will be effectively senior to the Notes to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness, including indebtedness of the Senior Facilities.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will not be initially guaranteed by any of the Guarantors or secured by any of the Collateral.
Subsubsection Text: On the Issue Date, the Notes will not be guaranteed or secured by any Collateral, as further described under “Description of Notes—Security.” The Notes Guarantees are not required to be granted until 60 days after the Issue Date. Certain security interests in the Collateral may not be granted until 10 business days after the Issue Date, while the pledge over the shares of the UAE Guarantors are not required to be granted until the later of the date falling 10 business days after the Issue Date or 10 business days after the date on which a notary public in the United Arab Emirates has approved the share pledge. Moreover, there can be no assurance that we will be successful in procuring such Notes Guarantees or security interests within the time period specified, the failure of which would result in an “event of default” under the Indenture. 58 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: Each Notes Guarantee and security interest will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit its validity and enforceability.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will include language to the effect that each Notes Guarantee and each security interest granted as well as any other obligation under the Security Documents will be limited so as to ensure compliance with local law. The Notes Guarantees, security interests and other obligations will also be subject to applicable corporate and other laws. In general, these laws prohibit companies from providing financial assistance to anyone for the purpose of acquiring their shares and limit the circumstances in which companies can transfer economic benefits to their shareholders outside the payment of properly declared dividends. They also provide for limitations that affect the rights of creditors generally in case an entity becomes insolvent. See “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability _of the Guarantees and Security Interests” for more details regarding limitations on Notes Guarantees_ and security interests in the Cayman Islands and the United Arab Emirates. Moreover, certain transaction documents that are governed by U.S. law judgments rendered by a U.S. court will generally not be directly enforceable in any of the jurisdictions in which the majority of the assets by which the Notes are secured are located. Instead, in many of these jurisdictions, as a pre-condition to enforcing a U.S. judgment, a local court will subject the judgment to a multi-factor test. Several of the factors the court will consider involve a considerable amount of discretion. And even if the court ultimately finds that the judgment is enforceable, the process may take a lengthy amount of time to complete. For all of these reasons, an investment in the Notes involves unique risks that may not apply or apply differently in a more conventional secured bond offering. If any of these risks materializes, your ability to collect payments of principal and interest under the Notes may be materially adversely affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will be secured only to the extent of the value of the assets that have been granted as security for the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be secured on a first-ranking basis by the same assets that secure the Senior Facilities, in each case, to the extent legally possible and subject to the Intercreditor Agreement and to any thin capitalization or tax issues, any legal or corporate benefit restrictions and the Agreed Security Principles. Not all of our assets secure the Notes and we will not be obligated to take action to perfect all liens on assets that do secure the Notes. If we default on the Notes, the holders of the Notes will be secured only to the extent of the value of the Collateral underlying their security interest. See “—The _Notes will not be initially guaranteed by any of the Guarantors or secured by all of the Collateral.” We_ may incur additional indebtedness in the future, which may also be secured by the Collateral. Your rights to the Collateral may be diluted by any increase in debt secured by the Collateral on a similar or more favorable basis to the Notes or a reduction of the Collateral securing the Notes. If the value of the Collateral is less than the value of the claims of the holders of the Notes together with the claims of the other secured creditors, those claims may not be satisfied in full. Furthermore, the Collateral may also secure certain additional indebtedness in the future on a super priority basis, pursuant to the terms and limitations set forth under the Indenture. If any such super senior indebtedness is incurred after the Issue Date, in the event of an enforcement of the Collateral, pursuant to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from the Collateral only after such super senior indebtedness has been repaid in full. As a result, holders of the Notes may receive less in an enforcement or insolvency scenario than if they were not required to share the proceeds. No appraisals of any of the security have been prepared by us or on our behalf in connection with the Offering. The fair market value of the security is subject to fluctuations based on factors that include, among others, our ability to implement our business strategy, the ability to sell the security in an orderly sale, general economic conditions, the availability of buyers and similar factors. The amount to be received upon a sale of any security would be dependent on numerous factors, including, but not limited to, the actual fair market value of the security at such time, general, market and economic conditions and the timing and the manner of the sale. There also can be no assurance that the security will be saleable and, even if saleable, the timing of any liquidation or foreclosure is uncertain. To the extent that liens, rights or easements granted to third parties encumber assets located on property owned by us, such third parties have or may exercise rights and remedies with respect to the property subject to such liens that could adversely affect the value of the security and the ability of the 59 ----- Security Agent to realize or foreclose on the security. In addition, the share pledges of an entity may be of no value if that entity is subject to an insolvency or bankruptcy proceeding. By the nature of our business, some or all of the security may be illiquid and may have no readily ascertainable market value. In the event that a bankruptcy case is commenced by or against us, if the value of the security is less than the amount of principal and accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes and other senior secured obligations, interest may cease to accrue on the Notes from and after the date the bankruptcy petition is filed. In the event of a foreclosure, liquidation, bankruptcy or similar proceeding, we cannot assure you that the proceeds from any sale or liquidation of the security will be sufficient to pay the obligations due under the Notes. In the future, the obligations to provide additional guarantees and grant additional security over assets, or a particular type or class of assets, whether as a result of the acquisition or creation of future assets or subsidiaries, the designation of a previously unrestricted subsidiary as a restricted subsidiary or otherwise, are subject to the Agreed Security Principles and, in the case of the Notes, the Intercreditor Agreement. The Agreed Security Principles set out a number of limitations on the rights of the holders of the Notes to require granting of, or payment or enforcement under, a guarantee or security in certain circumstances. The operation of the Agreed Security Principles may result in, among other things, the amount recoverable under any guarantee or security provided by any subsidiary being limited or security not being granted over a particular type or class of assets. Accordingly, the Agreed Security Principles may affect the value of the Notes Guarantees and Collateral provided by us and our subsidiaries. The validity and enforceability of the guarantees and security may also be affected by local law limitations. See “—Each Notes Guarantee and security _interest will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable laws or subject to certain defenses that may limit its validity and enforceability.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: Holders of the Notes will not control certain decisions regarding the Collateral.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be secured by certain of the Collateral securing the obligations under the Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations. We can incur additional indebtedness and other obligations that may be secured by the same Collateral under the terms of the Indenture. As a result of the voting provisions set forth in the Intercreditor Agreement, under certain circumstances, the lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement and counterparties to certain hedging arrangements could have effective control of all decisions with respect to the collateral securing the Notes. Pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Security Agent serves as a common security agent for the secured parties under the Senior Facilities Agreement, certain hedging obligations and the Notes. Subject to certain limited exceptions, the Security Agent will act with respect to such collateral only at the direction of an “Instructing Group”. The holders of the Notes will not have separate rights to enforce the Collateral. In addition, the holders of the Notes will not be able to instruct the Security Agent, force a sale of Collateral or otherwise independently pursue the remedies of a secured creditor under the Security Documents, unless they comprise an Instructing Group which is entitled to give such instructions. Disputes may occur between the holders of the Notes and creditors under the Senior Facilities, the counterparties to certain hedging arrangements or holders of any permitted additional indebtedness as to the appropriate manner of pursuing enforcement remedies and strategies with respect to the collateral. In such an event, the holders of the Notes will be bound by any decisions of the Instructing Group, which may result in enforcement action in respect of the Collateral, whether or not such action is approved by the holders of the Notes or may be adverse to such holders. The creditors under the Senior Facilities Agreements, the counterparties to certain hedging arrangements or the holders of certain other permitted additional indebtedness may also have interests that are different from the interest of holders of the Notes and they may elect to pursue their remedies under the relevant security documents at a time when it would otherwise be disadvantageous for the holders of the Notes to do so. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.” These arrangements could result in the enforcement of the Collateral in a manner that results in lower recoveries by holders of the Notes. Furthermore, other creditors not subject to the Intercreditor Agreement could commence enforcement action against the Company or its subsidiaries during such period, the Company or one or more of its subsidiaries could seek protection under applicable bankruptcy laws, or the value of certain Collateral could otherwise be impaired or reduced in value. 60 ----- If the Security Agent sells Collateral comprising the shares of any of our subsidiaries as a result of an enforcement action in accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement, claims under the Notes and the Notes Guarantees and the liens over any other assets securing the Notes and the Notes Guarantees may be released. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of Notes—Security—Release of Liens.”

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Company and the Guarantors will have control over certain of the Collateral, and the operation of the business or the sale of particular assets could reduce the pool of assets securing the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Security Documents allow the Issuers and the Guarantors to remain in possession of, retain exclusive control over, freely operate and collect, invest and dispose of any income from certain of the Collateral. So long as no default or event of default under the Indenture would result therefrom, the Issuer and the Guarantors may, among other things, subject to the terms of the Security Documents, without any release or consent by the Trustee or the Security Agent, conduct ordinary course activities with respect to the Collateral such as selling, modifying, factoring, abandoning or otherwise disposing of the Collateral and making ordinary course cash payments, including repayments of indebtedness. Any of these activities could reduce the value of the Collateral, which could reduce the amounts payable to you from the proceeds of any sale of the Collateral in the case of an enforcement of the liens on the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes, the Notes Guarantees and Our Structure
Subsubsection Title: There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Notes under which the Collateral securing the Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the Trustee.
Subsubsection Text: Under various circumstances, the Notes Guarantees and the Collateral securing the Notes will be released automatically. See “Description of Notes—Guarantees,” and “Description of Notes— _Security—Release of Liens.” In addition, if the Security Agent sells Collateral comprising the ordinary_ shares of the Issuers or the Guarantors as a result of an enforcement action, then claims under the Notes and the Notes Guarantees may be released or transferred. Your ability to recover on the Notes could be materially impaired in such circumstances. The Intercreditor Agreement also provides that the Collateral may be released and retaken in connection with the refinancing of certain indebtedness, including the Notes, if the Issuers have confirmed in writing to the Security Agent that it has determined that it is either not possible or not desirable to implement any such refinancing on terms satisfactory to it by instead granting additional Collateral and amending the terms of the existing Collateral. In certain jurisdictions, such a release and retaking of Collateral may give rise to the start of a new “hardening period” in respect of such Collateral.
