Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key factors affecting results of operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations and financial condition are affected by a variety of factors. Set out below is a discussion of the most significant factors that have affected our financial results in the periods under review and which we expect may affect our financial results in the future. In addition, certain factors other than those set forth below could also have a significant impact on our results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Macroeconomic and political conditions affecting demand for private K-12 English-language education in Dubai and the UAE
Subsubsection Text: Nearly all of our students are located in the UAE, and Dubai is our single largest market. As a result, our results of operations are, and will continue to be, affected by macroeconomic and political developments in or affecting Dubai and the UAE and, in particular, the impact of such developments on the demand for private K-12 English-language education. Demand is driven by factors including overall population growth, particularly among expatriates (who comprised over 88% of the population of the UAE in 2018, growth in the number of children in the UAE, the average length of time 76 ----- expatriates stay in the UAE, GDP and net income growth, the lack of a public schools provision for expatriate children in the UAE, the trend of UAE nationals switching from public-sector schooling to private-sector international schooling (since it was first permitted in 2015) and the desire among parents for high-quality private education for their children. Weaker economic conditions in the UAE generally result in both lower increases in student enrollments and higher attrition as a result of students leaving our schools, either as their parents leave the country, or through enrollment into competing schools. Together, lower gross enrollment and higher attrition can result in lower rates of net enrollment growth or net enrollment losses. In addition, lower demand also impacts our ability to raise the fees we charge. We have not had a decrease in net enrollments in any single year since 2003. We believe that the importance that parents place on education, the relative resilience shown by expatriate flows among our parent base during difficult economic conditions, and the relative price and value proposition of our schools compared to our competition have contributed to resilience in net enrollments. During the periods under review, economic growth in Dubai, Abu Dhabi and the UAE as a whole has resulted in a growing overall population and growth in the number of children attending schools in the UAE, as well as an increasing average length of stay in the region for expatriates. This economic environment, together with the growing demand for private K-12 English-language education, has helped to drive the increase in our student enrollments from 104,200 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to 114,644 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 to 119,616 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 to 123,368 in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. Growth in enrollment levels contributed approximately half of the overall revenue growth in the School Operations division between the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 and 2018.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our primary source of revenue is school tuition fees, which make up most of our School ARPS. School ARPS was $6,640 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, $7,074 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, $7,419 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 and $6,528 in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. Expansion in School ARPS accounted for approximately half of overall revenue growth in the School Operations division between the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 and the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. We have discretion to set the level of tuition fees at our new schools upon commencement of operations based on commercial considerations. Thereafter, we are permitted by our regulators in Dubai and Abu Dhabi to increase school tuition fees periodically according to a regulated framework. In Dubai, annual fee increases are regulated by the KHDA under the School Fees Framework and are generally linked to two factors: an annually-adjusted inflation benchmark, the ECI, and the rating that a school receives from the KHDA. The ECI is determined annually by the Dubai Statistics Centre (the “DSC”) and is based on historically observed inflation in the costs of operating a school, as determined by the DSC. The ECI is typically comparable to the DSC’s assessment of inflation in the consumer price index (CPI). The applicable ECI is typically announced in advance of an academic year, allowing school operators to communicate fee increase guidance to parents prior to seeking parental re-enrollment intentions. The ECI is generally announced in advance of the following academic year, allowing school operators to communicate fee increase guidance to parents in advance, and typically prior to seeking parental re-enrollment intentions. The ECI was 2.9% for the 2015–2016 academic year, 3.2% for the 2016–2017 academic year and 2.4% for the 2017–2018 academic year. In the 2018–2019 academic year, school operators in Dubai were not permitted to increase school fees. In April 2019 the ECI for the following 2019-2020 academic year was announced as 2.07%. Prior to the twelve months ended 31 August 2019, the School Fees Framework permitted schools to raise fees by a multiplier of ECI linked to the then-prevailing DSIB of the school. This generally allowed us to raise fees by an amount in excess of inflation. As at the date of this Offering Memorandum, we had six schools with an “outstanding” rating, six schools with a “very good” rating, 11 schools with a “good” rating and two schools with an “acceptable” rating. Schools which have been in operation for three years or less are not rated, and as such, four of our schools have not yet been rated or are pending review. Our average multiplier for each of the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 77 ----- and 2018 was 1.6x ECI (calculated on an unweighted simple average basis). Between the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 and the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 we were generally able to pass on the maximum permitted fee increase under the School Fees Framework, with only one exception at one of our schools in Dubai in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, when we chose to maintain fees for school-specific reasons in that school. Between the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 and the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, our School ARPS growth exceeded the UAE CPI as a result of the strong aggregate rating performance of our UAE schools. Prior to the 2019 revision, the School Fees Framework permitted schools to raise fees by a multiplier of ECI linked to the then-prevailing DSIB score of the school. This generally allowed us to raise fees by an amount in excess of inflation. Following the 2019 revision, the multiplier is driven by whether the school has achieved positive or negative changes in its rating from the DSIB. The multiplier is structured to incentivize school operators to invest in their schools in order to raise their ratings. If a school’s rating is upgraded, it can increase fees by the multiplier set out in the table below. If the school’s rating is downgraded, the school will not be able to increase fees by any amount in the coming year. The following table sets out the multiplier applicable to various ratings movements:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our principal source of revenue is school revenue, which we earn in our School Operations Division. This includes tuition, other revenues such as student registration and admission charges, and management fees. Principal drivers of revenues include macroeconomic and political conditions affecting enrollment demand in the markets in which we operate, tuition fee levels, grade aging and school maturity, student mix and the quantum of school support services revenues earned. Revenue is also impacted by seasonality. These factors are set out in more detail below.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our School ARPS growth during the periods under review has been impacted by grade aging, which has been increasing for two reasons. First, tuition fees are higher in more senior grades across all our schools, regardless of the ECI or rating. For example, the tuition fee charged for a student entering GEMS Wellington International School in KG1 was approximately $14,800 per annum for the 2018– 2019 academic year, whereas the tuition fee for a student entering the 12[th] grade was approximately $25,500. Second, the average grade of students across our portfolio has risen year-on-year within the review period. We develop new schools to accommodate junior grades initially, and subsequently provide capacity for more senior level grades as the student population matures. Our student population is generally young. As at 31 May 2019, the average grade of our students was 4.7, and the average grade of students at our Maturing Schools and New Schools was 3.9 and 2.7, respectively. Between September 2013 and February 2019, we opened 18 schools. We expect that an additional school will be opened in September 2019. Newly opened schools primarily attract kindergarten and junior grade students in their first years of opening. This has meant that these newer schools have student bodies which are more heavily skewed towards junior grades than our Mature Schools. In each year, as these schools mature, younger students graduate through grades in the school, and the average student body ages. The following graph sets out our enrollment mix by grade for the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Eligible schools that have maintained the same rating of the previous ECI year[(1)] Schools that have improved their rating from[(1)]: ECI x 2 Very Weak to Weak Weak to Acceptable Acceptable to Good Schools that have improved their rating from[(1)]: ECI x 1.75 Good to Very Good Schools that have improved their rating from: ECI x 1.5 Very Good to Outstanding Schools that have dropped in performance (from their current rating to a No increase in school fees lower one)[(1)] Note: (1) For profit schools in Dubai, the last inspection rating conducted by DSIB will be considered while implementing the fee increase as per the above table. We view tuition fee increases associated with the ECI as an opportunity to ensure that the operational cost inflation we experience can be passed on to customers, either in part or in whole, thus supporting our operating margins. Tuition fees for our schools in other jurisdictions are reviewed periodically. In Abu Dhabi, fee increases for the 2019-2020 academic year will be granted based on two factors: the Abu Dhabi Education Cost Index (“ADECI”) (set at 2.31% in the 2019-2020 academic year) and a school’s rating, with higherrated schools able to increase fees by a greater multiple of the ADECI. An exceptional fee increase regime also exists in Abu Dhabi. In Sharjah, Fujairah and Ras Al Khaimah, private schools are required to request proposed fee increases directly from the UAE Ministry of Education. Any proposed fee increases are subject to the maximum permitted increase of 10% one year after the last increase, 20% two years after the last increase and 30% three years after the last increase. In addition to fee increases pursuant to the various fee frameworks, UAE regulators will consider applications for exceptional fee increases (subject to certain conditions laid out in the fee framework). We have secured exceptional fee increases on a number of occasions across various Emirates since the introduction of the fee framework. In advance of academic year 2019-2020, we have secured exceptional fee increases in Dubai, Abu Dhabi and Sharjah. In Dubai, we have secured exceptional fee increases for four of our schools; Al Khaleej National School, where we are permitted to raise fees by 21.4% over the course of three years; Kindergarten Starters, where we are permitted to raise fees by 9.45% over the course of two years; The Westminster School Dubai (“TWS”) where we are permitted to raise fees by 4.0% over the 78 ----- course of the next year; and Our Own Indian School (“OIS”), where we are permitted to raise fees by 9.74% over two years. In Abu Dhabi, we are permitted to raise fees by 18.35% for OOL, Al Ain over the course of the next year. In Sharjah, we are permitted to raise fees by 10% for the coming academic year for both Our Own Boys School, Sharjah, and Our Own Girls School. In Qatar, all fee increases must be approved by the Qatar Ministry of Education. For additional details on the fee increase regimes to which we are subject, see “Regulation Overview.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: FY2016A FY2017A FY2018A May2019A Kindergarten Division Junior Division Middle Division Senior Division Note: (1) Enrollment numbers are computed based on closing enrollments. 79 ----- The following graphs set out our enrollment mix by grade for Mature and Maturing Schools for the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: One of the factors affecting our School ARPS, which in turn affects our revenue, is our mix of students by school type. School tuition fees per student range from $2,000 to $30,000 per year, with schools in the Mid-Market price point typically charging fees of between $2,000 and U.S.7,000 annually per student, schools in the Mid-Market Plus price point typically charging between $5,000 and $15,000 annually per student, and schools in the Premium price point typically charging between $15,000 and $30,000 annually per student. As such, School ARPS for students will typically be highest for students at Premium schools, followed by students at Mid-Market Plus schools and then Mid-Market schools. Moreover, fees in our Maturing Schools and New Schools are generally higher than those in our Mature Schools, even within the same price point. This is because initial fee levels at newly opened schools are not subject to regulation, while yearly fee increases are subject to regulation. School ARPS in the nine months ended 31 May 2019 for our Mature Schools was $6,746, compared to a School ARPS of $9,683 for Maturing Schools and $7,895 for New Schools in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. As such, new students generally joined schools at higher price points, and the progression of those students into higher grades at higher prices will generally contribute to higher School ARPS. 80 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We provide a comprehensive range of school support services that generate ancillary revenues for us through separate fees charged to students. These services include school bus and other transportation services, school uniform sales, sports services, after-school activities, school catering, school security services and teacher training. Support Services ARPS, together with School ARPS, makes up our total ARPS. While the majority of the School Support Services division’s revenue is generated through offering services to our students, certain services are also provided to third parties. Fees for these services are dependent on both the level of service provided (with higher fees for higher price points), and demand for the individual service, which can vary across price points. For instance, school bus transportation services are particularly dependent on Mid-Market enrollments, as this business sees the highest utilization from students enrolled in schools at this price point. Our Support Services ARPS, which is primarily attributable to school bus transportation services, was $939, $1,005, $1,125, and $1,043 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our revenues are affected by seasonality. We recognize revenues over the ten months of a year when our schools are in session, between September and June. However, our business incurs costs, including teaching salaries, over a twelve-month period throughout the year. We recognize six months of revenue and costs in the first half of our fiscal year, from 1 September until 28 February, but only approximately four months of revenues against six months of costs in the second half of our fiscal year, from 1 March to 31 August. Accordingly, our revenues are generally higher in the first half of our fiscal year than in second half. We typically generate an operating loss during the summer months of July and August when our business generates low revenues but pays salaries. As such, Adjusted EBITDA margins in the first half of our fiscal year are generally higher than those in the second half. For example, our Adjusted EBITDA margin was 33% in the six months ended 28 February 2018 and 19% in the six months ended 31 August 2018. In addition, our British and IB curriculum-based schools require tuition fees to be paid in three yearly installments, our American curriculum-based schools require tuition to be paid in two yearly installments and our Indian curriculum-based schools generally require monthly tuition payments. In all of the curricula, tuition fees are required to be paid in September, as that is the start of the school year for the British, American and IB curricula-based schools, and a month in which payment is due for the Indian curriculum-based schools. However, to the extent that parents pay fees in advance in August, they will be accounted for in the previous fiscal year, whereas fees that are paid in September are accounted for in the following fiscal year. As such, the timing of fee payments may have an impact on our bank balances and cash and indebtedness.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: 2016 2017 2018 Kindergarten Division Junior Division Middle Division Senior Division Whenever we open a new school, we expect to see a large rise in enrollments among younger students attending the lower grades of the school, thus slowing the increase or decreasing the average grade of our students. This may have a dilutive effect on School ARPS in the short term, as students in lower grades pay lower fees than students in higher grades at the same school. However, the added enrollments increase our long-term potential revenue over time The average age and grade of students across our portfolio has increased in each period between the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019. Our weighted average grade across our entire school portfolio has increased from grade 4.5 to 4.6 to 4.7 to 4.7 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019, respectively. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019, we accepted an above average number of younger students into our schools (and particularly our New Schools and Maturing Schools). This impacted the overall enrollment mix in these years. Grade aging also occurs in Mature Schools, where during the periods under review we have observed that the weighted average school grade continued to increase. We attribute this effect to the continuing maturation of the UAE’s expatriate population, and the increasing trend of parents staying longer in the country. For further information on grade aging, see “Business—Our Business—The School Operations _division—Grade aging.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: A significant component of our expenses is school staff compensation, in particular for teaching staff. School staffing expense is driven by two primary factors—individual teacher compensation and the number of teachers employed relative to the number of students, typically expressed as the Pupil Teacher Ratio (“PTR”), which is calculated at the period end. As part of our commitment to hiring and retaining highly qualified staff, we benchmark teaching salaries to both home-country and UAE pay levels. Our compensation packages for teachers typically include housing, provision of school services to teachers’ children and airfare allowances as well as statutory end of service benefits. Relocation benefits are paid when recruiting from overseas. We have also historically operated a long-term incentive plan for teachers which offers cash payments to our longer-term teaching employees. 81 ----- Staff costs comprised 62.2%, 62.8%, 63.5%, 67.1% and 66.4% of the School Operations division’s expenses for the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and the nine months ended 31 May 2018 and 2019, respectively. As we continue to expand our school network and the capacity of our schools, we will need to hire more teachers, which will result in an absolute increase in expenses. The PTR varies across our various school models. PTRs are lower (and number of teachers are higher) in Premium schools as compared to Mid-Market Plus schools, which in turn have lower PTRs than Mid-Market schools. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, PTRs were 12.1 for Premium schools, 15.8 for Mid-Market Plus schools and 19.6 for Mid-Market schools. In addition, PTR levels increase as schools mature, and our overall PTR has historically been diluted by new schools being added to our school portfolio. We generally have maintained a high level of investment in both teacher compensation and teacher numbers. Between the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019, aggregate PTRs across all models decreased from 17.3 to 16.6, as set out in the following table.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We incur general expenses across our School Operations and School Support Services divisions. Expenses comprise (i) education and administrative expenses, which include staff costs, other education and administrative expenses, rental—operating leases (“rental costs”), one-off costs, (ii) depreciation, impairment and amortization and (iii) pre-operative expenses. Our ability to maintain and increase profitability depends on our ability to manage these expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We classify our operating costs relating to the management of our business, other than staff costs, rental costs, one-off costs, as “administrative expenses”. Within the School Operations division, other education and administrative expenses include items such as water and electricity expenses, the operational cost of cleaning and routine facilities maintenance, school supplies and various other costs, including marketing expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our rental costs in respect of operating leases were $69.9 million, $74.2 million and $79.6 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively, and $59.9 million and $62.4 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 and 2019, respectively. See “Business—Our _Business—The School Operations division—Approach to operation of our schools” and “—Capital expenditure and other commitments.”_ Our rental costs arise from long-term contractual arrangements over which we have significant visibility. The weighted average remaining lease term of our lease arrangements as at 31 May 2019 was 14.1 years, with the longest lease having 29 years remaining. Eight of our leases are due to be renewed in the next five fiscal years. In addition, we are negotiating renewal terms for one lease which has expired, but where we continue to operate the school, OOF. We continue to evaluate the cost of leases against the cost of capital and may therefore selectively look to repurchase sale and leaseback arrangements which are expensive relative to current market lease rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: One-off costs comprise IPO expenses and other non-recurring costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation consists of non-cash expenses commensurate with the declining value of the tangible assets in the business. It is the systematic allocation of the depreciable amount of a tangible asset over its useful life. Impairment consists of amount by which the carrying amount of an asset or cash-generating unit exceeds its recoverable amount. Carrying amount is the amount at which an asset is recognized in the balance sheet after deducting accumulated depreciation and accumulated impairment losses. 82 ----- Amortization consists of non-cash expenses commensurate with the declining value of the intangible assets with definite life in the business. It is the systematic allocation of the intangible asset over their definite life. Indefinite-life intangibles are not amortized as there is no foreseeable limit to the cash flows generated by those intangible assets. Instead of amortization, indefinite-life assets are evaluated for impairment yearly.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Pre-operative expenses comprise all expenses incurred in advance of the opening of a new school.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: PTR . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 17.3 16.8 16.5 16.5 16.6 Much of this decrease was attributable to the addition of Maturing Schools and New Schools to the portfolio. PTRs are generally lower in Maturing Schools and New Schools, as we will recruit the number and type of teachers that we expect will be required based on anticipated enrollment levels in year two of operation.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to grow total enrollment depends on our ability to develop new schools or increase capacity at existing schools. In each of the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019, we have grown overall enrollment levels at both Maturing Schools and New Schools. We incur certain fixed costs relating to the operation of our business each year, regardless of student enrollment levels. Enrollment of additional students in schools which have available capacity does not increase fixed costs, principally rent, as well as head office costs, and only marginally increases semifixed costs such as general and administrative costs, resulting in lower average costs per student and higher potential profits. As such, the utilization rate of our schools is a key driver of revenue and profit margin. The total capacity at our schools increased by 20,506 places between 1 September 2015 and 31 May 2019, due to the establishment of seven new schools, the extension of nine existing schools and the relocation of two schools. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, we commenced operations at two new schools and extended four existing schools, increasing total capacity to 116,188 students. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, we commenced operations at four new schools, acquired Wesgreen International School and extended five existing schools, increasing total capacity to 132,407 students. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, we commenced operations at two new schools, merged GEMS American Academy and GEMS Nations Academy and extended four existing schools, increasing total capacity to 145,959 students. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, we commenced operations at one new school, GEMS Founders Mizhar, with a capacity of 3,210 seats, increased capacity at one existing school, Wesgreen International School, by approximately 1,100 seats, and merged Our Own Boys School Sharjah into New Our Own English Private School, Sharjah, the combined effect of which was to increase total capacity to 146,831 students. We intend to open a new school in September 2019 on the site of the former Our Own Boys School, Sharjah. Capacity utilization is calculated as the number of enrolled students divided by the available capacity. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019, our overall capacity utilization rate was 90%, 87%, 82% and 84%, respectively. Our capacity utilization rate has decreased due to our investment in new capacity in each period, which typically occurs ahead of enrollment growth. We aim to increase the capacity of our schools on an ongoing basis, but any expansion will temporarily decrease our overall utilization rate until we are able to enroll more students. Accordingly, a key driver of our success is our ability to quickly fill available capacity and maintain high utilization rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Shifting financial dynamics through a school’s lifecycle
Subsubsection Text: Our schools exhibit shifting financial dynamics throughout their lifecycle. Schools are initially lossmaking when they are first built, due to pre-operative expenses, as well as comparatively high fixed costs which are offset by a small enrollment base. However, as the school matures and enrollment and utilization increases, profitability increases. This occurs in part because increasing enrollments lead to more favorable starting utilization levels, including PTRs, while fixed costs remain relatively unchanged and pre-operative expenses are absorbed. As such, opening new schools is accretive to revenue, but initially dilutive to profitability. Expansions to existing schools have a similar effect, although the dilution in profitability is mitigated by these schools’ existing enrollment base. 83 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We regularly construct new schools and expand the facilities of our existing schools in order to expand our capacity and meet growing enrollment needs. During the planning and construction phases, these projects increase our capital outlays, although we construct our schools in phases, with a primary school constructed first, followed three to four years later by a secondary school, to reduce the initially required capital outlay. When the projects are completed, the additional capacity provided by the construction or expansion allows us to increase our enrollments and therefore our revenues. We expect to open one school in September 2019 and another in September 2020, with additional schools to open in the following years. See “Business—Our Business—The School Operations _division—Development of new schools and expansion of existing schools” and “—Capital expenditure and other commitments.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: During the periods under review, we acquired a group of schools which we now classify as one school, Wesgreen International School, as well as the Hamilton Aquatics, Threads and Infracare facilities management businesses. The acquisition of Wesgreen International School allowed us to acquire a Mature School that was already highly utilized, with approximately 3,500 existing enrollments and a capacity of 4,000 seats. Concurrently with the Offering, we are acquiring Bellevue, which operates 15 schools, 14 of which are in the United Kingdom and one of which is in Switzerland. In addition, we have exchanged contracts to buy Farlington School, and anticipate completing this transaction in early September 2019.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our finance costs in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 and 2019 were $31.4 million, $51.3 million, $64.8 million, $49.3 million and $60.0 million, respectively. These costs primarily reflected the interest expense attributable to our banking facilities. On 4 December 2017, we drew down $900 million of the Existing Senior Facilities to refinance our existing facilities and to pay the related fees, costs and expenses. In addition, we also raised $200 million through the issuance of subordinated perpetual certificates (the “Certificates”) in November 2013. Payments under the Certificates are recorded in our accounts to equity as preferred dividends. We repaid the Certificates pursuant to a call option on the first available date of 21 November 2018, using a mixture of additional drawings under our Existing Senior Facilities and available cash resources at that time. 84 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our net finance costs comprise the difference between finance income and finance costs for the fiscal year/period. Finance income comprises interest income received. Finance costs comprise term loan interest, the unwinding of deferred and contingent consideration, the amortization of loan arrangement fees, and bank charges and other fees, including credit card merchant fees. We secure preferential credit card merchant fees by offering customers co-branded credit cards under our loyalty program.

Subsubsection Text: _of Mature Schools . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._ _96_ _97_ _97_ _97_ _99 of Maturing Schools . . . . . . . . . . . ._ _60_ _54_ _55_ _55_ _60 of New Schools . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._ _—_ _—_ _8_ _8_ _22_ **PTR . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** **17.3** **16.8** **16.5** **16.5** **16.6** We expanded enrollment by 10,444 students, or 10%, from 104,200 students in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to 114,644 students in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017. Our enrollment grew across all price points, and in both our Mature and Maturing Schools, with the fastest growth in our Maturing Schools, where enrollment grew by 5,145 students. New schools were a key driver of enrollment growth, as at the beginning of the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, we opened four new schools, GEMS Founders (British curriculum, Mid-Market), GEMS Winchester Fujairah (British curriculum, Mid-Market), GEMS Nations Academy (American curriculum, Premium) and GEMS Al Barsha National School for Girls (British curriculum, Mid-Market Plus), and acquired Wesgreen International School in Sharjah (British curriculum, Mid-Market Plus). The acquisition of Wesgreen International School contributed over 3,500 additional student enrollments. We classify Wesgreen International School as a Mature School, as it was opened prior to 2014. We also completed extensions of seven existing schools, resulting in capacity expansion of 16,219 places in the period. After opening in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 and operating 87 ----- successfully for one year, we merged GEMS Nations Academy with GEMS American Academy, an existing premium American curriculum school in time for the start of the following academic year. Despite our growth in enrollment, our overall capacity utilization declined in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 to 87% from 90% in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, as capacity grew at a greater pace than enrollment during the year due to the number of new school openings and extensions of existing schools. We grew enrollment by 4,972 students, or by 4.3%, from 114,644 students in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 to 119,616 students in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. Our enrollment grew across all price points, and in Mature Schools, Maturing Schools and New Schools. Enrollment growth was strongest in our Mid-Market Plus price point, with a 6.5% increase, and was strongest in our Maturing Schools, which accounted for 21.2% of the new enrollments in the period. Capacity increased by 10.2%, or 13,552 seats, during the same period, increasing from 132,407 seats to 145,959 seats. The primary drivers of new capacity during the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 were the opening of two new schools with 5,220 seats, GEMS National School for Boys, Dubai (British, Mid-Market Plus) and GEMS New Our Own English Public School, Sharjah (Indian, Mid-Market). These capacity expansions were offset by the impact of merging GEMS American Academy and GEMS Nations Academy, which decreased capacity for our Premium price point segment in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. Capacity utilization contracted, from 87% in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 to 82% in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, due to the new capacity added during the period outstripping the rise in enrollments during the period. We grew enrollments by 3,655 students, or 3.1%, from 119,713 students in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 to 123,368 students in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. Our enrollment grew across our Mid-Market Plus and Mid-Market price points, and in Mature, Maturing and New Schools. Enrollment growth was strongest in our Mid-Market price point, with a 4.8% increase, and was strongest for our New Schools, which grew by 1,441 enrollments, from 422 enrollments to 1,863 enrollments. During the same period, we grew capacity by 0.6%, or 872 seats, due to the opening of two schools, GEMS Founders Mizhar (British, Mid-Market) and GEMS Our Own English Private School, Sharjah (Indian, Mid-Market), as well as by further expanding a number of existing schools. In combination, the addition of new enrollments outstripped new capacity in the period, resulting in capacity utilization increasing from 82% to 84%. 88 ----- The following tables set out data on revenue, School ARPS and certain other contributors to pricing:

The increase in School Operations revenue by $119.1 million, or 17.2%, from $691.9 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to $811.0 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 was primarily driven by the increase in enrollment of 10,444 students, which was primarily due to new school openings, capacity enhancement in existing schools and the Wesgreen International School acquisition, as described above, and to a lesser extent the 6.5% increase in School ARPS from $6,640 per student in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to $7,074 per student in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017. Growth in School ARPS in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 was driven primarily by fee inflation linked to academic performance, as we fully passed on the 3.21% increase in the ECI during the period. During the period, our average ECI multiplier for Dubai schools was 1.6x, reflecting the number of outstanding, very good and good schools in our portfolio. School ARPS also benefitted from a positive mix effect through a higher contribution from Mid-Market Plus and Premium school revenue at a higher price point than the average. Finally, grade aging also had a positive impact in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 as the weighted average grade in our schools expanded from grade 4.5 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to grade 4.6 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, although the increase was offset in part by the dilutive effect of doubling enrollments during the period. School Operations revenue increased by $76.4 million, or 9.4%, from $811.0 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 to $887.4 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. Revenue growth was broadly equally split between enrollment growth and pricing growth, with School ARPS increasing by 4.9% during the period. Revenue growth was strongest in Maturing Schools, where revenues grew by 17.1%, mostly due to the 20.9% growth in enrollment. The Mid-Market Plus and Mid-Market price points grew by a combined $54.3 million, accounting for over two-thirds of school revenue growth. Premium revenues grew by 5.1%, despite only modest net enrollment growth in the period. 89 ----- We grew School Operations revenues by $15.8 million, or 2.0%, from $789.6 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 to $805.4 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. While student enrollments increased during this period, they were also adversely affected by a negative mix shift, as our Premium school enrollments declined by 783 students, or 2.9%, over the same period. The decline in Premium enrollments was largely driven by decreases in four of our 16 Premium schools. We attribute the contraction in enrollments in these schools to a combination of weaker macroeconomic conditions in the UAE and increased competition within this price segment. The impact of the associated decline in revenue in the Premium segment largely offset the positive revenue impact of additional enrollment in other segments during the same period. We were also adversely affected by the decision by the Dubai Executive Council to not allow private schools to raise fees in the twelve months ended 31 August 2019, resulting in lower than anticipated revenue growth in the period. _School Support Services division_ We grew revenue from the School Support Services division by $18.4 million, or 16.8%, from $109.2 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to $127.6 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, and further increased it by $52.9 million, or 41.5%, to $180.5 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. Revenue from School Support Services decreased by $5.9 million, or 4.0%, from $149.2 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 to $143.3 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. During the periods under review, school transportation revenues represented the majority of the School Support Services division’s revenues. The increase in revenue in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 was attributable to an increase in the number of students served, primarily in the transport business, as a result of enrollment growth, and further growth in average prices charged. Overall penetration rates grew during the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 in the transport business as well. Moreover, during the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 we reported a contribution from Threads for the first time following its acquisition in 2017. The increase in revenue in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 was broadly equally attributable to a continued expansion of our school transport business user base, in line with overall growth in student numbers, and an expansion in revenues from our other support services businesses. In addition, we recorded income from Hamilton Aquatics and Infracare for the first time as part of our revenues for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. Infracare largely services our own schools, and as such its revenue contribution is largely eliminated in consolidation. The decrease in revenue in the nine months ended 31 May 2019 was due to lower inter-segment revenue.

Subsubsection Text: _Percentage of revenue . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._ _14.2%_ _12.5%_ _11.2%_ _10.3%_ _10.3%_ From the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, other education and administrative expenses (excluding one-off costs) increased from $112.1 million to $115.4 million and then decreased to $114.5 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. In the same period, other education and administrative expenses (excluding one-off costs) declined as a percentage of revenue from 14.2% to 12.5% to 11.2%, respectively. From the nine months ended 31 May 2018 to the nine months ended 31 May 2019, other educational and administrative expenses (excluding one-off costs) increased by $2.5 million, from $92.9 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 to $95.4 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. Other education and administrative expenses (excluding one-off costs) include other operational costs involved in the running of schools, as well as non-staff costs of the Corporate division. We have sought to control these costs by targeting savings in utility expenses and facilities management contract expenses, as well as through smart procurement, and by leveraging an Enterprise Resource Planning system, Microsoft Dynamics AX, which was rolled out in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016. 92 ----- Since one-off costs are non-recurring in nature, these have been excluded from Adjusted EBITDA but impact net profit and operating cash flows for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, as well as the nine months ended 31 May 2018 and 2019. _Rental costs_ The following table sets out our rental costs:

Subsubsection Text: Net cash from operating activities decreased by $44.3 million, from $286.6 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to $242.3 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017. This decrease was primarily due to a $147.3 million decrease in working capital, which related to the later start of the summer term of the following academic year, which began on 10 September 2017 (ten days into the twelve months ended 31 August 2018). Net cash from operating activities decreased by $19.6 million, from $242.3 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 to $222.7 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. Subsubsection Title: Net cash used in investing activities
Subsubsection Text: Net cash used in investing activities increased by $115.5 million from $288.2 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to $403.7 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017. This increase was primarily due to the purchase of property and equipment used to open new schools and investments in schools under construction, and the repurchase of three school buildings previously held under sale and leaseback arrangements, as well as net cash outflows relating to the acquisition of businesses. Net cash used in investing activities decreased by $42.3 million, from $403.7 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 to $361.4 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. The decrease was driven by lower net cash outflows relating to the acquisition of businesses. Net cash used in investing activities decreased by $251.6 million from $317.2 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 to $65.6 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. This decrease was primarily due to lower growth capital expenditure in the nine months ended 31 May 2019.

Net cash from financing activities was $165.4 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 as compared to $116.4 million of net cash used in in financing activities in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. This decrease was primarily due to cash utilized for the repayment of the Certificates.

Subsubsection Text: As a result of the factors discussed above, we recorded an increase in profit for the year of $5.2 million, or 4.0%, from $131.5 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to $136.7 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, and a decrease of $31.8 million, or 23.3%, to $104.9 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. The decrease in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 was primarily because of IPO expenses. We recorded a decrease in profit for the period of $27.0 million, or 13.7%, from $197.4 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 to $170.4 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2019, primarily due to higher depreciation, finance costs and pre-operative expenses.

Net finance costs increased by $20.2 million, or 97.6%, from $20.7 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 to $40.9 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017. The increase in finance costs was due primarily to a $16.3 million increase in term loan interest and a $8.0 million unwinding of deferred and contingent consideration in 2017. Net finance costs increased by $14.2 million, or 34.7%, from $40.9 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 to $55.1 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. The increase in finance costs was primarily due to an increase in the amortization of loan arrangement fees. Amortization of loan arrangement fees includes an amount of $11.5 million which represents the unamortized portion of the loan arrangement fee on a previous senior facility. We repaid the previous senior facility during the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 and, as such, the related unamortized portion of the loan arrangement fee was charged to the consolidated statement of profit or loss for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. The increase in net finance costs was partially offset by a $7.2 million decrease in the unwinding of deferred and contingent consideration relating to the acquisition of Wesgreen International School. Finance income, which relates to income received from GEMS Global under a shareholder loan, remained broadly flat during the period. Net finance costs increased by $12.9 million, or 30.6% from $42.1 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 to $55.0 million in the nine months ended 31 May 2019, reflecting an increase in overall borrowings, as well as an increase in relevant base rates in the period.

Subsubsection Text: Our cash needs have historically related to costs associated with the construction and expansion of schools, the acquisition of schools, the purchase of vehicles, maintenance capital expenditure and debt service. Our principal sources of liquidity are our operating cash flow and banking facilities. 94 ----- As part of our growth strategy, we intend to continue expanding existing schools, opening new schools and acquiring individual schools. We plan to fund these business development initiatives through a mixture of operating cash flow, equity and debt funding.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In the application of our accounting policies, which are described in the notes to our interim unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements as at and for the nine months ended 31 May 2019 and Note 2.3 to our consolidated financial statements as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, management is required to make judgements, estimates and assumptions about the carrying amounts of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. The estimates and associated assumptions are based on historical experience and other factors that management considers to be relevant. Actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates and underlying assumptions are reviewed on an ongoing basis. Revisions to accounting estimates are recognized in the period in which the estimate is revised if the revision affects only that period or in the period of the revision and future periods if the revision affects both current and future periods. The following is a summary of the key accounting policies, which require management to make judgements, estimates and assumptions, and which we believe are material for potential investors. For a complete description of these and other significant accounting policies, please refer to the notes to our interim unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements as at and for the nine months ended 31 May 2019 and Note 2.3 to our consolidated financial statements as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: When another party is involved in providing goods or services to its customer, we determine whether we are a principal or agent in these transactions by evaluating the nature of our promise to the customer. We are a principal and record revenue on a gross basis if we control the promised goods or services before transferring them to the customer. However, if our role is only to arrange for another entity to provide the goods or services, then we are an agent and will need to record revenue at the net amount that we retain for our agency services. Agency services include commission income from the sale of books, canteen sales and exam fees, and is recognized in the same period as sales or services rendered.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have a loyalty points program, GEMS Rewards, which allows customers to accumulate points that can be redeemed for free services. The loyalty points give rise to a separate performance obligation as they provide a material right to the customer. A portion of the transaction price is allocated to the loyalty points awarded to customers based on relative stand-alone selling price and recognized as a contract liability until the points are redeemed. Revenue is recognized upon redemption of products by the customer. When estimating the stand-alone selling price of the loyalty points, we consider the likelihood that the customer will redeem the points. We update our estimates of the points that will be redeemed on a quarterly basis and any adjustments to the contract liability balance are charged against revenue on materiality basis.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Generally, we receive short-term advances from our customers (fee received in advance). Using the practical expedient in IFRS 15—Revenue from contracts with customers, we do not adjust the promised amount of consideration for the effects of a significant financing component if we expect, at contract inception, that the period between the transfer of the promised good or service to the customer and when the customer pays for that good or service will be one year or less.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue from contracts with customers is recognized when control of the goods or services is transferred to the customer at an amount that reflects the consideration to which we expect to be entitled in exchange for those goods and services. We have generally concluded that we are the principal in our revenue arrangements, except for the agency services below, because we typically control the goods or services before transferring them to the customer. The revenue from different contracts with customers is recognized as follows: - Tuition, annual and computer fees are recognized over the period of time the services are rendered. - Registration and admission fees are recognized at the time of enrollment. - Transportation fees are recognized over the period of time the services are rendered. - Sales of readymade garments (uniforms) is recognized when the significant risk and rewards of ownership of the goods have passed to the customer. - Facility management fees are recognized over the period of time the services are rendered. - Canteens revenues are recognized when food and beverages are served. Revenues from food distribution are recognized upon delivery to the customers. 98 ----- - Sports coaching fees and facility rental are recognized over the period of time the services are rendered or period during which facilities are rented. - Management fees are recognized over the period of time that management services are rendered. - Operation fees are recognized over the period of operations. We consider whether there are other promises in the contract that are separate performance obligations to which a portion of the transaction price needs to be allocated.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Construction in progress is stated at cost, net of accumulated impairment losses, if any. Property and equipment are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation and any impairment in value. Such cost includes the cost of replacing part of the property and equipment and borrowing costs for long-term construction projects if the recognition criteria are met. When significant parts of property and equipment are required to be replaced at intervals, we recognize such parts as individual assets with specific useful lives and depreciation, respectively. Likewise, when a major inspection is performed, our cost is recognized in the carrying amount of the property and equipment as a replacement if the recognition criteria are satisfied. All other repair and maintenance costs are recognized in the consolidated statement of profit or loss as incurred. The present value of the expected cost for the decommissioning of the asset after its use is included in the cost of the respective asset if the recognition criteria for a provision are met. Land and capital work-in-progress are not depreciated. 99 ----- Depreciation is calculated on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of the assets as follows:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Freehold/leasehold buildings and improvements . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3 to 50 years 3 to 50 years 3 to 50 years 3 to 50 years Furniture, fixtures and equipment . . . . . 3 to 5 years 3 to 5 years 3 to 7 years[(1)] 3 to 7 years[(1)] Motor vehicles . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 5 to 8 years 5 to 8 years 5 to 10 years[(1)] 5 to 10 years[(1)] Library books . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 4 years 4 years 4 years 4 years Note: (1) As at 1 September 2017, the estimated useful lives of motor vehicles and furniture, fixtures and equipment were revised by us (See Note 2.3 of our consolidated financial statements as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018). An item of property and equipment is derecognized upon disposal or when no future economic benefits are expected from its use or disposal. Any gain or loss arising on derecognition of the asset (calculated as the difference between the net disposal proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset) is included in the consolidated statement of profit or loss in the year the asset is derecognized. The carrying values of property and equipment are reviewed for impairment when events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying value may not be recoverable. If any such indication exists and where the carrying values exceed the estimated recoverable amount, the assets are written down to their recoverable amount, being the higher of their fair value less costs to sell and their value in use. Expenditure incurred to replace a component of an item of property and equipment that is accounted for separately is capitalized and the carrying amount of the component that is replaced is written-off. Other subsequent expenditure is capitalized only when it increases future economic benefits of the related item of property and equipment. All other expenditure is recognized in the consolidated statement of profit or loss as the expense is incurred. The assets’ residual values, useful lives and methods of depreciation of property and equipment are reviewed, and adjusted prospectively, if appropriate, at each financial period end.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Finance leases, which transfer to us (being the lessee) substantially all the risks and benefits incidental to ownership of the leased item, are capitalized at the inception of the lease at the fair value of the leased asset or, if lower, at the present value of the minimum lease payments. Lease payments are apportioned between the finance charges and reduction of the lease liability so as to achieve a constant rate of interest on the remaining balance of the liability. Finance charges are recognized in finance costs in the consolidated statement of profit or loss. Capitalized leased assets are depreciated over the shorter of the estimated useful life of the asset or the lease term. Leases where the lessor retains substantially all the risks and benefits of ownership of the asset are classified as operating leases. Operating lease payments are recognized as an expense by the lessee in the consolidated statement of profit or loss on a straight-line basis over the lease term.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The determination of whether an arrangement is, or contains, a lease is based on the substance of the arrangement at inception date, whether fulfillment of the arrangement is dependent on the use of a specific asset or assets or the arrangement conveys a right to use the asset, even if that right is not explicitly specified in arrangement.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: If the sale and leaseback transaction results in a finance lease, any excess of sales proceeds over the carrying amount is deferred and amortized over the lease term. If the sale and leaseback transaction results in an operating lease, any profit or loss is recognized immediately in the consolidated statement of profit or loss unless the loss is compensated by future lease payments at below market price, in which case the profit or loss is to be deferred and amortized 100 ----- in proportion to the lease payments over the period for which the asset is expected to be used. If the sale price is above fair value, the excess over the fair value is deferred and amortized over the period for which the asset is expected to be used.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: For information on the nature and effect of recent accounting pronouncements, see Note 2.2 of the consolidated financial statements as at and for the year ended 31 August 2018. In particular, the standards and interpretations that are issued, but not yet effective, as of the date of issuance of our consolidated financial statements as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 include the following. IFRS 16—Leases was issued in January 2016 and replaces IAS 17—Leases. The new standard brings most leases on the statement of financial position for lessees under a single model, eliminating the distinction between operating and finance leases. Under IFRS 16, a lessee recognizes a right-of-use asset and a lease liability. The right-of-use asset is treated similarly to other non-financial assets and is depreciated accordingly. The lease liability is initially measured at the present value of the lease payments payable over the lease term, discounted at the rate implicit in the lease if that can be readily determined. If that rate cannot be readily determined, the lessee shall use their incremental borrowing rate. Lessor accounting remains largely unchanged and the distinction between operating and finance leases is retained. IFRS 16 is expected to have a significant impact on the amounts recognized in our consolidated financial statements. On adoption of IFRS 16, we will recognize within the consolidated statement of financial position a right of use asset and lease liability for all applicable leases. Within the consolidated statement of profit or loss, rental- operating leases expense will be replaced by depreciation and finance costs. The standard will also impact a small number of measures such as operating profit and cash generated from operations, and alternative performance measures used by us. The full impact of IFRS 16 is currently under review, including understanding the practical application of the principles of the standard. It is therefore not practical to provide a reasonable estimate of the financial effect until this review is complete. We plan to adopt the new standard from the financial year beginning on 1 September 2019.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to various financial risks, including interest rate risk, credit risk and liquidity risk. These risks and the manner in which we seek to mitigate them are summarized below and described in more detail in the notes to the interim condensed consolidated financial statements as at and for the nine months ended 31 May 2019.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value of future cash flows of financial instruments will fluctuate because of a change in interest rates. We are not exposed to any significant interest rate risk on our interest-bearing assets (short-term deposits) and liabilities (fixed interest rate vehicle loans and other term loans). Our exposure to the risk of changes in market interest rates relates primarily to our longterm debt obligations with floating interest rates.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk that one party to a financial instrument will fail to discharge an obligation and cause the other party to incur a financial loss. We are exposed to credit risk principally on our bank balances. We seek to limit our credit risk with respect to students’ fees by regularly monitoring outstanding fees receivable. We limit our credit risk with regard to bank deposits by only dealing with reputable banks. Credit risk is limited to the carrying values of financial assets in the consolidated statement of financial position. With respect to credit risk arising from our other financial assets, including cash and cash equivalents, and derivative instruments, our exposure to credit risk arises from default of the counterparty, with a maximum exposure equal to the carrying amount of these instruments.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that we will have insufficient cash to settle amounts due by us at any time. 101 ----- We limit our liquidity risk by ensuring that bank facilities or related party funds are available. The terms of admission of students of the educational entities require fees to be paid within the academic term or on a monthly basis. Trade payables are settled on the basis of credit terms agreed with the respective suppliers. Our terms of invoices require amounts to be paid within 30 days of the date of invoice. See the notes to the audited consolidated financial statements as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 for more detail on the maturity profile of our undiscounted financial liabilities as at 31 August 2018.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Currency risk is the risk that the fair value of future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because of changes in foreign exchange rates. We are not exposed to any significant currency risk as the majority of our transactions and balances are denominated in AED, which is pegged to the U.S. dollar.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We set an appropriate capital management strategy. The primary objective of our capital management is to ensure that we maintain healthy capital ratios in order to support our business and maximize shareholder value. We manage our capital structure and make adjustments to it in light of changes in economic conditions. No changes were made in the objectives, policies or processes during the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017, 2018 and in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. Capital comprises the share capital, restricted reserve, share-based payment reserve, cash flow hedge reserve, foreign currency translation reserve, retained earnings/(accumulated losses), subordinated perpetual certificates and non-controlling interests and was $124.0 million as at 31 August 2016, $231.4 million as at 31 August 2017, $233.7 million as at 31 August 2018 and $197.4 million as at 31 May 2019. 102 -----

Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion is intended to convey management’s perspective on our results of operations and financial condition as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and the nine months ended 31 May 2018 and 2019, reported in accordance with IFRS. All references to “we,” “us” or “our” in respect of historical consolidated financial information in this discussion are to the Group on a consolidated basis. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” The following discussion should be read in conjunction with our historical consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, the related notes and the information relating to our business thereto included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum as well as the “Selected Historical Financial Information.” The discussion includes forward-looking statements that reflect the current view of our management and involves risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statements as a result of factors discussed below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, particularly in “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.” Investors should read the whole of this Offering Memorandum and not just rely upon summarized information. Subsection Title: The international private K-12 English-language education market
Subsubsection Text: GEMS Education competes in the international private K-12 English-language education market, which is large, growing and distinguished by several attractive characteristics. In 2018, the total global education market size was estimated at close to $6.5 trillion. K-12, which focuses on educating students from ages 3 to 19, is the largest segment, representing 50% of the total market size. The global K-12 market is projected to grow at a 5% CAGR from 2018 to 2030, driven by student enrollment and tuition fees. International private K-12 English-language schools are a subset of this market and provide a curriculum to students wholly or partly in the English language outside an English-speaking country, or offer an English-medium curriculum other than the country’s national curriculum. This segment of the K-12 market is our primary focus, and is expected to grow at a rapid pace, underpinned by a 10% CAGR of school fee income from 2018-2028, which is in turn driven by student enrollment and tuition fees. The following graphs set out the estimated CAGR for international school fee income, as well as for enrollment from 2000 to 2028.

2000 2019 2028E _Source: Market Data_ Note: (1) A school is an international school if it delivers a curriculum to students wholly or partly in the English language outside an English-speaking country, or if the school is in a country where English is one of the official languages and offers an English-medium curriculum other than the country’s national curriculum. The UAE is the largest international private K-12 English-language education market globally, by number of students and by revenue. By comparison, in 2017 there were approximately the same number of K-12 students in the UK private sector, (620,000), as there were UAE international private English-language students (605,000). Moreover, all of the top six cities globally by enrollment in international schools are in the GCC (Dubai, Abu Dhabi, Riyadh, Doha, Sharjah and Jeddah). We own and operate schools in four of those cities (Dubai, Abu Dhabi, Doha and Sharjah). The following table sets out K-12 revenue by market and price segment for 2018:

We believe the international private K-12 English-language education market is characterized by a number of factors, including:

Many parents consider their children’s education to be a non-discretionary expenditure and will generally give priority to the quality and continuity of their children’s education over pricing considerations. Consequently, they seek schools that provide high academic and pastoral care standards, modern facilities and a broad range of extra-curricular activities. 104 |Dubai|Rev Growth Enrolment (15- 18) Growth (15-18) Both Dubai and Abu Dhabi have ~2.3bn significant 13% 4% proportion USD: <5k USD: 5-10k USD: 10-20k USD: 20+k of mid-priced segments, unlike Singapore and Hong Kong, ~1.1bn 15% 5% which are primarily USD: <5k USD: 5-10k USD: 10-15k USD: 15+k ‘expensive’ schools markets ~1.2bn 9% 3% USD: 10K-16k USD: 16-22k USD: 22-27k USD: 27+k ~0.6bn 9% 4% USD: 10K-16k USD: 16-24k USD: >24k ~0.4bn 12% 5% USD: 2.5-6k USD: 6-12k USD: >12k|Enrolment Growth (15-18)| |---|---|---| |Abu Dhabi||| |Singapore||| |Hong Kong||| |HCMC||| -----

Subsection Title: Weak/weakening K-12 public education offerings in many markets
Subsubsection Text: In certain markets, government underfunding of public schools leads to issues such as aging infrastructure, large class sizes and poor academic performance, all of which can lead parents to seek private school alternatives.

The international private K-12 English-language education market has high barriers to entry, which makes it challenging for new entrants to compete effectively and gain market share from incumbent operators. While there are some variations across countries, these barriers generally include: - the time required to build brand recognition and reputation, both on a local and regional basis; - challenges securing government licenses and regulatory approvals; - the scarcity of real estate in commercially viable areas that can accommodate a sizeable campus with the comprehensive and high-quality facilities parents and students expect; - the tendency for students to stay in the same school until graduation or their family moves away; - difficulty in hiring and retaining highly qualified education professionals; and - significant benefits of scale in terms of market insight and function/system centralization.

Subsection Title: Long-term model with low funding risk
Subsubsection Text: The building and operating of an international private K-12 English-language school requires longterm capital investment. For example, while the average GEMS school typically breaks even within three to five years, on a school-level Adjusted EBITDA basis, time to break even across the industry can be much later. In addition, the recurring, visible nature of student enrollment and generally predictable ramp-up of enrollment lessens the funding risk for an operator. This is especially true for companies which have a history of opening schools and can draw on previous experience and market insights.

Subsection Title: Fragmented market with few operators of scale
Subsubsection Text: The international private K-12 English-language education market is highly fragmented and, while there are a small number of global multi-school operators, such as GEMS Education, SABIS, Nord Anglia, Curro, Cognita, and International Schools Partnership, the majority of private K-12 schools are operated by single-school operators. In such a highly fragmented market, the scale, expertise, resources and experience of multi-school operators provide a competitive advantage over singleschool operators.

The UAE private K-12 market is large and growing. In total, the estimated revenue of the UAE private K-12 education market in 2017 was $4.4 billion. In 2018, revenue for the private international K-12 segment was $3.4 billion, and this segment is forecast to grow at approximately 10% per year for the next five years. Of this $3.4 billion, Dubai represented $2.3 billion of the market value and Abu Dhabi represented $1.1 billion. The following graph sets out the breakdown of the historical and projected total revenue in private international K-12 schools in Dubai and Abu Dhabi, in billions of dollars. 105 ----- The following table sets out historic and projected total revenue in private international schools in Dubai and Abu Dhabi from 2015 to 2023:
