Subsubsection Text: AY 2015 AY 2018 AY 2023F Dubai Abu Dhabi _Source: Market Data Note: AY23F numbers have been estimated assuming growth in fee same as historical._ Forecast growth in the UAE private education sector is supported by several positive underlying trends. UAE GDP is expected to grow at approximately a 3% CAGR over the next five years, due to stabilizing oil prices, infrastructure spend and easing fiscal consolidation. In addition, parents in the region are increasingly seeking better quality education for their children and are showing a growing willingness to spend on education, particularly within national populations. Notably, despite free education, approximately 60% of Emiratis choose private education for better quality of teaching and learning outcomes. The publication of school ratings and increased transparency on performance provides parents with increased visibility on education quality and has further supported continued growth in private education. Finally, the sizeable expatriate population in the UAE continues to grow steadily, and expatriates account for approximately 80% to 90% of private enrollment in Dubai and Abu Dhabi. Government privatization initiatives are also supportive of future growth in the private education sector. Further private investment in education will likely be required to ease the strain on tightening government budgets. Alongside a desire by governments to improve educational outcomes, this is expected to result in the private sector playing an increasing role in education reform.
Enrollment volumes and pricing are the key market drivers in the private K-12 education market, as discussed below.

Enrollment growth in the UAE is primarily driven by population growth and the shift among students from public to private schools: - **Population growth—the UAE region has historically experienced high population growth, as compared to Western Europe and globally, with 2011-2017 CAGRs of 5% and 6% in Dubai and Abu Dhabi respectively. The region is expected to continue to exceed Western European and global population growth, with estimated CAGRs from 2017 to 2030 of 5% and 4% in Dubai and Abu Dhabi, respectively; and - **Public-to-private shift—the percentage of students enrolled in private schools varies significantly across GCC countries, but uptake is high in the UAE, as discussed below. As public education 106 ----- offerings continue to face challenges, it is expected that there will be a continued shift in enrollment from public to private schools, including in countries that already have comparatively higher levels of private school enrollments, such as the UAE.

There are three factors which impact tuition fee pricing in the UAE: - **Annual price inflation—each market in the GCC has a different regional education regulator which has its own fee escalation governance regime. Prices have historically risen ahead of inflation and each of our markets has a fee mechanism in place, which is further described in “Regulation Overview.” - **Grade aging—irrespective of annual tuition fee increases, older children in higher grades in school will typically have higher tuition fees than younger children in lower grades in the same school. Therefore, as the child population at a certain school or in a certain market gets older and the percentage of older children in the private school market becomes greater, the average tuition fee for that school or market increases. - **Portfolio mix—there is a wide range of school alternatives at differing price points in the private K- 12 education market in the UAE. Pricing levels for certain operators and average tuition fee levels in these markets will therefore be driven by distribution of students from premium to mid-market schools.

Subsection Title: The Dubai education market The K-12 education market in Dubai
Subsubsection Text: Dubai is the largest individual school market in the Middle East. Dubai has 277 total schools serving approximately 290,000 students, of which 91% are enrolled in private schools. The following graphs set out the split between public and private schools and public and private students, respectively. The following graphs set out the split between public and private schools and enrollments, respectively. in the 2018-2019 academic year.

_Source: Market Data_ The following table sets out student enrollments for the Dubai market as a whole as well as for us from the 2011-2012 academic year through the 2018-2019 academic year. **2011- 2012 2012- 2013 2013- 2014 2014- 2015 2015- 2016 2016- 2017 2017- 2018 2018- 2019** Dubai total student enrollments . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 204,721 223,085 242,866 254,121 263,652 272,943 281,432 289,195 GEMS Education student enrollments – Dubai . . . . . . . 50,132 55,727 62,652 66,761 69,278 73,288 77,023 79,060 GEMS Education market share (%) . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 24.5 25.0 25.8 26.3 26.3 26.9 27.4 27.3 _Source: KHDA Data_ 107 ----- While we represented 27.3% of the market in Dubai, based on enrollments in the 2018-2019 academic year, the rest of the market is highly fragmented, with the second largest operator, Indian High School, representing only 4.3% of the market. The Dubai population has grown strongly: between 2011 and 2018, during which period the Emirati population grew by approximately 5% and the expatriate population (and total population) grew by approximately 7%. In Abu Dhabi, these groups grew at 4% and 7% CAGR over the same period, respectively. While population growth is expected to moderate, expatriates are staying longer and having more children in the region, thereby driving the growth of student-aged children in the region. Further, the percentage of the population aged 14 or younger has increased in the UAE, but remains below the OECD average and provides opportunity for future school enrollment growth, as set out in the following graph.

UAE 2010 UAE 2018 OECD 2018 Between 2011, when the KHDA first began publishing market data, and the 2018-2019 school year, student enrollment in Dubai grew at a 5.5% CAGR, outpacing the overall UAE population growth rate, which grew at a CAGR of 1.1% over the period. This 53% increase in number of students, from 189,000 to 290,000, was addressed by the opening of 70 new schools over the period.

The Dubai private school market is expected to grow from $2.3 billion in 2018 to $3.5 billion in 2023, representing a 10% CAGR. The average tuition fee per student is expected to grow at a 4% CAGR from 2017 to 2023, boosted by an increased contribution from more expensive curricula and the student grade aging effect. Dubai’s education market is supported by the “Vision 2021” initiative, which is intended to pave the way for Dubai’s transition to becoming an international hub for knowledge-based activity, innovation and sustainable industrial activities. Vision 2021 sets out a number of education-related targets, including: - all schools, universities and students to be equipped with “smart” systems and devices; - significant investments to promote enrollment in preschools; - improve rank in reading, mathematics and science examination scores, and have a strong knowledge of the Arabic language; - elevate the rate of graduation from secondary schools to international standards; and - all schools to have exceptional leadership and internationally accredited teaching staff. The government of Dubai has also announced a commitment to improving education outcomes for Emiratis, including through the increased use of private schools. 2015 Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study (“TIMSS”) scores show that Emiratis in private schools, whether using the British or MoE curriculum, perform better than Emiratis in MoE public schools. This commitment to increasing the enrollment of Emiratis in private schools is expected to drive increased penetration of Emiratis in private schools, from 56% in 2017 to 66% in 2023. We estimate that if the number of students in international private K-12 schools continues to grow at a 4% CAGR from 2017 to 2023, and utilization stays constant at 90%, this will require the market to add an additional 80,000 seats of capacity, or approximately 30 to 40 new schools based on the current average size of Dubai schools. 108 -----

Abu Dhabi is a smaller market than Dubai and its private education market was worth an estimated $1.1 billion in 2018. There are currently 442 schools, serving approximately 373,000 students, of which approximately 67% are enrolled in private schools. The following graphs set out the split between public and private schools and enrollments, respectively, in the 2016-2017 academic year.

Subsubsection Text: _Source: Market Data_ From 2018 to 2023, the private education market in Abu Dhabi is expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 10%, from $1.1 billion to $1.6 billion, driven by increasing tuition fees and a rise in the proportion of private school students.

In the 2017-18 academic year, there were over 28,000 K-12 equivalent schools in the United Kingdom. The number of primary schools has declined by 1% (206 schools) over the past five years. However, the number of primary school pupils increased by 8.6%, from 5.1 million pupils to 5.5 million over the same period. The number of secondary school pupils increased by 31,400 (0.8%) from the 2012-13 academic year to 3.9 million in the 2017-18 academic year. Over the same period, the number of secondary schools also increased by 2.8% (113) to 4,190 schools. It is estimated that as of January 2018, the private sector, comprised of independent schools, accounted for approximately 620,000 students, or 6% of all UK school pupils, across 2,444 schools, or 8.2% of total schools in the UK. In 2017, independent schools generated revenues of £9.8 billion. The following graphs set out the split between public and private schools and enrollments, respectively, in the 2018-2019 academic year.

We are the world’s leading provider of private K-12 English-language education by revenues, operating in the UAE and Qatar. We are particularly focused on the UAE, the largest private education market in the world by revenue. Concurrently with the Offering, we are acquiring a 92.9% shareholding in Bellevue from an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of the Varkey Group, one of our indirect shareholders. Bellevue operates 15 schools, of which 14 are in the United Kingdom and one is in Switzerland.

Subsection Title: Our Business in the United Arab Emirates and Qatar
Subsubsection Text: As at 31 May 2019, the School Operations division operated 48 GEMS-branded schools throughout the GCC, of which 46 were in the UAE and two were in Qatar. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, the School Operations division accounted for 86.2% of our revenues and 90.3% of our Adjusted EBITDA (before inter-segmental eliminations). The schools are strategically located in residential 110 ----- catchment areas and are categorized into the following three price points based on a number of factors, including quality of facilities, average class size and tuition fees charged: - Premium schools, which from the lowest grade to the highest grade typically charge tuition fees of between $15,000 and $30,000 annually per student. Our Premium schools (16 as at 31 May 2019) provide access to each of the four curricula offered by us and accounted for 49.2% of the School Operations division’s revenue in the nine months ended 31 May 2019; - Mid-Market Plus schools, which from the lowest grade to the highest grade typically charge tuition fees of between $5,000 and $15,000 annually per student. Our Mid-Market Plus schools (12 as at 31 May 2019) provide access primarily to the British curriculum, with a limited number offering the Indian or American curricula and accounted for 21.3% of the School Operations division’s revenue in the nine months ended 31 May 2019; and - Mid-Market schools, which from the lowest grade to the highest grade typically charge tuition fees of between $2,000 and $7,000 annually per student. Our Mid-Market schools (20 as at 31 May 2019) provide access to the Indian and British curricula and accounted for 29.9% of the School Operations division’s revenue in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. In addition to the schools we own, we also manage two private schools in Abu Dhabi on behalf of the ruling family. These management services include assisting in the hiring of senior management teams and providing periodic quality assurances and inspections. While we are responsible for overseeing the general financial and operational performance of these schools, we do not directly employ the staff, control or influence the physical infrastructure of managed schools or fund the capital expenditure at the schools. We receive management fees for undertaking these services, but do not consolidate the operational (e.g. enrollment and capacity) or financial results (e.g. revenue and costs) of the managed schools in our financial statements. Revenue from the management fees earned is accounted for under our Corporate division.

Subsection Title: Our Business in the United Arab Emirates and Qatar
Subsubsection Text: The School Support Services division provides a comprehensive range of educational business services under various GEMS-owned brands, which complement our core education offering. These services include school bus and other transportation, school uniform sales, school catering sports management services, after-school activities, school catering, school security services and teacher training. Our School Support Services division also provides services to non-GEMS schools in the UAE. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, the School Support Services division accounted for 13.8% of our revenues and 18.9% of our Adjusted EBITDA (before inter-segmental eliminations).

Subsection Title: Our Business in the United Arab Emirates and Qatar
Subsubsection Text: The Corporate division allows us to leverage the benefits of scale by providing our centralized support service functions, including finance, legal, information technology, business development and human resources. Revenue from the schools we manage but do not own is accounted for in the Corporate division.

Subsection Title: Our Business in the United Arab Emirates and Qatar
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the Offering, we are acquiring a 92.9% shareholding in Bellevue from an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of the Varkey Group, one of our indirect shareholders. Bellevue operates 15 schools, of which 14 are in the United Kingdom, and one is in Switzerland. For further information on Bellevue, see “Business—Our Business—UK School Bellevue.” As at 31 May 2019, Bellevue educated 2,717 students.

Subsection Title: Our Business in the United Arab Emirates and Qatar
Subsubsection Text: Founded by Mr. Sunny Varkey and beginning with a single school in Dubai, we have been a pioneer of the UAE’s education system. As at 31 May 2019, we offered a diverse range of educational choices through 48 schools across three price points, Premium, Mid-Market Plus and Mid-Market, and four curricula, British, Indian, American and International Baccalaureate (“IB”). While over half of our schools teach the British curriculum, our students come from more than 170 countries, with British nationals representing only approximately 2% of our current students. As at 31 May 2019, 123,368 students were enrolled in our schools. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, students paid tuition fees ranging from $2,000 to $30,000 per student per annum and, for the twelve months ended 31 May 2019, we generated ARPS of $8,494. We also provide a comprehensive range of school support services, including school bus transportation, school uniform sales, sports management services, after-school activities, school catering, school security services and teacher training. We pride ourselves on providing consistently high-quality education and student outcomes, irrespective of a school’s price point, and our students have consistently outperformed their global peers in standardized examinations. For example, as at the date of this Offering Memorandum, 93% of our rated schools in Dubai (collectively, “Rated Schools”) were designated as “outstanding,” “very good” or “good” by the KHDA, the Dubai education regulator. As at 31 August 2018, the last period when comparable data was available, only 61% of non-GEMS schools were so rated in Dubai. According to data provided by the KHDA, we had a market share by enrollment in Dubai of 27.3% for the 2018–2019 academic year and our school portfolio had over three times the number of students as the Dubai public education system. Our commitment to providing high quality education through all of our curricula and price points has helped to drive our uninterrupted growth in enrollment and revenues for over 15 years. We have grown enrollment and revenues consistently, including during and after the global financial crisis in 2008, and during periods of regional conflict. From the twelve months ended 31 August 2006 to the nine months ended 31 May 2019, student enrollment grew at a CAGR of 8.1% and school revenue grew at a CAGR of 17.5%, in each case exceeding the CAGR of UAE GDP and the UAE’s population growth of 5.3% and 5.1% over the same period, respectively. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018, we had revenue of $789.7 million, $926.2 million and $1,022.5 million, respectively. Over the same periods, our Adjusted EBITDA was $212.8 million, $262.2 million and $282.6 million, respectively. In the nine months ended 31 May 2018 and 2019, we had revenue of $904.9 million and $928.0 million, respectively. Over the same periods, our Adjusted EBITDA was $306.0 million and $302.2 million, respectively. We currently operate through three business divisions corresponding to our financial reporting segments: (i) School Operations; (ii) School Support Services; and (iii) Corporate. Once we complete the Acquisition, we will operate Bellevue Education as a fourth division.

On 10 July 2019 we signed the Senior Facilities Agreement with Goldman Sachs Bank USA, Citigroup Global Markets Limited, Credit Suisse Loan Funding LLC, Credit Suisse AG, London Branch and HSBC Bank Middle East Limited. For additional details, see “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.”_ 111 -----

Subsubsection Title: Acquisition of Bellevue from Varkey Global
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the Offering, we are acquiring a 92.9% shareholding in Bellevue from an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of the Varkey Group, one of our indirect shareholders. Bellevue operates 15 schools, of which 14 are in the United Kingdom, and one is in Switzerland. As at 31 May 2019, Bellevue educated 2,717 students. For further information on Bellevue, see “—Business—Bellevue.”

We have exchanged contracts to buy Farlington School, an independent day and boarding school for pupils between ages four and eighteen in Horsham. We will pay approximately £0.9 million at completion on a debt-free cash free basis to the current owners, a charitable trust. Farlington was originally founded in 1896 and educates 233 students. The acquisition will be funded from existing cash resources and we anticipate completing in early September 2019. The property is leased, but we have an option to buy it within three years.

Subsubsection Title: Announcement of new KHDA fee framework and exceptional fee increases in the UAE
Subsubsection Text: In April 2019, the KHDA announced a revised fee framework for Dubai Schools. The fee framework allows schools with a rating of Acceptable or higher to increase fees by 2.07% for the 2019-2020 academic year. We will apply this fee increase to 26 of our 28 Dubai schools where we are eligible to do so. In one school we will apply the increase for only junior grades. For further information on fee frameworks, see “Regulation Overview—United Arab Emirates.” In addition, we have received permission for exceptional fee increases for the 2019-2020 academic year outside of the KHDA framework in seven schools in total, of which four are in Dubai, two are in Sharjah and one is in Abu Dhabi.

Subsubsection Title: Start of the 2019-2020 academic year in Indian curriculum-based schools
Subsubsection Text: In April 2019, our Indian curriculum-based schools started the 2019-2020 academic year. Even though capacity utilization within our Indian curriculum-based schools is the highest in our portfolio, we managed to increase the enrollment where there was capacity to do so. In April 2019, we also merged two schools, Our Own Boys School (“OOB”) and New Our Own English Private School (“EPS”), both mid-market Indian curriculum-based schools, on the site of EPS, in Sharjah. This merger allowed us to better utilize the newer facilities of the EPS site, which was developed during the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. We intend to refurbish the school buildings of the former OOB site into a new midmarket British curriculum-based school at a higher price point, which is scheduled to open in September 2019. We believe that the mid-market British curriculum-based offering is increasingly favored by parents in the UAE over monocultural Indian schooling. In addition, in April 2019 we reduced capacity, and therefore opening enrollment, at the Indian curriculum-based school Our Own Girls School (“OOS”) at the request of that school’s regulator, the SPEA. Concurrently, we secured an exceptional fee increase for this school. In the aggregate, the impact of the merger of OOB and EPS and the reduction of capacity at OOS largely offset enrollment growth in our expanding Indian curriculum-based schools. As a result, we anticipate net enrollment in our Indian curriculum-based schools will remain largely flat between the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 and 2019.

CVC Funds have led the CVC Consortium, which has agreed to acquire a significant minority stake in GMHL. Upon completion of the transaction, the CVC Consortium will acquire a 30.5% stake from existing shareholders for an aggregate consideration of approximately $1.3 billion. The transaction is anticipated to close by the end of July 2019. The transaction will result in the exit by a consortium led by Fajr, including Blackstone and Mumtalakat, which acquired a significant minority stake in GMHL in 2014. Existing minority investor Khazanah, which invested in January 2018, will retain its 3% stake in GMHL.

Subsubsection Title: Outlook for the twelve months ending 31 August 2020
Subsubsection Text: As at the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have largely completed the 2019-2020 academic year re-enrollment campaign for our British, American and IB curricula-based schools. During this campaign, parents are asked to pay a re-enrollment fee in order to be allocated a position in the coming academic year. This re-enrollment fee is generally offset against the coming semester’s tuition fee invoice. 112 ----- On a like-for-like basis, as at the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have secured a higher number of re-enrollment intentions for these schools than at the same date in the prior academic year. In particular, the absolute number of re-enrollment indications, and the percentage of students seeking to re-enroll in our Premium schools segment, is higher than in the prior year. As such, we anticipate a lower churn rate in our British, American and IB curricula-based schools than in the prior academic year. Additionally, we continue to market our schools to new students (“new joiners”). We calculate new joiners based on the twelve months to 30 June. The overall number of new joiners as of 30 June 2019 was slightly ahead of the number of new joiners as of 30 June 2018, and we additionally expect further new joiners to be attracted to our new school GCS, which we intend to open in September 2019. Nevertheless, we anticipate that the number of students in our Premium schools will be modestly lower in the twelve months ending 31 August 2020 than in the twelve months ending 31 August 2019, given subdued volumes of new joiners into the premium segment.

Subsubsection Title: We operate a leading global K-12 English-language education platform with significant competitive advantages and high barriers to entry
Subsubsection Text: We are the world’s largest provider of private K-12 English-language education. In Dubai, where the majority of our operations are based, we had approximately 80,000 students in the nine months ended 31 May 2019, making us more than six times larger than our next nearest competitor. We have also grown faster than our nearest rival in Dubai, with an enrollment CAGR from the 2010-2011 academic year to the 2018-2019 academic year of 7.0%, as compared to 3.8% for our nearest rival and 5.3% for the Dubai market as a whole. The following graphs set out our size as compared to our competitors and enrollment CAGR data for us and our nearest competitors in Dubai:

Subsubsection Title: Number of Students, thousands_** **_2011 – 2019 enrollment CAGR
Subsubsection Text: _Source: KHDA, 2019_ The large scale of our operations provides numerous benefits, including: - a high degree of market insight driven by our detailed visibility over the large numbers of students in our schools, as well as the volume of enquiries we receive; - the ability to efficiently allocate excess demand for our schools into other GEMS schools with available capacity; - the ability to rapidly spread best practices throughout our school portfolio, in particular through cost management and performance benchmarking; - the cost-effective use of centralized support functions, such as finance, legal, information technology, business development, recruitment, maintenance and human resources, to support large numbers of schools simultaneously; and - the ability to attract talented teaching professionals from around the world. 113 ----- We believe that we have a long-term track record of, and reputation for, delivering high-quality education. Although most of our students do not use English as their first language, they have consistently outperformed their global peers in standardized examinations across our curricula, including for UK A levels, average IB diploma score, Indian Central Board of Secondary Education (“CBSE”) pass rates and results in the Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study (“TIMSS”). Our graduates have been accepted to all eight Ivy League universities, all of the top 50 UK universities and 1,050 universities in 53 countries. This track record of academic outperformance has strengthened our brand and reputation in our markets, allowing us to fill available capacity at new schools, maintain high levels of student re-enrollment and further improve our academic profile. Our teachers and senior administrative staff are highly qualified and experienced, and are recruited through a rigorous hiring process which we manage centrally. We are one of the largest employers of British, North American and Indian teachers outside of their respective home countries, and in the nine months ended 31 May 2019, we received approximately 65,000 applications for the approximately 1,300 teaching positions we had available, enabling us to be highly selective in hiring staff. This selectivity has allowed us to recruit a diverse and talented teacher base, with teachers coming from over 90 countries and a wide variety of specialist fields. We attract this quantity of high quality teaching applications because of our international scale, strong brand, reputation for quality and competitive compensation packages. We emphasize ongoing professional development through our teacher training program, operated by TELLAL, a GEMS brand and the first fully accredited teacher training institute in the UAE, which is certified to grant teaching qualifications recognized both in the UAE and globally. Over half of our teachers have been with us for more than three years, and our teacher turnover rates are below the industry average for Dubai, and we believe that our commitment to professional development is key to maintaining these strong teacher retention rates. We are a trusted partner for key stakeholders in the education sector, including regulatory bodies, teachers, parents and real estate developers. In particular, our NPS from parents has doubled over the past year to 14, with 37% of our students’ parents scoring their child’s school as a nine or ten out of ten. Our reputation and credibility with these stakeholders provide numerous benefits, including high demand for our services, access to high quality teachers and access to strategically located land for school construction. We benefit from the strategic location of our schools in proximity to residential areas in the UAE. Furthermore, our reputation and relationships with stakeholders provide us with early access to desirable locations for the development of new schools, and our land bank allows us to strategically hold properties at a low cost until the development opportunity matures. Our existing scale, financial resources, operational experience and deep institutional knowledge allows us to better address certain structural hurdles in expanding in existing markets and entering new markets compared to other operators. For instance, significant financial resources are required in order to invest in new school facilities or to acquire existing schools. Our broad experience coupled with our strong understanding of the local markets facilitates our ability to meet legal, financial and other requirements in securing government licenses and regulatory approvals in multiple jurisdictions. Additionally, centralized expertise and local knowledge helps us address the issue of the scarcity of suitable sites in key markets and the tendency of property developers and landlords to prefer operators with a strong track record and financial resources. Our long and positive track record and established reputation underpins our ability to recruit and retain high quality teachers, particularly in expatriate markets.

Subsubsection Title: We operate in the largest private K-12 market in the world with the most attractive growth trends
Subsubsection Text: The UAE private K-12 market is large and growing. In total, the estimated revenue of the UAE private K-12 education market in 2017 was $4.4 billion. In 2018, revenue for the private international K-12 segment was $3.4 billion, and this segment is forecast to grow at approximately 10% per year for the next five years. Of this $3.4 billion, Dubai represented $2.3 billion of the market value and Abu Dhabi represented $1.1 billion. This growth has been driven by several economic and political growth trends, including historic population growth and economic expansion, a young, skilled population, increasing population stickiness, government focus on quality education and ongoing price and cost inflation. The UAE has several structural advantages with respect to the education sector, including: - a high degree of private school penetration in K-12 education; - private schools provide the highest quality of education; 114 ----- - UAE private schools focus on residents, who generally stay longer than non-residents; and - most students in the UAE are young and, because of this, private school enrollments generally ramp up from the lowest grades onwards. The following graph sets out private K-12 enrollments by country:
We believe that our competitive strengths are as follows:

Subsubsection Title: We operate a vertically integrated business model, offering a wide variety of services which drive revenue diversification and expand our addressable market
Subsubsection Text: We have a diversified business model, generating revenue through our School Operations division as well as our School Support Services division. In addition, on completion of the Acquisition, we will also generate revenue through our Bellevue division. Our School Operations division provides a diversified offering across multiple curricula (British, Indian, American and IB) and price points (Premium, Mid-Market Plus and MidMarket). This diversity of offering expands our addressable market by allowing us to provide offerings that are attractive to parents across a variety of socioeconomic groups. This diversity also decreases our reliance on any one socioeconomic group, thereby decreasing volatility in enrollment numbers. The following chart illustrates the differences between our Mid-Market, Mid-Market Plus and Premium schools: 115 ----- The School Operations division is complemented by our School Support Services division, which offers a variety of education-related support services to our students as well as third parties. We are able to provide services and drive revenue throughout the school day, from selling school uniforms, to transporting children to and from school, to providing sports management services and other extracurricular activities after education has ended for the day. The acquisition of Bellevue, which operates 15 schools, of which 14 are in the United Kingdom and one is in Switzerland, as well as the acquisition of Farlington School in the United Kingdom, will further diversify our schools offering and provide us with a more geographically diversified revenue base.

Subsection Title: Number of K-12 Students by Country** **Private K-12 School Enrolled in International Schools in 2018 (‘000)** **Enrollment (‘000) in 2018 644 5,700
Subsubsection Title: Our attractive and profitable business model delivers high revenue visibility and sustained profitability and cash flow conversion
Subsubsection Text: We have high visibility over student enrollment levels for upcoming academic years well before they begin. We initiate our re-enrollment campaigns for British, American and IB curricula-based schools in February, far ahead of the start of the school year in September. Historically, we have achieved a reenrollment rate of approximately 80% by May for these curricula. Moreover, at a majority of our schools, the terms and conditions of enrollment require a full term’s notice of withdrawal for a refund of prepaid tuition. The following graph, based on representative data from prior year results, demonstrates our build-up of the enrollment budget for the 2019 academic year. It demonstrates how we progressively build visibility over opening enrollment levels for the upcoming academic year by collecting both re-enrollment intentions from existing students, and securing enrollments from new joiners.

Subsubsection Title: We benefit from a well-invested portfolio with low capital intensity, which is positioned for growth
Subsubsection Text: Between September 2013 and February 2019, we opened 18 schools. Since 1 September 2015, we have invested approximately $1.1 billion in capital expenditures on the construction and development of these schools. These Maturing Schools and New Schools are now built and require no further significant investment to maintain current capacity levels. As of 31 May 2019, these schools had an aggregate unfilled capacity of approximately 22,000 seats, leaving substantial room for additional student enrollments without the need for further investment in capacity expansion. Furthermore, ARPS at these Maturing Schools and New Schools are generally higher than those at Mature Schools, even within similar price brackets, reflecting the overall fee inflation across the market. Taken together, these factors are expected to allow Maturing Schools and New Schools to contribute material Adjusted EBITDA growth at minimal incremental cost. The following graphs set forth our capacity utilization of Maturing schools by cohort year of opening, as at 31 August 2017 and as at 31 May 2019:

Subsection Title: May c.80% of re-enrolment indications achieved + Start of Indian curriculum September 100% of opening enrolment
Subsubsection Text: Oct Nov Dec Jan Feb Mar Apr May Jun Jul Aug Sep Our market share in Dubai allows us a high degree of visibility over the shape of demand across the market (e.g., by price point). In the last three fiscal years, approximately half of our revenue growth was driven by regulated yearly fee increases, which are in turn dependent (in Dubai, our largest market) on the ECI and the school ratings published by the KHDA. As the ECI for an academic year is published in advance and the DSIB typically publishes school ratings for the upcoming academic year in April or May, we generally have time to plan for the permitted fee levels at each of our schools and manage our cost base accordingly. See “—Our Business—The School Operations division—Tuition _fee increases”. For example, we learned in June 2018 that we were not permitted to increase fees in_ our Dubai schools for the following academic year and, as a result, we focused on reducing our cost base in advance of the following academic year. 116 ----- We benefit from strong Adjusted EBITDA margins, which reflect the significant benefits of our scale, our high degree of revenue visibility and our efficient and controlled cost base. Fifteen of our schools began operating between September 2013 and August 2017 (“Maturing Schools”) and three of our schools began operating in September 2017 or later (“New Schools”). Both those schools which began operating prior to September 2013 (“Mature Schools”) and Maturing Schools have grown enrollment year-on-year between the twelve months ended 31 August 2016 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019. Occupancy levels for our Maturing Schools increased year-on-year over the same period. We benefit from low non-discretionary capital expenditures (mainly in relation to maintenance investments and support services, primarily transportation). We enjoy favorable working capital dynamics, due to parents prepaying tuition fees for the upcoming school semester or year, although the year-end position can be impacted by the start date of the new school year. We also benefit from a favorable tax regime, as the UAE does not currently impose income or corporate tax on our business. Furthermore, we benefit from a zero VAT-rating for school fees and certain other services we provide.

Subsubsection Title: We are Founder-sponsored and led by an experienced, professional executive management team
Subsubsection Text: We were founded by the Varkey Family in 1968 and have benefited from their deep knowledge and understanding of the education sector, which has allowed us to take advantage of the growth opportunities in our markets. In particular, we have benefited from our Executive Vice Chairman, Sunny Varkey’s, deep knowledge of the sector and strong relationships with relevant education stakeholders in the UAE. Our school management team has deep educational and operational management expertise at the corporate and school levels. Our entire corporate education team has held positions of leadership responsibility in schools and/or regulatory education authorities. Our principals and other senior administrative staff also have an exceptional track record of teaching in leading academic institutions and are supported by our Academic Council of leading educators from around the world.

Subsection Title: Current Capacity Utilization of Maturing Schools, by Year of Opening, as at 31 May 2019
Subsubsection Text: 7 Schools Opened in 12 Months to 1-Aug-2014 3 Schools 2 Schools 3 Schools Opened in FY 2015 Opened in FY 2016 Opened in FY 2017 Utilization of Opening Capacity Utilization of Total Current Built Capacity We have multiple opportunities for further profitable growth, including growth through expansion of existing schools, greenfield site development of new schools and acquisitions. We have a clear investment framework, allowing us to efficiently and profitably expand into new locations, as well as a 117 ----- proven track record of successfully developing new schools, having opened 18 new schools between September 2013 and February 2019. Our efficient construction process and strong ties with CMC have enabled us to consistently meet our construction timelines for new schools, and we have always been able to open new schools at the beginning of the school year. We expect to open one school in September 2019 and another in September 2020, with additional schools to open in the following years. We also have a land bank of 16 additional sites across the UAE. Taken together, these projects give us various options for further capacity expansion, subject to market demand, over which we have good visibility and can choose a school’s price point nearer the time of opening. This record of successful and ongoing development is supported by additional factors, including our access to prime locations, our strong relationship with local authorities, our flexible approach and extensive experience in opening schools, our disciplined investment framework and our ability to benefit from our scale which provides us with high visibility of market conditions. Our growth opportunities are also not restricted to our current core UAE markets, as demonstrated by the Acquisition, which expands our offering in the UK and Switzerland, and our plan to develop a new school site in the United Kingdom. We also have the potential to grow by investing in our School Support Services division, both by increasing the penetration of this business among our existing students and by providing these services to non-GEMS schools and other clients. We can also grow this business by acquiring additional school support service businesses, such as the Hamilton Aquatics swim academy, which we acquired in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, and integrating them into the larger framework of School Support Services.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to deliver high-quality education and strong outcomes for students
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our commitment to the provision of a high quality educational experience to our students is the foundation of our operating performance and growth. Our educational model focuses on our students, with parents and teachers contributing to student success, and strong school leadership teams setting school direction, overseeing improvement plans and resources and ensuring quality of teaching, learning and the wider student offering. We intend to continue to offer our students an excellent education by recruiting and retaining experienced and highly qualified principals and teachers and striving to help each student achieve high academic performance. We have shown strong academic results to date, with our students outperforming their global peers in terms of UK A levels, average IB diploma scores, Indian CBSE pass rates and TIMSS results, and we intend to continue to build upon our strong academic results. We believe that our reputation for quality and our desire to exceed the expectations of our students and parents are key to strengthening our position as the world’s leading provider of private K-12 English-language education.

Subsubsection Title: Increase student enrollment at schools with available capacity
Subsubsection Text: We aim to continue to increase enrollment by applying our systematic processes for generating inquiries, converting inquiries to enrollments and retaining existing students. We have a centralized enrollment team that works in parallel with dedicated admissions officers at each school. This allows 118 ----- us to leverage demand and enquiry data from across our portfolio of schools, and to refer demand from schools operating at full capacity to schools with available capacity. We intend to focus our efforts on increasing enrollments at our Maturing Schools and New Schools, which have greater levels of available capacity.

Subsubsection Title: Increase capacity in existing markets and evaluate new markets
Subsubsection Text: We intend to expand at our existing schools where market demand supports additional capacity development. We also intend to relocate and transplant certain existing schools to new locations, as this can allow existing schools to be redeveloped on sites with greater expansion capacity and also resets the baseline fee level for existing schools which, due to the regulatory cap on yearly fee increases, are below the current market rate for a school of that type. To support this strategy, we intend to continue developing our relationships with real estate developers and landlords, who we expect will continue to be key stakeholders in relation to our expansion of capacity at existing schools. We intend to continue to open new schools in the UAE and potentially in other new markets. In the UAE, we intend to open one new school in the twelve months ended 31 August 2020, and will continue developing new schools at greenfield sites at a more moderate rate than in prior years, largely focused on relocation and expansions of existing successful schools. While we have primarily grown organically in our existing markets to date, we may also seek to acquire single schools or portfolios of schools that meet our acquisition criteria, as demonstrated by our acquisition of Wesgreen International School in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 and our ongoing acquisition of Bellevue. We seek to acquire existing schools when there is no overlap with existing GEMS schools, there is an opportunity to improve the school’s operational or financial model and there is scope for school expansion on the existing site. Acquiring existing Mature Schools also allows us to benefit from an immediate, large increase in enrollments without needing to wait for enrollment levels to increase year over year, as we would for a Maturing School or New School. We regularly evaluate opportunities in adjacent markets in the GCC, which are characterized by lower political risk, strong underlying economic growth, large youth populations and a lack of public-sector education provisions. We believe that we may have a competitive advantage in these markets due to our deep experience in the K-12 educational sector and our ability to leverage the benefits of our portfolio of established schools, school support services and high-quality staff.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to recruit and develop exceptional teachers
Subsubsection Text: We emphasize the recruitment and development of high quality teachers. Our teachers are drawn from 90 countries and a wide variety of specialist fields, and we intend to continue recruiting teachers who can provide our students with globally recognized qualifications. We seek experienced teachers who are learners themselves, and who are experts in classroom organization and flexible in their teaching approach, as well as up to date on their subject knowledge and IT. We also seek teachers who are respectful of students and their community, and who aim to instill character, ambition and values in students, together with knowledge and understanding. We also seek to continuously improve our teachers through the teacher training that we provide through TELLAL. TELLAL is KHDA-approved, and the only institution in the UAE able to offer postgraduate teacher training, including for specialist Arabic teachers. Through TELLAL, we intend to continue developing and delivering proprietary training programs, including for teacher training, teacher and leader licensing preparation, leadership and management training, professional development and learning, and Arabic teacher training. We intend to continue using TELLAL to steer high quality teachers to our schools. To date, 90% of participants who have completed a TELLAL program have gone on to be teachers.

Subsubsection Title: Further grow our School Support Services division
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue expanding our School Support Services division by investing in the services it provides and acquiring additional school support service businesses. In particular, we intend to seek out acquisitions of businesses that provide services related to additional parts of the school day that we currently do not cover, such as our recent acquisition of Hamilton Aquatics, which allowed us to provide additional aquatics-related services to students. We currently provide many of our School Support Services to third parties, in addition to our own students, and intend to expand this division by providing our offering to additional third parties, as well as by leveraging our existing student base. 119 -----
Our strategy is as follows:

We began as a family tutoring business in Dubai for prominent Emirati families, started by K.S. and Mariama Varkey in 1959. In 1968, the Varkeys opened Our Own English High School, a school which we continue to operate today. From 1968 to 1980, we focused primarily on Dubai’s private K-12 English-language education sector. In 1980, Sunny Varkey took over operation of that school, and under his direction we began our strategic expansion; we operated and managed 10 schools by 1991, 15 schools by 2000, 20 schools by 2005, 25 schools by 2010 and 30 schools by 2013. From 1 September 2013 through 31 May 2019, a net 17 further schools were opened, including two in Qatar, and one further school was acquired, bringing us to 48 schools in total at 31 May 2019. We have also undertaken school management for various providers during our history, although thirdparty school management arrangements are not currently our primary focus. The table below sets out certain information regarding the growth of our school portfolio between 31 August 2007 and 31 May 2019:

In 2007, The Abraaj Group acquired a 25% stake in GMCL from the Varkey Group (which, at that time, controlled the operations of our Group). In 2012, The Abraaj Group converted its stake into a vendor loan note that the Varkey Group subsequently repaid in 2013. In 2014, GEMS Global subsequently transferred GMCL to GMHL Holdings (the prior holding company of GMCL) and sold a 20.66% stake in GMHL to Gamma Investco Limited, a consortium led by a vehicle indirectly owned and controlled by Fajr and including vehicles ultimately owned and/or controlled by Blackstone and Mumtalakat. In January 2018, GEMS Global completed the sale of a further 3.0% stake in GMHL to Khazanah and completed the sale of a 0.12% stake to AH Education. The CVC Consortium will acquire a 30.5% indirect stake in the Company, comprising the entire 20.66% held by Gamma Investco Limited, and a 9.84% stake from GEMS Global. The transaction is anticipated to close by the end of July 2019. Concurrently with the Transactions, GEMS Global will reorganize itself in order to transfer shares to DJ Invest Co, which is wholly owned by Mr. Dino Varkey, our CEO, and Mr. Jay Varkey, one of our Non-Executive Directors, as a result of which they will own an indirect 30.3% interest in the Company.

As at 31 May 2019, we offered a diverse range of educational options to over 123,000 students through 48 schools in the UAE and Qatar across three price points, Premium, Mid-Market Plus and Mid-Market, and four curricula, British, Indian, American and IB. We also provide a comprehensive range of school support services, including school bus transportation, school uniform sales, sports management services, school catering, after-school activities, school security services and teacher training. We operate through three business divisions, School Operations, School Support Services and Corporate. Upon completion of the Acquisition, we will add a fourth business division, Bellevue.

As at 31 May 2019, we operated 48 GEMS-branded schools throughout the GCC, of which 46 were in the UAE (31 in Dubai, seven in Abu Dhabi, five in Sharjah, two in Fujairah and one in Ras Al Khaimah) and two were in Qatar. 120 ----- Our portfolio of schools provides a leading K-12 platform with scale, exceptional school brands and a record of superior test scores and academic results across a range of curricula and fee levels throughout the periods under review. This platform has enabled us to capture a broad student base in the markets in which we operate. The following graphs set out the number of GEMS-branded K-12 English-language schools and levels of student enrollment as at 31 May 2019, in each case by school price point:

Subsubsection Text: We provide a balanced school portfolio comprising Premium, Mid-Market Plus and Mid-Market schools that are differentiated by price point and curricula to best meet the needs of our parents and students. Across our schools, fee levels range from $2,000 to $30,000 per student per annum, with fees per student increasing each year, as the student advances through higher grade levels. While schools at all price points offer a high-quality education, Mid-Market Plus and Premium schools typically offer lower PTRs, larger and newer campuses, and a greater variety of facilities, such as swimming pools, recording studios and robotics labs. 121 ----- _Premium schools_ As at 31 May 2019, we operated 16 Premium schools and one Premium nursery across Dubai and Abu Dhabi, providing K-12 English-language educational services to more than 26,000 students. Our Premium schools, from the lowest grade to the highest grade, typically charge between $15,000 and $30,000 per student per annum in tuition fees. We offer Premium schools across all four of our curricula. In addition, since 2014, we have also operated one Premium nursery school in Dubai, Little Gems. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, the average PTR for Premium schools was 12.1x. N/R schools include those for which public ratings are not compiled, or where ratings have not been made publicly available by their respective inspection agencies. _Mid-Market schools_ As at 31 May 2019, we operated 20 Mid-Market schools in Dubai, Abu Dhabi, Fujairah, Ras Al Khaimah and Sharjah, providing K-12 English-language educational services to approximately 73,000 students. An additional Mid-Market school was opened in September 2018. Our Mid-Market schools, from the lowest grade to the highest grade, typically charge between $2,000 and $7,000 per student per annum in tuition fees and primarily cater to students seeking the British and Indian curricula. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, the average PTR for Mid-Market schools was 19.6x. 123 ----- The following table sets out certain information about each of our Mid-Market schools as at 31 May 2019, by region and rating:

Subsection Title: Additional Capacity** **Status School Anticipated School Opening Date** **Curriculum** **Price point
Subsubsection Text: Our offering is centered around four major curricula groups as set out below. In each instance, the curriculum offered is supplemented by the specific national requirements of the relevant local education regulator: - British curriculum: typically based on the National Curriculum for England and Wales (the “NCEW”), with examinations based on the General Certificate of Secondary Education (“GCSE”), international GCSE and A Level standards. We also offer a hybrid British/UAE bilingual curriculum in two schools; - Indian curriculum: typically based on the CBSE curriculum; - American curriculum: typically based on the U.S. “common core” state standards. We also offer a hybrid U.S./UAE curriculum targeted at UAE nationals in one school; and - IB curriculum: typically based on a curriculum set by the International Baccalaureate organization. As well as stand-alone IB curriculum-based schools, we also offer senior students in certain of our Indian and American curricula-based schools the opportunity to complete their senior school (i.e. between the ages of 16 to 19) via the IB curriculum. For further information on our curriculum accreditations, see “—Accreditations and affiliations.” We also provide management services to two government schools on behalf of the Royal Family of Abu Dhabi, which teach the UAE national curriculum. Across our schools, our curriculum is guided by detailed and demanding government standards and internationally-recognized requirements that specify what students should know and be able to do at the end of each academic year in various fields of study. Our diverse school offerings reflect the demographic diversity and nationality mix of the UAE, and Dubai in particular. As at 31 May 2019, our students came from more than 170 countries. The majority of our currently enrolled students are citizens of South Asian nations, principally India and Pakistan, or from the wider Middle East region, including the UAE. These students attend a mix of curricula and, as at 31 May 2019, approximately 45% of our British curriculum-based school enrollment comprised South Asian nationals, and a further 37% were nationals from the Middle East, including the UAE. British nationals made up only approximately 2% of our overall student enrollment, and only 5% of our British curriculum-based school enrollment. The parents of our students are employed in a wide variety of sectors. As at 31 May 2017, no single employer represents more than 5% of our students’ parents, based on our analysis, with banking and financial services (15%), airlines, travel and hospitality (13%) and government (11%) representing the three largest employment sectors. Irrespective of nationality, many of our students have long-standing familial roots in the UAE. According to surveys we undertook in May 2017, 80% of our students’ parents have resided in the UAE for over five years, and 67% have resided in the UAE for over nine years. We believe that a significant proportion of our students were born in the UAE. 125 ----- The graph below shows the duration that parents of our students have resided in the UAE, based on a survey we undertook in May 2017:

We divide our students into four grade divisions: kindergarten (typically ages 3-5), junior (typically ages 5-9), middle (typically ages 10-14) and senior (ages up to 19). In line with the UAE’s overall K-12 student population, the majority of our students are in the kindergarten and junior school grade divisions, as illustrated by the graph below for each of the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and the nine months ended 31 May 2019:

Subsection Title: Enrollment Mix by Division and Weighted Average Student Grade
Subsubsection Text: Our weighted average student grade has increased year on year, from grade 4.5 to 4.6 to 4.7 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively. This gradual increase has primarily been driven by three factors. First, Maturing Schools and New Schools continue to add more students in higher grades over time, as a high proportion of students who enroll in early grades 126 ----- typically stay with the school and rise through a grade level each year. Secondly, even in Mature Schools, the average tenure of student, and therefore the average grade within each school, has continued to increase year on year, due to a trend in parents staying longer in the UAE. Finally, our Maturing Schools and New Schools continue to add more students as they open new grades above their initial year K-6 plan. As at 31 May 2019, this trend was partially offset by an above average number of younger pupils joining our schools, particularly in Kindergarten and Year 1 classes of new schools we have recently opened. See “—The lifecycle of a typical GEMS school.”

Subsection Title: Enrollment Mix by Division and Weighted Average Student Grade
Subsubsection Text: Year over year movements in net enrollments are a function of the number of students re-enrolling, and the number of new joiners to our schools. We have consistently increased our total net enrollment every year since 2003, even during periods of global or regional macroeconomic or geopolitical stress. We have high visibility over student enrollment indications for an upcoming academic year, well before the start of that year. _Re-enrollment_ We initiate our re-enrollment campaign for British, American and IB curricula-based schools in February, well ahead of the start of the academic year in September, and begin accepting payment for the upcoming academic year from April onwards. We charge a fee to re-enroll, which is generally offset against the next year’s tuition fees. Because parents pay a fee to do so, we believe re-enrollment indications are a good indication of parental intent. Re-enrollment for Indian curriculumbased schools occurs in April, at the start of that curriculum’s academic year. Re-enrollment accounts for the significant majority of the student population base in any year. Therefore, the combination of early re-enrollment indications and the earlier start of the Indian curriculum-based schools gives us visibility on the trajectory of the next year’s total enrollment levels. At the end of the 2018-2019 academic year, around 3.6% of our students graduated from the highest grade in their respective schools. The size of our graduating class has grown year over year as our student body becomes larger and more mature. After the deduction of graduating students, around 80% of students rejoined us for the subsequent 2019-2020 academic year, which we define as re-enrollment. Re-enrollment levels have consistently been around 80% in the British, American and IB curricula-based schools, and are slightly higher in Indian curriculum-based schools. Within those non-graduating students who did not re-enroll in one of our schools for the 2019-2020 academic year, we believe approximately two-thirds left the country, typically because their parents’ circumstances changed. Approximately one-third of students who did not re-enroll left to join competitor schools. Rises in our churn rate between the 2016-2017 academic year and the 2018-2019 academic year are largely attributable to an increase in the number of students who left the country. _New joiners_ We seek to offset the impact of students leaving our schools by recruiting new joiners throughout the course of the academic year, filling places both for the current academic year (intra-year joiners) and for the start of the following academic year (inter-year joiners). Typically, our new joiners are joining the GEMS school system for the first time, either as young students entering in kindergarten or early years sections, or as students joining from another country following the relocation of their parents to our markets. Some students also join us from competitor schools in the markets in which we operate. The number of new joiners at our schools has grown every year, and the number of new joiners recruited during the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 was the highest we have ever enrolled. We enrolled 29,303 new joiners (inter-year and intra-year) in the 2016-2017 academic year, 31,934 new joiners in the 2017-2018 academic year and 33,519 new joiners in the 2018-2019 academic year.

Subsection Title: Enrollment Mix by Division and Weighted Average Student Grade
Subsubsection Text: Students at our schools have consistently outperformed their global peers in both public and private schools in standardized examinations, despite the non-selective nature of our schools. 127 ----- In the three academic years between 2016 and 2018, the percentage of our students achieving GCSE 9-4 (equivalent to A* to C grades) significantly exceeded the UK average (based on examination results for students at all UK schools). In 2018, 81% of GEMS students achieved this level, compared to 67% for the UK average. Our students also exceeded UK averages at A Level during the period, with 32% achieving A*/A grades in 2018, compared to 26% for the UK average. These results were achieved even though 95% of our British curriculum students are non-British nationals, with the majority of these students identifying English as a non-mother tongue language. Similarly, students studying the IB curriculum achieved average test scores that exceeded worldwide averages during the same period, with 2018 being the best year on record, when our students achieved average final points mark of 33 versus 30 worldwide. Moreover, 93% of our students passed the International Baccalaureate, compared to a global average of 78%. In the case of our students studying the Indian curriculum, the CBSE pass rate has been just under 100% in each of the past four years, compared to the worldwide average which ranged between 82% and 83% during the same period. Our students have also performed well in the TIMSS assessments, a series of international assessments of the mathematics and science knowledge of students around the world conducted by the IEA every four years. In the 2015 set of TIMSS tests, for example, the average grade four math TIMSS scores for our Mid-Market, Mid-Market Plus and Premium price points were 541, 529 and 565, respectively, with each of these scores exceeding the UAE average of 452. The next cycle of TIMSS assessment is planned for 2019.

Subsection Title: Enrollment Mix by Division and Weighted Average Student Grade
Subsubsection Text: Our Dubai-based schools are subject to inspection and rating by the KHDA on an annual basis, typically in March or April, with the results communicated in April or May. Our schools in Abu Dhabi are subject to inspection by ADEK approximately once every two years. The KHDA awards ratings based on several factors, principally the quality of a school’s educational offering. Schools can be rated “Outstanding,” “Very Good,” “Good,” “Acceptable” or “Unacceptable.” Schools are not rated for the first three years of operation. When schools are first rated, they will receive either an “acceptable” or “good” rating, and this can progressively improve, based on inspection performance. The following table sets out the KHDA ratings for our Rated Schools as at 31 May 2019:
