Subsubsection Text: Our overall average School ARPS was $6,640, $7,074 and $7,419 for the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 respectively. Increases in School ARPS are driven by the following three primary factors: _Tuition fee inflation_ School operators in Dubai and Abu Dhabi have generally been permitted by their respective regulators to increase school tuition fees periodically to account for inflation. In Dubai, school tuition fees are regulated by the KHDA based on two factors: an annually-adjusted inflation benchmark, the ECI, and a multiplier. In advance of the twelve months ended 31 August 2019, the Dubai Executive Council announced that school operators would not be permitted to increase fees for the following year. Prior to the 2019 revision, the KHDA framework permitted schools to raise fees by a multiplier of ECI linked to the then-prevailing DSIB score of the school. This generally allowed us to raise fees by an amount in excess of inflation. Following the 2019 revision, the multiplier is driven by whether the school has achieved positive or negative changes in its rating from the DSIB. The multiplier is structured to incentivize school operators to invest in their schools in order to raise their ratings. If a school’s rating is upgraded, it can increase fees by the multiplier set out in the table below. If the school’s rating is downgraded, the school will not be able to increase fees by any amount in the coming year. 129 ----- The following table sets out the multiplier applicable to various ratings movements:

Note: (1) One school may have two curriculums. Therefore, the number of ratings is not equal to the number of schools. ADEK awards ratings based on a number of factors, principally the quality of a school’s educational offering. Schools can be rated “Outstanding,” “Very Good,” “Good,” “Acceptable,” “Weak” or “Very Weak.” Two of our rated Abu Dhabi Emirate schools were rated “Very Good” (American and IB curriculum), with the rest being rated “Good” (three schools with British curriculum, one school with Indian curriculum and one school in Al Ain (a municipality of Abu Dhabi) with British and Indian curricula). In addition, ADEK also conducted a parent survey in September 2017 for each of our schools in Abu Dhabi (including Al Ain) across four different criteria: parent-school partnership, school safety, 128 ----- teaching effectiveness and physical environment. According to the survey, our schools ranked above all other schools in Abu Dhabi on all of these criteria and our school in Al Ain ranked above all other private schools in Al Ain on three out of four of the criteria. As at the date of this Offering Memorandum, ADEK are currently undertaking a new round of surveys, although there is no known publication date. School ratings are made public and have a significant impact on our ability to attract and retain students, as well as teachers. We also believe that our ratings support recognition for our brand as a leading educator. Improved rating outcomes are also an important indicator to evaluate the effectiveness of our continued investment in educational quality. In addition, in our largest market, Dubai, the amount by which we are able to increase tuition fees at each of our schools on an annual basis depends in part on the ratings achieved by our schools. See “—Tuition fee increases” below. Our two Northern Emirates schools (Our Own Fujairah and GEMS Westminster Fujairah) have not historically been subject to a structured inspection regime, although this changed in 2018, as the Northern Emirates are implementing a school rating system based on the Dubai regulatory framework, and although we have privately been informed of the likely ratings for these schools, no rating for any schools in the Northern Emirates has yet been made public. For further information on the applicable regulatory requirements in respect of each of the Emirates within the UAE, see “Regulation Overview— _United Arab Emirates.”_

Our schools are accredited by a variety of international educational organizations, including the International Baccalaureate, the New England Association of Schools and Colleges, the Commission on American/International Schools Abroad, the Council of International Schools and AdvancED (previously known as the Commission on International and Transregional Accreditation). Several of our schools have also been certified as examination centers by international boards of education, including Edexcel, Cambridge International Examinations (the “CIE”), University of Cambridge, United Kingdom and Assessment and Qualifications Alliance. In addition, some of our schools are also affiliated with the British Schools of the Middle East, the CIE, the Council for Indian School Certificate Examinations and the Central Board of Secondary Education of India.

Subsubsection Title: Approach to academic quality at our schools
Subsubsection Text: We strive to maintain the highest standards of education quality across all of our curricula, without regard to fee levels. We consider the following to be the key factors driving school choices for parents: - the quality of teachers and the curriculum; - the school’s reputation; - the school’s location; - the school’s rating provided by the relevant regulators (the KHDA, ADEK or the MOE); - the overall educational and pastoral environment that each school creates for our students; - academic record; - campus quality and overall facilities; and - value for money. 131 ----- We believe that these factors are central to the reputation of our schools and the high standard of education we provide, and are supported by the following initiatives: _An academically rigorous educational and co-curricular program_ We strive to meet the individual needs of each of our students. Each curriculum is designed to comply with the relevant internationally recognized requirements, and is adapted to meet local regulatory requirements, culture and customs, particularly additional UAE-specific curriculum components. We use an integrated IT platform that can be customized for each student. It allows each school to track the performance of our students on an individual basis as well as to benchmark their performance within the school and across our school portfolio. Students are tracked across 88 parameters, based on the KHDA assessment framework. We believe that this enhances the tracking of our students’ academic performance by giving teachers, parents and students an accurate measure of individual progress across a range of metrics. In addition, this platform allows clear learning objectives to be set and monitored within the classroom and on a school-wide basis. Further, the IT platform creates accountability among faculty members and drives consistency in instruction by applying comparable metrics across our school portfolio. In addition to the rigorous approach to classroom-based learning, through our e-Sports and Academy Plus offerings, we operate sporting and academic co-curricular activities during and after school across our schools that provide a supplementary informal learning environment for students as well as additional revenues for us. See “—The School Support Services division.” _Highly qualified principals, teachers and administrative staff_ We demonstrate our commitment to premium quality education by hiring and retaining highly qualified principals, teachers and administrative staff. We use a range of strategies to identify, select and employ our staff. We recruited approximately 1,300 new teachers in the nine months ended 31 May 2019 in anticipation of academic year 2019-2020. These additions were made to accommodate new teaching positions in Maturing Schools and New Schools, as well as to replace teachers who had left. We have a dedicated in-house team dealing with academic recruitment. We receive a substantial number of teaching job applications, receiving almost 65,000 applications in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. We require our teachers to be fully qualified with formal teaching qualifications. Teachers typically have prior teaching experience in national or international schools before joining. As well as recruiting teachers globally, we also train new teachers and offer professional development for current teachers through our teacher training division, TELLAL. TELLAL is fully accredited to grant teaching qualifications recognized both in the UAE and globally. It also generates third party revenues from offering training and accreditation services to other school groups in the UAE. As at 31 May 2019, we employed 3,345 teachers in British curriculum-based schools, 2,900 teachers in Indian curriculum-based schools, 640 teachers in American curriculum-based schools and 556 teachers in IB curriculum-based schools. We believe we are among the world’s largest private sector employers of British and Indian curriculum teachers, and that our scale and global visibility with teachers assists in our ability to attract and recruit new staff. As part of our commitment to hiring and retaining highly qualified staff, we benchmark teaching salaries to both home-country and UAE pay levels, and pay salaries which we believe are competitive but not typically market-leading. Our compensation packages for teachers typically include housing and airfare allowances as well as statutory end of service benefits. We also operate a long-term incentive plan for teachers, “Share our Future,” which offers cash payments to our longer-term teaching employees. Furthermore, teachers receive concessions on tuition fees for their own children enrolled in our schools. Salaries in the UAE and Qatar do not incur income tax. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, our staff costs were 66.4% of our total operating expenses. We believe that turnover rates for our teachers are similar to overall turnover rates for expatriates in the UAE, with turnover rates for teachers at our schools being 20.3%, 19.8% and 15.6% in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively. Furthermore, we believe that our teacher turnover levels are lower than average in the K-12 international schools market, which we believe to be approximately 20 to 25%. As at 31 May 2019, over 53% of our teachers had been with us for at least three years, while 24% had been with us for six or more years. 132 ----- Our schools have clear policies for professional development that set out the main responsibilities and entitlements for staff at all levels. In each school, a member of the senior leadership team is responsible for strategy, planning, implementation and evaluation of the professional development of our staff. To maintain consistency, the same member of the senior leadership team typically oversees the staff performance management and appraisal processes, through which individual objectives and development plans are framed and monitored. We regularly and rigorously review the performance of our principals and teaching staff to ensure that their performance meets our high standards. Principals and teachers also benefit from various continuing professional development initiatives, including those provided by TELLAL, which are designed to foster career progression and to improve the quality of our administrative and teaching staff. _High quality school facilities_ Our school facilities, such as science laboratories, sports facilities, computer, music and theatre resources, enhance the educational experience of our students, with additional facilities being offered at higher price points. In addition, the majority of classrooms, irrespective of school price point, use interactive computerized white boards that facilitate students’ participation in learning. We use architectural consultants that specialize in school design to design new schools and to expand or refurbish existing facilities, and to ensure that our facilities can be used efficiently and in a manner that best enhances the professional and educational experience for both staff and students.

We operate a quality assurance program that includes regular school reviews by our corporate education department. The corporate education team operates on a Group level and is staffed by educators with significant teaching and school leadership experience. Reviews are conducted in schools on an annual basis, and outcomes are monitored and determine the school’s ongoing and future development. In-depth school reviews are conducted each time a school enters a new phase of development (for example, the introduction of a new principal or other significant changes that may have a material impact on the school). The quality assurance program also includes regular classroom observation and a review of teaching and learning which is conducted by school principals and their leadership teams. We also encourage the sharing of education best practices across schools, and provide formal forums for school principals and senior leadership teams to do so. All school principals and leadership teams are trained in school self-evaluation, which is a criteria of the regulatory inspection framework, and is undertaken on a continuing basis by the schools themselves, to improve the standards of learning and teaching quality in our schools.

In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, we received 76,047 enquiries from prospective students, which led to over 40,567 registrations and over 26,900 new joiner enrollments. The student recruitment process is defined by the following stages: - _Enquiries: parents considering enrolling their child at a GEMS school register their child’s details online or in person and request further information; - _Visits: parents are encouraged to visit the school campus accompanied by the relevant child and to meet with members of the school’s senior leadership and admissions teams; - _Registration: parents register their child with the school, specify a start date and pay a non- refundable application fee; and - _Enrollments: we aim to place registered students either within the academic year in which they applied or in the subsequent academic year. Students are enrolled on a first-come, first-served basis. We have a centralized enrollment team which works in parallel with dedicated admissions officers at each school. This allows us to leverage demand and enquiry data from across our portfolio of schools, and to refer demand for schools at capacity to schools with excess capacity. We also maintain a waitlist of prospective students who are seeking entry to our schools. 133 ----- The enrollment team uses customer relationship management tools to track, report on, follow-up and help convert enquiries into new enrollments. From the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 onwards, we have implemented Salesforce, a specialized client relationship management system across all of our UAE and Qatar schools, giving us additional marketing functionality and visibility over the enrollment process. _Generation of enquiries_ Many of our enquiries start from parents’ online research. This includes visits to individual school websites, our corporate website, government websites such as those of the KHDA or ADEK and thirdparty reference sites, such as the Good School Guides for Dubai, Abu Dhabi and Doha and Which School Advisor. Parent referrals are also important for generating enquiries. We offer a “refer a friend” scheme whereby if a referral leads to an enrollment at certain GEMS schools with capacity, then the referring parent will receive a monetary benefit either in the form of a one-off tuition fee discount (if the parent has a child enrolled at a GEMS school) or a cash reward. In addition, we have established relationships with the human resources personnel of major employers and provide information packs, employee handbooks and marketing materials to help new employees understand the local education system. Certain of these employers can reserve places in our schools for their employees. While some employers fund some of our tuition fees as part of expatriate compensation packages, substantially all of our tuition fees are paid by parents directly. We track parental employment details at the time of application, and this data indicates that parents of our students are employed in a wide variety of sectors, with no one sector representing more than 15% of parents, and no single company employing more than 5% of our students’ parents as at 31 May 2017. Relocation agents who settle expatriate families in cities in which our schools are located are also a source of enquiries. We do not pay commission-based placement agencies in the UAE or Qatar to source prospective students. _Marketing and brand awareness_ Our marketing strategy is designed to develop brand awareness among prospective parents and students, along with teachers, regulators and other stakeholders. Our marketing function is centrally controlled with a common brand architecture and agreed communications strategies, materials and support but is executed locally at each school by principals, admissions managers and marketing staff. Our marketing strategy is primarily based on our reputation, referrals and word-of-mouth rather than media campaigns, thereby minimizing our annual marketing spend. We launched a new branding campaign in the first quarter of 2018 which was intended to support the overall GEMS brand. We supplement our marketing strategy with other targeted activities intended to help us raise awareness with parents and prospective teachers. These activities include preparing promotional materials, such as school brochures and educational magazines and holding internal and external public relations exercises and conferences. For example, in association with the Varkey Foundation, a UK registered charity, we have sponsored the Global Education and Skills Forum held annually in Dubai since 2013. We also donate to the annual Global Teacher Prize, a $1,000,000 award, payable over 10 years, which is presented annually to an exceptional teacher who has made an inspirational impact on their students and their community. _Student retention_ We also employ a parent loyalty program, “GEMS Rewards,” to encourage student retention. This loyalty scheme encompasses a number of strategies, including a co-branded credit card which provides a discount on school fees. Parents can also use the GEMS Rewards smartphone-based app to secure discounts and offers on unrelated online and offline purchases. Parents who use co-branded credit cards to pay tuition fees are also able to pay in installments. We pay lower merchant fees on payments made with our co-branded cards than for other credit cards and negotiate generally lower merchant fees with our acquiring bank partners. The majority of our fees are paid via credit or debit cards. 134 -----

Subsubsection Title: The lifecycle of a typical GEMS school
Subsubsection Text: Most new enrollments into our schools are kindergarten or junior grade children, who are joining the education system for the first time as they start school, or who are young children moving to the UAE in the junior grades. As such, we shape our new school development process to generally accommodate junior grades initially, and then to subsequently provide capacity for more senior level grades as the student population matures. We typically develop our new schools in two to three phases. The first phase generally involves the construction of a kindergarten and primary school, providing places for kindergarten through grade five or six students. The first phase is designed to be a complete free-standing school and include all the facilities required, such as designated play areas, learning and discovery areas, reading rooms, sports facilities and swimming pools where relevant. The second phase of construction is typically initiated within three to four years after the first phase opens. The second phase typically involves the construction of secondary school sections for students in the middle and senior grades and typically comprises the development of classrooms as well as any specialist facilities for secondary school students (such as computer labs, libraries, senior sports facilities and fitness suites). Some of our schools have undertaken third phases of construction, which further expand the capacity of the school building. We believe that the benefits of this multi-phase approach include: - minimizing the initial set-up costs of construction by initially only constructing a primary school; - benefiting from the high level of initial demand at the primary school level; and - our schools constructed in the first phase being able to become self-sufficient and financially viable, and the construction of the secondary school in the second phase being generally launched when the first phase is well utilized, thereby providing a source of students for the secondary school. Moreover, our approach is to build primary and secondary schools on the same premises, thereby benefiting from economies of scale and the resulting cost savings while offering a high quality of education to our students. Economies of scale and cost savings are realized by incorporating specialist facilities, such as play areas, drama facilities, art rooms and music facilities, in one location for the benefit of both primary and secondary school students while simultaneously giving students access to a greater variety of facilities and enhancing their educational experience. Furthermore, the development of a secondary school or secondary sections of an existing school is generally undertaken to capture inherent and already visible demand for school places from existing primary school students who are graduating through the junior grades. _Capacity utilization_ New schools generally increase their enrollment year on year until they reach full capacity utilization. As described above, new enrollment is primarily added in early years and kindergarten classes year on year. As at 31 May 2019, our overall utilization of phase one capacity in our 15 Maturing Schools was 96%, our Mature Schools’ capacity utilization was 96% and our total average capacity utilization was 84%. Capacity utilization levels for Maturing Schools typically increase over time, as set out in the table below:

Eligible schools that have maintained the same rating of the previous ECI year[(1)] Schools that have improved their rating from[(1)]: ECI x 2 Very Weak to Weak Weak to Acceptable Acceptable to Good Schools that have improved their rating from[(1)]: ECI x 1.75 Good to Very Good Schools that have improved their rating from: ECI x 1.5 Very Good to Outstanding Schools that have dropped in performance (from their current rating to a No increase in school fees lower one)[(1)] Note: (1) For profit schools in Dubai, the last inspection rating conducted by DSIB will be considered while implementing the fee increase as per the above table. The ECI is determined annually by the Dubai Statistics Centre (the “DSC”) and is based on historically observed inflation in the costs of operating a school, as determined by the DSC. The applicable ECI is typically announced in advance of an academic year, allowing school operators to communicate fee increase guidance to parents prior to re-enrollment. The ECI was 2.9% for the 2015–2016 academic year, 3.2% for the 2016–2017 academic year and 2.4% for the 2017–2018 academic year. No ECI was formally communicated for the 2018–2019 academic year and operators were not permitted to raise fees for Dubai schools in that academic year. In April 2019, the DSC announced that the ECI for the 2019-2020 academic year will be 2.07%. Existing schools cannot increase fees without prior approval from the KHDA. The KHDA has also historically considered applications for exceptions to the general framework for fee increases (subject to certain conditions laid out in the framework). Finally, the KHDA and other authorities in Dubai can also decide that tuition fees cannot be increased despite growing inflation, as occurred most recently in the 2018–2019 academic year. See “Regulation Overview—United Arab Emirates—Dubai—Fee _Framework.”_ In Dubai, we have increased fees at all of our schools every year since the 2011-2012 academic year, with exceptions in the 2012-2013 academic year, when the ECI was set at negative 1%, and in the 2018-2019 academic year, when the Dubai Executive Council froze tuition fees. In addition, we may choose not to increase fees at specific schools for commercial reasons. We chose to do so in the 2017-2018 academic year at one school, and will do so again at two schools in the upcoming academic year. Tuition fees for our schools in other jurisdictions are reviewed periodically. In Abu Dhabi, schools are typically able to increase school tuition fees by up to 6% every year, with the permitted fee increase based on performance under four criteria. In Sharjah, Fujairah and Ras Al Khaimah, private schools are required to request proposed fee increases directly from the UAE Ministry of Education. Any proposed fee increases are subject to the maximum permitted increase of 10% one year after the last increase, 20% two years after the last increase and 30% three years after the last increase. In Qatar, all fee increases must be approved by the Qatar Ministry of Education. See “Regulation Overview” for details. We view tuition fee increases associated with the ECI as an opportunity to ensure that the operational cost inflation we experience can be passed on to customers, thus supporting our operating margins. _Grade aging effect_ Our historic School ARPS growth also reflects a grade aging effect. Tuition fees are higher in more senior grades across all of our schools. For example, the tuition fee charged for a student entering GEMS Wellington International School in Kindergarten 1 (“KG1”) was approximately $14,800 per 130 ----- student per annum for the 2017–2018 academic year, whereas the tuition fee for a student entering the 12th grade was approximately $25,500 for the same academic year. As at 31 May 2019, 15 of our 48 schools were Maturing Schools, having been opened between September 2013 and August 2017, and three of our schools were classified as New Schools, having been opened after September 2017. Maturing Schools and New Schools primarily attract kindergarten and junior grade students in their first years of opening. As a result, these newer schools have student bodies which are more heavily skewed towards junior grades than our Mature Schools. This results in a lower ARPS at opening as compared to the ARPS when the school is Mature. Each year, as these schools mature, younger students progress through grades in the school, and the average age of the student body rises. This has the natural effect of raising the average School ARPS for the school independently of tuition fee increases. Grade aging also occurs in Mature Schools, where year on year we have observed that the weighted average school grade continues to increase. We attribute this effect to the continuing maturation of the UAE’s expatriate population, and the increasing trend of parents staying longer in the country. Our weighted average grade across our entire school portfolio has increased from grade 4.5 to 4.6 to 4.7 in the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018, respectively. _Mix effect_ Our tuition fees at a portfolio level are also affected by the increasing contribution from newer schools. Tuition fees for our Maturing Schools and New Schools are generally higher than those for our Mature Schools, even within the same price point; the School ARPS in the nine months ended 31 May 2019 for our Mature Schools was $6,013, compared to a School ARPS of $8,684 for Maturing Schools over the same period. As such, incremental students joining schools at a higher price point, and the progression of those students into higher grades at higher prices will generally support higher School ARPS.

Subsubsection Title: Development of new schools and expansion of existing schools
Subsubsection Text: Historically, the majority of our school portfolio growth has been driven by greenfield construction of new schools and expansion of existing schools. However, we have also acquired schools operated by third parties, including our acquisition of Wesgreen International School in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 and our acquisition of Bellevue, which we are currently in the process of completing. In the period between 1 September 2016 and 31 May 2019, we expanded capacity at our existing schools by 14,695 places, developed seven greenfield schools with a total of 20,506 places and acquired one school with a total of 4,680 places. _Site identification and land bank_ When determining whether to expand in our existing markets, we adopt a multi-stage approach to assess the viability of making an investment. Our dedicated business development team first identifies land parcels suitable for development in areas of high demand. Once a parcel has been identified, an initial feasibility study is prepared. As part of the initial feasibility study, we seek to identify the potential demand for private K-12 English-language education within the specific catchment area of the site. If, based on the outcome of the first phase, we decide to further consider the opportunity, the initial proposition is presented to our investment committee (the “investment committee”) for approval to add the site to our land bank by signing a long-term lease over the site. We typically seek to arrange 136 ----- these leases with multi-year rent-free periods, so that we do not incur ongoing operational expenses during the site’s detailed planning phase. We also seek to negotiate lease clauses that permit termination for convenience, allowing operational flexibility should the site not be deemed suitable for ultimate development. At this point, a detailed feasibility study is prepared to fully evaluate the investment opportunity, with the following factors in particular being considered: (i) the addressable market, which is the anticipated net population growth within a 20-minute commute to the proposed facility; (ii) the anticipated demographics and nationality of the population growth, as this will impact the model, curriculum and pricing for the new school; (iii) the competitive dynamics from existing or planned schools; and (iv) our anticipated share of the net additional K-12 children moving into the area. We do not rely on the attrition of existing schools in place provided by competitors when planning new schools. If the decision is taken to proceed, the development plan and associated capital expenditure are presented for approval to the investment committee, at which stage they must meet certain underwriting thresholds. These thresholds include internal rate of return targets by year seven and certain cash breakeven thresholds. Subject to the approval of the investment committee, construction commences, followed by completion and opening of the school, generally within 12-18 months from commencement of construction, depending on the site, scope of design, and design. _Contractor engagement_ Substantially all of our school construction has historically been undertaken by CMC. CMC is a construction and interior fit-out operator. It is a Varkey Group Affiliate and has over 35 years of experience in the construction industry. It has constructed over 50 schools for us and third-party clients, making it highly experienced and knowledgeable with respect to the particular requirements and construction timetables for our schools. As our preferred school construction supplier, CMC can leverage its long operating history with us to help ensure that school construction projects are delivered on time and within budget. CMC is contracted to develop all of our currently planned or under development schools. _Expansion into new markets_ In considering other potential markets outside of the UAE and Qatar, GMHL considers jurisdictions with strong underlying macroeconomic fundamentals, a large youth population and a limited publicsector school provision. Our shareholder also considers the competitive advantage of being able to offer the benefits of our portfolio of established schools, the opportunities for providing school support services and the availability of high quality staff at the appropriate remuneration levels. Based on the above criteria, GMHL has established a joint venture in the KSA (the “KSA Joint Venture”), in partnership with Hassana. In May 2019, the KSA Joint Venture announced the acquisition of 100% of Ma’arif Holding Company for Education and Training (“Maarif”). Maarif comprises 13 schools and serves over 21,000 students in the KSA. Similarly, GMHL has also established a joint venture in Egypt, in partnership with the private equity firm EFG (the “Egypt Joint Venture”). In November 2018, the Egypt Joint Venture entered into agreements, pursuant to which it acquired four international schools in Cairo. The assets, liabilities and operations of the KSA Joint Venture and the Egypt Joint Venture are outside of the Restricted Group. While both have stand-alone management and staff, we anticipate continuing to provide operational and educational support to both entities, for which we will be remunerated on an arms-length basis. Our shareholder receives management fees from both the KSA Joint Venture and the Egypt Joint Venture. We also receive an intellectual property licensing fee from the KSA Joint Venture. _Development models_ We use one of several development models to construct facilities and expand capacity, depending on what is appropriate in the circumstances: - New site development. A new school may be developed on a new greenfield site, often adjacent to or part of a master planned residential community where an increase in K-12 aged students is 137 ----- anticipated. In this situation, the master plan developer is often the landlord, and the school forms an integral part of the project plan. - On-site extension. Schools may also be developed through the extension of an existing site. This involves the expansion of an existing school, including by constructing phase two or phase three, as discussed in “—The School Operations division—The lifecycle of a typical GEMS school.” - Expansion in parallel. A new school may be developed on a site which is adjacent or closely located to an existing site. Often, this will be the development of a secondary school to capture demand from students already graduating from a primary school. - Relocation and transplant. On occasion, an existing school may be transplanted onto a new or existing site. The decision to use this approach is driven by the maturity of a school, the condition of its infrastructure and the availability of expansion capacity at an existing site. Ideally, it is undertaken near an old school, to maximize the number of students who remain at the new school site. This approach also presents an opportunity to reset fees for a school that may have been open for several years and the fees of which are below the current market rate for a school at that level. Finally, the vacated site can be returned to the landlord (if the lease is coming to an end) or redeveloped into a new facility. The most recent examples of a relocation and transplant were: (i) the merger of the GEMS Dubai American Academy into the facilities of the GEMS Dubai Nations Academy in advance of the twelve months ended 31 August 2018; and (ii) the relocation of our own boys school, Sharjah which was merged with English Private School Sharjah, in the twelve months ended 31 August 2019. We intend to open a new school at a higher price point, GEMS Cambridge Sharjah, on the vacated site, in September 2019. - Acquisition. Under certain circumstances, we will consider the acquisition of single schools or a portfolio of schools. We evaluate potential acquisitions based on a number of factors, including the school’s existing track record, the strength of our management team, the investment rationale, historical financial performance, expected rate of return and integration timeline and growth potential. In addition to GEMS Cambridge Sharjah, we expect to open one school in September 2019 and another in September 2020, with additional schools to open in the following years.

Subsubsection Title: Approach to operation of our schools
Subsubsection Text: Historically, we have leased the land on which our buildings are constructed and used several asset ownership models to operate our school buildings, including an operating company (“Owned”) model, a property company (“Leased”) model, a mixed model and a sale and leaseback model. In addition, we maintain a land bank. As at 31 May 2019, the weighted average lease term of all of our leases for our existing schools was 14 years. _Owned schools_ Under this model, we build and subsequently own all phases of a school building on leased or owned land. The school construction is generally carried at construction cost on the balance sheet. _Leased schools_ Under this model, either the landlord or a third party builds the entire school building, which we then lease. Taken together, owned and leased property management models accounted for 92% of our 48 schools as at 31 May 2019. _Mixed_ On certain sites, a landlord or third party has constructed phase one of a school and we have built the remaining phases. This model accounted for 8% of our schools as at 31 May 2019. _Sale and leaseback schools_ In addition, we have historically raised financing by arranging sale and leaseback transactions for certain of our school buildings. In these instances, we either sold existing schools to real estate 138 ----- investors in return for a commercial lease or approached developers to construct schools to our specifications in return for long-term leases. Properties leased under sale and leaseback arrangements represent our most expensive individual school leases. We have repurchased school buildings operated under the sale and leaseback model, acquiring three schools in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 for $159.8 million and one further school in the UAE in the nine months ended 31 May 2018 for $53.1 million. The repurchase of leases underlying these buildings generated rent savings of $13.5 million and $5.4 million in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017 and 2018, respectively. Concurrently with the transaction, we are acquiring the leasehold interest of two further school buildings in Qatar and aim to complete these transactions by 31 August 2019. _Land bank_ We also maintain a land bank, whereby we seek long-term leases and sign lease options on prospective sites. We also seek rent-free periods and high optionality to return the site. We will then later use our land bank to potentially develop new facilities. Our land bank currently consists of 16 sites, with six sites in Dubai, four sites in Abu Dhabi, two sites in Sharjah and one site in each of Ajman, Al Ain, Fujairah and Ras Al Khaimah, although we have identified four of these properties as land we will not develop, and may seek to renegotiate or cancel the related leases. For further details on our criteria for acquiring sites for our land bank, see “—Development of new schools and _expansion of existing schools—Site identification and land bank.”_

Subsubsection Text: Number of schools . . . . . . . . 1 1 3 2 3 7 15 31 48 Utilization of opening capacity (%) . . . . . . . . . . . . 50 9 101 54 100 108 96 N/A N/A Utilization of total current built capacity (%) . . . . . . . . 50 12 70 31 61 65 60 96 84 Notes: (1) Maturing Schools are schools that began operation between September 2013 and August 2017. 135 ----- (2) Mature Schools are schools that have been in operation since before September 2013. (3) Includes Wesgreen International School, acquired by us in the twelve months ended 31 August 2017. For example, one of our Premium schools which opened during the twelve months ended 31 August 2014 had 313 students and an average student age of 5.9 years in February 2014, 745 students and an average student age of 6.8 years in February 2015 and 1,380 students and an average student age of 6.2 years in February 2019. We structure our schools to cater to the high levels of demand at the primary school level by offering more classes and focusing on increasing capacity at lower grades. Typically, the required capacity at the later grades in secondary schools decreases due to student turnover and fewer new entrants at the secondary school level. Notwithstanding this, the proportion of our students in senior grades has increased year on year from 17% as at 31 August 2015 to 20% as at 31 May 2019, driven by a maturing overall portfolio. _Financial model_ Typically, our schools reach the operational break-even point (on a school-level EBITDA basis) within three to five years, when capacity utilization reaches approximately 50% or more. Prior to opening a new school, we incur capital expenditure to develop the school’s physical infrastructure, as well as pre-operational expenses such as the costs of securing regulatory approvals, and the cost of hiring school staff to assist in regulatory approvals, marketing, training and school mobilization prior to the opening of the school. Once opened, a new GEMS school typically experiences losses during its first two to three years of operation, due to the lower operational leverage of the fixed components of the school’s operational expenses. These operational expenses include the salaries of the administrative and senior leadership teams, and the relatively fixed components of administrative expenses such as water and electricity charges. Moreover, we typically open a school with the number of teachers we anticipate will be required for the second year of operation, meaning that the school initially opens with more teachers than necessary, and correspondingly smaller class sizes and lower PTRs. As the school adds enrollments, capacity utilization levels and PTRs will correspondingly rise. While the decision to start construction of phase two depends on a number of factors, we typically target the construction of phase two once the school is approaching 50% utilization, with phase two targeted to open in year three or four of the school’s life. Although the foregoing discussion describes the lifecycle of a typical GEMS school, the actual performance of any particular school may vary due to a number of factors, including the location of the school, specific country dynamics and the regulatory environment in which the school operates.

We provide transportation services for students to and from school and are the largest such privatesector business in the UAE. We operate, via School Transport Services LLC (“STS”) and its subsidiaries, a transportation company which was established in the UAE in 2008. STS operates across all of our schools in the UAE and has an exclusive contract to provide transport services to students in our school portfolio as well as to students at non-GEMS schools. As at 31 May 2019, STS employed over 3,200 staff and operated more than 2,400 school buses carrying more than 80,000 students each day. The principal source of revenue for STS are the transport fees collected from parents. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, on average 62% of our students on a Group-wide basis used our transport services. Our transport services have the highest penetration among our Mid-Market Plus schools, with an average of 71% of these students using our transportation services in the nine months ended 31 May 2019. Additional revenue is generated from STS’s corporate, event and tourism bus and coach transport services, IT surveillance services and after-school transport services provided to us and third-party private school operators. The principal costs of STS are driver salaries, fuel, vehicle maintenance, vehicle depreciation, vehicle insurance and vehicle financing costs.

We generate income from uniform sales to both our own schools and some schools outside our school portfolio, through our wholly owned subsidiary, Threads. Threads has eight retail outlets and 139 ----- 34 in-school concessions, and has the exclusive contract to provide school uniforms to 44 GEMS schools in the UAE. Threads also sells footwear, stationery, bags and accessories and its service capabilities include design, pre-production sampling, supply chain and quality management, logistics, warehouse and retail. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2018, Threads sold approximately one million items of school apparel. The sales cycle is concentrated in August and September, at the start of term for the British, American and IB curriculum-based schools on the one hand, and in March and April, at the start of term for the Indian curriculum-based schools on the other. Threads also generates approximately 10% of its sales from third-party schools and corporate clients. It was acquired from GEMS Global in September 2017.

We generate income from sports management services through our ESM brand, which rents our football, tennis, swimming and other sports facilities to third-party sports providers, organizes summer camps and events, and provides coaching services through our Sports Academy. The business generates additional income by providing a selection of these services to non-GEMS schools. It manages over 150 facilities and has staged more than 350 events since 2012, and each week, approximately 12,000 students and 15,000 adults participate in events organized by it or at our facilities. We also generate income from sports management services through our Hamilton Aquatics swim academy, which we acquired in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. Hamilton Aquatics provides swimming lessons for all ability levels, from our “Learn to Swim” lessons for beginners through to our “High Level Swim Squad for Olympic Level Swimmers.” We also provide water safety programs and training courses for swim coaches.

We generate income from after-school activities services through our Academy Plus brand, which provides after-school extra-curricular activities and extended learning opportunities such as dance and music classes, language tuition and Science, Technology, Engineering and Math programs to students at both GEMS and non-GEMS schools.

We acquired Slices, a catering services business in the twelve months ended 31 August 2018. Slices provides catering services through outsourced third-party providers to several of our schools and also to third-party schools.
We generate income from school security services through our Safecor brand, which provides our schools with security guards and general security services.

We generate income from teacher training services through our TELLAL brand. TELLAL offers teacher training, teacher and leader licensing preparation, leadership and management training, professional learning and development and Arabic teacher training. We offer these services to both GEMS and non-GEMS teachers. TELLAL’s teacher trainers include both our staff and third-party trainers. We also offer KHDA and ADEK-approved online models.
Infracare provides soft infrastructure services such as cleaning and maintenance at many of our schools, and also for some third-party schools.

We provide a comprehensive range of school support services that generate ancillary revenues for us through fees charged to our students that are in addition to tuition fees. While the vast majority of the School Support Services division’s business is generated through our school portfolio, certain services are also offered to some third-party school operators and, as such, the School Support Services are not branded or associated directly with our schools. The School Support Services division comprises school bus transportation, school uniform sales, sports management services, school catering services, after-school activities, school catering, school security services and teacher training. In the nine months ended 31 May 2019, the School Support Services division accounted for 13.8% of our revenue and 18.9% of our Adjusted EBITDA (before inter-segmental eliminations), the majority of which was attributable to our transportation services. Support Services ARPS for the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 was $939, $1,005 and $1,125 respectively. It was $1,173 in the twelve months ended 31 May 2019.

The Corporate division primarily comprises our Group-wide corporate-level operations and allows us to leverage the benefits of scale by taking responsibility for Group-wide corporate-level activities. Expenses including central functional staff and administration expenses are charged to the Corporate division. 140 ----- We also recognize the revenue from providing managed school operations to third-party schools in Abu Dhabi and the KSA in our Corporate division. Under this model, revenues are generated by the payment of management fees to us for the services the division provides. In the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018, these management fees were $3.2 million, $3.5 million and $1.4 million, respectively.

Concurrently with the Offering, we are acquiring a 92.9% shareholding in Bellevue from an indirect wholly-owned subsidiary of the Varkey Group, one of our indirect shareholders. As at 31 May 2019, Bellevue educated 2,717 students across 15 schools, of which 14 are in the United Kingdom, and one is in Switzerland. We intend to operate Bellevue as a stand-alone division within our organization. Bellevue primarily owns and operates independent “prep” day schools. Prep schools teach the NCEW and prepare students aged 3 to 13 to sit the Common Entrance Exam, the 11+ exam, and other entrance examinations which are required for entrance into independent secondary schools in the United Kingdom. Bellevue also operates two secondary schools, Ealing Independent College, a secondary school educating children from 14 to 19 in London, and Surval Montreux, a girls’ secondary boarding school located in Switzerland which teaches the IB curriculum. Bellevue’s UKbased schools are clustered in the South West and North West of the United Kingdom, and to a lesser extent, in London. In addition, Bellevue’s Bruern Abbey school prepares students with dyslexia or other specific learning difficulties for the Common Entrance and other entrance examinations to mainstream independent senior schools. Bellevue’s schools are Mature and well established in the communities they serve. Bellevue’s oldest school was established in 1834, but all Bellevue’s schools benefit from modern teaching and learning practices as well as modern educational facilities. Bellevue largely attracts prospective students from within local communities through its academic reputation and word-of-mouth recommendations from parents. As a result, Bellevue is less reliant than peers on agents and overseas placement agents to secure new enrollments. In addition, surveys of Bellevue’s parents indicate high and improving levels of customer satisfaction, with over 97% of parents strongly agreeing that their child enjoys coming to school. Unlike our schools in the GCC, Bellevue generally caters to UK resident (i.e. non-expatriate) students. As such, Bellevue’s student churn ratio has been under 10% per year in the last three years, and most students who graduate from Bellevue’s schools progress to another independent secondary or grammar school in the United Kingdom. Compared to our schools in the GCC, Bellevue schools operate at higher levels of capacity utilization. As at 31 May 2019, capacity utilization across the Bellevue portfolio was 83%. Bellevue owns the land and real estate on a freehold basis at nine of its 15 schools. Leases on its remaining schools are long dated, with expiries between 2031 to 2037. _History and Development_ Bellevue was established by its current CEO, Mark Malley through the acquisition of an academically failing school in London in 2003. Mr. Malley, a former headmaster of a UK independent school, subsequently built the portfolio to its current state through a strategy of single site acquisitions, using a blend of (i) strategic, niche and profitable schools, (ii) stable and predictable schools with an established market position, (iii) academically or financially underperforming schools and (iv) greenfield development. In June 2018 GEMS Global, a holding company of the Varkey Group, owned by our Executive Vice Chairman, acquired Bellevue from its former owners. Bellevue believes it has a demonstrated track record of successfully overlaying its education best practices in acquired schools in order to drive educational results, which in turn drives high parent satisfaction and occupancy and low churn at its acquired schools. Bellevue has delivered growth in enrollments ahead of local competitors in most schools, and in most instances in advance of the wider independent UK school segment. Bellevue’s strategy is to continue to drive capacity utilization where space exists in existing schools, selectively extend and develop mature sites to grow capacity, and to continue to acquire single site schools where an opportunity for future revenue growth exists. 141 ----- Bellevue has lodged a planning application to develop a new 420-seat secondary school, 19 Mallord Street, located in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, in central London. The application involves the refurbishment of an existing leasehold school site, which is currently vacant. Subject to planning approval, we anticipate opening Mallord Street in the twelve months ended 31 August 2021. In addition to managing its own schools, Bellevue’s management also provide oversight of four independent schools owned by the Varkey Group on an arms-length basis. The following table sets out certain information on Bellevue’s schools as of 31 May 2019:

Subsection Title: Overview of Bellevue Schools Property Status School** **Established Years offered** **Curriculum** **Price point** **Capacity
Subsubsection Text: Ealing Independent College, London . . . . . . . 1992 Ages 14-19 NCEW Premium 160 Leasehold Surval Montreaux, Switzerland . . . . . . . . . . . . 1961 Ages 12-19 IB Premium/Residential 72 Freehold _Management team_ Bellevue has a dedicated UK-based management team, including Mark Malley. Mr. Malley is supported by a supervisory academic team of educationalists, as well as a stand-alone finance and administration team. Following the transaction, Mr. Malley will have a 7.1% shareholding in Bellevue and through certain incentive arrangements, has rights over 19% of Bellevue’s equity by 2021. _Fees and fee increases_ Fees and fee increases for independent schools are unregulated in the United Kingdom and are set with reference to commercial considerations. The average fees in Bellevue’s preparatory schools 142 ----- range from approximately £7,100 to £14,400 per annum, depending on geographic location and services provided. Average fees in Bellevue’s secondary schools are between £16,200 and £25,000 per annum. We believe that Bellevue’s fees are positioned at the lower end of comparable UK independent school fees and therefore present a compelling value for money proposition relative to the academic outcomes delivered. _Academic performance and regulatory framework_ Bellevue aims to deliver exceptional academic outcomes, largely through (i) the recruitment of high quality school leaders and teachers and (ii) the provision of high quality teaching and learning in generally small format schools featuring small class sizes. UK independent schools are inspected periodically by the Independent Schools Inspectorate, which is overseen by the Office for Standards in Education on behalf of the Department of Education. The Independent School Standards framework was introduced in the UK in 2014. Inspections by the Independent Schools Inspectorate (the “ISI”) may be undertaken to assess “compliance only” with the relevant standards, or a combined inspection of “Educational Quality and Compliance”, which consists of a qualitative review of teaching and learning practices within the school. As the inspection cycle for UK independent schools is undertaken on a rolling basis, not all UK independent schools have yet undergone a full inspection under the standards. Of Bellevue’s 14 UK-based schools, all inspected schools met the standards in their last inspection. Furthermore, five schools have completed full Educational Quality and Compliance inspections by the ISI as at 31 May 2019. Each of these schools secured an “Excellent” rating for both quality of academic and other achievement, and for the quality of pupils’ personal development. In addition to external reviews, Bellevue also undertakes a regular review cycle of peer review and assessment, whereby head teachers review other schools in the portfolio to share best practices across the group. This can cover a wide range of areas, including delivery of education, as well as safeguarding, leadership development and curriculum review.

Subsection Title: Overview of Bellevue Schools Property Status School** **Established Years offered** **Curriculum** **Price point** **Capacity
Subsubsection Text: We have exchanged contracts to buy Farlington School, an independent day and boarding school for pupils between ages four and eighteen in Horsham. We will pay approximately £0.9 million at completion on a debt-free cash free basis to the current owners, a charitable trust. Farlington was originally founded in 1896 and educates 233 students. The acquisition will be funded from existing cash resources and we anticipate completing in early September 2019. The property is leased, but we have an option to buy it within three years.

We have comprehensive information technology infrastructure and systems that support our datadriven approach to the management of our business. These systems allow our executive team, regional management, school principals and teachers to monitor and analyze data relating to key operating metrics. Our information technology platform is intended to provide an array of sophisticated and innovative education management systems to (i) ensure that the highest standards of quality education are offered across our school portfolio and (ii) identify any of our schools that are not meeting the required standards or are experiencing operational issues. With the benefit of the centralized monitoring system, we can deploy resources to the affected school to take the relevant action required to resolve these issues in a targeted and effective manner. Furthermore, our enterprise management suite of software allows us to more efficiently manage our Group-wide systems. Our information technology platform and systems are scalable to support the growth of our business. They are managed internally by dedicated IT professionals. We manage the availability of our networks with well-resourced and modern technology. We monitor our systems on a real-time basis to verify the robustness and availability of our servers, network and data storage. Our server infrastructure uses resilient data storage technology and is in a third-party hosted high availability data center. In recent years, pedagogy in schools has increasingly focused on new and innovative digital technologies to support learning. We have embraced this focus on digital learning alongside changes 143 ----- in how the curriculum is delivered to ensure that we prepare our students for the future. Our virtual learning environment provides access to digital content, a virtual library and assignments and quizzes, and promotes student-teacher collaboration. All of our schools have Wi-Fi coverage, either in all areas of the school, thereby supporting our “bring your own device” strategy. In addition, we aim to implement the latest advances in teaching solutions at our schools. Examples of this include robotics and coding programs, interdisciplinary and real world-focused learning, and an emphasis on skills that will be needed in the future. All of our schools are focused on digital and curricular innovation. Technology is integrated into classrooms and learning spaces, allowing full utilization of wireless and interactive touchscreens and the ability to collaborate across devices. Curriculum innovation has focused on new ways of delivering learning experiences through blended programs, global innovation and entrepreneurial challenges, design thinking and new technologies and growth.
The table below shows the number of employees employed in each of our divisions as at 31 August 2016, 2017 and 2018 and 31 May 2019:

Of our total staff of 18,757 as at 31 May 2019, 7,441 were teaching staff, 2,096 were teaching assistants, 1,857 were school administration staff and 7,363 were support staff. We have not experienced any significant staff disputes. The human resources (“HR”) function is centralized and HR policies are uniform across all schools. HR policies are developed through the identification of needs and based on feedback from different stakeholders across the business. Our UAE operations are subject to various federal and Emirate laws that regulate wages, hours, benefits and other terms and conditions relating to employment. Employment relations in the UAE are generally regulated by the UAE labor law (the “UAE Labor Law”). The UAE Labor Law applies to all employees in or within the jurisdiction of the UAE, except for certain specific groups, such as individuals employed by Government bodies and individuals employed by companies registered in the Dubai International Financial Centre. In accordance with the UAE’s employment and immigration rules, all non-UAE-national employees must have a valid residency visa and work permit with their registered employer in the UAE.

We are fully committed to safeguarding the welfare of all our students and recognize our responsibility to take steps to promote safe practices and protect children from harm, abuse and exploitation. We acknowledge our duty to act appropriately in response to any allegations, reports or suspicions of abuse. To fulfill our commitments to safeguard and promote the welfare of children, our policy framework requires us to have: - clear priorities for safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children, explicitly stated in strategic policy documents; - a clear commitment by senior management to the importance of safeguarding and promoting children’s welfare; - a clear line of accountability within the organization for work on safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children; - recruitment and human resources management procedures that take account of the need to safeguard and promote the welfare of students, including arrangements for appropriate checks on new staff and volunteers; 144 ----- - procedures for dealing with allegations of abuse against members of staff and volunteers; - arrangements to ensure that all staff undertake appropriate training to equip them to carry out their responsibilities effectively, and keep this updated by refresher training at regular intervals, and that all staff, including temporary staff and volunteers who work with children, are made aware of the establishment’s arrangements for safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children and their responsibilities for that; - policies for safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children and procedures that are in accordance with guidance and locally agreed inter-agency procedures; - arrangements to work effectively with other organizations to safeguard and promote the welfare of children, including arrangements for sharing information; - a culture of listening to, and engaging in, dialogue with children—seeking children’s views in ways that are appropriate to their age and understanding, and taking account of those views in individual decisions and in the establishment or development of services; - appropriate whistle-blowing procedures, and a culture that enables issues about safeguarding and promoting the welfare of children to be addressed; and - senior leaders who understand the context of Federal Law 3 of the UAE, the guiding Law for Safeguarding and Child Protection. Furthermore, we have a child safeguarding policy, which is based on the following principles: - the welfare of a child or young person will always be paramount; - the welfare of families will be promoted; - the rights, wishes and feelings of children, young people and their families will be respected and listened to; - keeping children safe from harm requires people who work with children to share information; and - those people in positions of responsibility within the organization will work in accordance with the interests of children and follow the policy outlined in the GEMS Policy Framework. We have child protection policies and procedures at the classroom, school and Group levels. These policies and procedures aim to protect students and staff, provide staff and volunteers with the overarching principles that guide schools’ approach to safeguarding students’ welfare and ensure consistently good practice across the schools. At the classroom level, we provide training and practice in standard response protocols and in standard reunification methods and holds school incident management briefings and major incident medical management and support briefings. At the school level, we conduct security risk audits and provide additional child safeguarding resources where necessary, and require that at least 20% of the employees of every school attend mandatory external fire training from a certified training provider. We also have crisis management policies and procedures in place to ensure the safety of our students and staff, including through the use of critical incident response protocols, the establishment of incident management teams and the use of incident reporting software. Furthermore, our recruitment policy requires all applicants to provide references and evidence of identity and qualifications and to be checked for criminal records. At the Group level, we conduct investigations on any security incidents and monitor the results of risk audits. We also set security governance, policies, procedures and standards, evaluate and select security vendors, ensure compliance with applicable security legislation and provide incident response strategy support. In addition, we require all of our employees to complete a series of six health and safety trainings every two years. Our transport business is regulated by the Roads & Transport Authority in Dubai and by the Department of Transport in Abu Dhabi. We have developed procedures to comply with the prescribed safety guidelines in respect of the transportation services that we provide. These procedures include maintaining safety features such as mandatory seat belts for every child seated on our busses, emergency exits, video surveillance monitored by an operations control center, seating capacity specifications and prescribed seat sizes and the implementation of detailed safety checks on all vehicles on a daily basis to ensure compliance with the above safety measures. All of our buses travel with both a trained driver and a separate bus guardian, who is responsible for monitoring safety. We 145 ----- also use a GPS system to track the location of all buses and student swipe cards to track student presence, and we provide panic buttons to alert the operations control center of any issues. In addition, we ensure that all drivers have the required licenses, qualifications and authorizations to transport children, and require drivers to undergo periodic randomized drug and alcohol testing. We are in the process of installing additional safety equipment in buses, including computerized real time monitoring to detect distracted or fatigued drivers.

We are committed to ensuring a healthy and safe environment for our students and employees and are subject to various health and safety requirements. To comply with these requirements, we have adopted applicable policies and procedures, which are implemented across the school portfolio. We have also adopted and implemented the global standard for health and safety management systems (BS OHSAS 18001) covering schools in the UAE and Qatar. The implementation has been validated by a certified third party. We take steps to comply with all relevant health and safety legislation and requirements. Whenever related issues are identified, they are brought to the attention of management and/or the Board. We seek to address such issues promptly and monitor and follow up as appropriate. In addition, the internal audit team undertakes a regular review of these policies and procedures across our operations to monitor compliance. The internal audit team’s findings are reviewed by the Audit and Risk Committee of the Board, as well as by the CEO and COO. In relation to building safety policies, we have adopted procedures to comply with the guidelines and recommendations prescribed by the relevant regulatory authorities in each of the regions in which our schools operate. These procedures include, but are not limited to, building design, fire risk assessment and emergency procedures. We are also required to comply with certain environmental requirements. In addition, the internal audit team undertakes a regular review of the environmental standards across our operations to ensure that the applicable policies are being adhered to. The internal audit team’s findings are reviewed by the Audit and Risk Committee of the Board, as well as by the CEO and COO. Furthermore, ISO certification 14001 on environment and ISO certification 9001 on quality have been awarded to STS.

Subsection Title: Relationship with GEMS Global, the Varkey Group and the Founder
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we benefit from our affiliation with GEMS Global, which owns and operates a separate portfolio of schools in countries across Africa, East Asia, Europe and North America. GEMS Global is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Varkey Group (which is controlled by the Founder). Since we were separated from GEMS Global in 2014, GEMS Global has extended its operations into the digital space with the acquisitions of Pamoja Education Limited, the exclusive online provider of the IB curriculum, and Oxford Study Courses Limited, a provider of IB revision courses. It has also invested in several EdTech funds. This has enabled us to complement our physical schools business with online learning opportunities. Substantially all of our school construction has historically been undertaken by CMC (a Varkey Group Affiliate). CMC is a construction and interior fit-out company, with over 35 years of experience in the construction industry. See “—Business—The School Operations division—Development of new _schools and expansion of existing schools—Contractor Engagement” and “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions” for further information in respect of our relationship with GEMS Global, the_ Varkey Group and the Founder.

Our headquarters are currently located at Sheikh Zayed Road, Dubai. We use several asset ownership models to operate our school buildings, including an Owned schools model, a Leased schools model, a mixed model and a sale and leaseback model. For further details on these ownership models, see “—Our Business—The School Operations division—Approach to _operation of our schools”. For further details on how individual schools are owned, see “—Our Business—The School Operations division—School categories”._ 146 -----

We are actively involved in various corporate and social responsibility activities, primarily through our support of the Varkey Foundation, a charitable foundation set up by the Founder in 2010, which we intend to continue to support. The Varkey Foundation is a not-for-profit organization established to improve standards of education for underprivileged children throughout the world. It is active in developing teachers’ abilities and supporting advocacy campaigns to promote excellence in teaching practices worldwide. It provides grants to partner organizations that offer innovative solutions in support of its mission. Recent major initiatives by the Varkey Foundation, which have been partly funded by us, include the Global Teacher Prize and the Global Education and Skills Forum, an annual event bringing together world leaders from the public, private and social sectors seeking solutions to achieving education, equity and employment for all. We have also partnered with the KHDA to provide scholarship grants and educational support for Emirati students in our Dubai schools as part of the Mohammed Bin Rashid Distinguished Students Programme and with the MOE to sponsor the Emirates Innovative Teacher Award until 2021.

We are the applicant or registrant of 97 trademarks relating primarily to our logos and the name “GEMS” and “GEMS Education” throughout the regions in which we operate and worldwide (save for India). We are also the applicant or registrant of trademarks relating to the School Support Services. We have registered 114 domain names, including www.gemseducation.com. We seek to manage and protect our intellectual property for ourselves and GEMS Global.

We maintain insurance cover in respect of various insurable risks under a range of insurance policies. These include property, fire and consequential loss, public liability, money insurance, fidelity guarantee, personal injury and medical malpractice. Assets are covered on a replacement cost basis. We also have in place insurance cover for our teachers and staff, such as credit life insurance, credit card insurance, travel insurance, transportation business, mortgage property insurance and mortgage life insurance.

From time to time, we are involved in litigation in the ordinary course of our business activities, such as disputes with customers, contractors, suppliers and tax authorities. Neither the Company, nor any member of the Group, is or has been involved in any governmental, legal or arbitration proceedings (including any such proceedings that are pending or threatened of which our management is aware) during the 12 months preceding the date of this Offering Memorandum that may have, or have had, a significant effect on our financial position or profitability. 147 -----

The information in the following section has been provided for background purposes. The information has been extracted from a variety of sources released by public and private organizations as described in “Market and Industry Data.” The Company confirms that the information in this section has been accurately reproduced from these sources and, as far as the Company is aware and is able to ascertain from information published by these sources, no facts have been omitted which would render the reproduced information inaccurate or misleading. Industry publications, surveys and forecasts generally state that the information contained therein has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. The Company believes that these industry publications, surveys and forecasts are broadly reliable, but the Company has not independently verified them and cannot guarantee their accuracy or completeness. The projections and forward-looking statements in this section are not guarantees of future performance and actual events and circumstances could differ materially from current expectations. Numerous factors could cause or contribute to such differences. See “Risk Factors” and “Forward_Looking Statements.”

The UAE Ministry of Education was established in 1971 and is responsible for all aspects of education in the UAE. It is also responsible for planning, implementing, supervising and harmonizing the education system including between the various Emirates of the UAE. The education sector is regulated separately in each of the seven Emirates of the UAE: Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Sharjah, Ajman, Umm Al Quwain, Ras Al Khaimah and Fujairah. In 2014, the UAE launched the UAE National Agenda (the “National Agenda”), which sets out a number of objectives required to achieve the UAE Vision 2021 across sectors, including education, health, economy, police, housing, infrastructure and government services. The eight objectives applicable to the education sector are: - to be among the 20 highest performing countries in the Programme for International Student Assessment, an international test of knowledge and skills for 15-year-old students in reading, mathematics and science; - to be among the highest 15 performing countries in Trends in Mathematics and Science Study (“TIMSS”), an international test for students in grades 4 and 8; - to ensure that 98% of Emirati students complete their high school education; - to ensure that 95% of children in the UAE attend pre-primary education; - to ensure that 90%. of grade 9 students develop high skills in Arabic language in the UAE National Agenda Parameter assessment; - to ensure that 100%. of schools have high-quality teachers; - to ensure that 100%. of public schools have highly-effective school leadership; and - to ensure that no students need to join the UAE University Foundation Programme, a one-year program which helps students transition from high school to university by building up their communication skills and mathematics proficiency. In connection with the National Agenda, the UAE has published a schools inspection framework (the “Unified Schools Inspection Framework”), which is designed to provide a shared set of quality standards to underpin the UAE’s drive to meet its objectives under the National Agenda. Different Emirates have interpreted the Unified Schools Inspection Framework differently, including with regards to the frequency of inspections; and the thresholds for particular ranking outcomes. However, broadly, all schools in the UAE are inspected periodically, and assessed and reviewed on a similar basis. Dubai has the longest history of inspection under the current framework. To provide a rating for each school, inspectors use the following six-point scale, set out in the Unified Schools Inspection Framework, to express judgements on the overall performance of a school (the “UAE Performance Indicators”): - Outstanding: Quality of performance substantially exceeds the expectation of the UAE; - Very Good: Quality of performance exceeds the expectation of the UAE; - Good: Quality of performance meets the expectation of the UAE—this is the desired level for every school in the UAE; - Acceptable: Quality of performance meets the minimum level of quality required in the UAE—this is the minimum level for every school in the UAE; 148 ----- - Weak: Quality of performance is below the expectation of the UAE; and - Very Weak: Quality of performance is significantly below the expectation of the UAE. The inspection process involves a self-evaluation process completed by the schools, followed by a review of the schools by an independent and experienced inspection team. The inspection teams spend approximately three to five days in each school under review, measuring the school’s performance against its self-evaluation and the Unified Schools Inspection Framework. All schools are expected to have school improvement plans in place, regardless of their initial evaluation results. In March 2018, the UAE Ministry of Education implemented the Teacher Licensing System, which requires all teachers in the UAE to be obtain a UAE teaching license by the end of 2020.
