To obtain a license, teachers will be required to pass several examinations, depending on their status and existing qualifications, as recognized by the UAE. Following the deadline at the end of 2020, all schools operating in the UAE will be required to ensure that their teachers hold valid teaching licenses.

Private schools in the UAE are subject to the overarching federal rules of the UAE Ministry of Education in respect of fee increases. Under these rules, private schools can increase fees by a maximum of 10% one year after the last increase, 20% two years after the last increase and 30% three years after the last increase. In addition to the federal rules, individual Emirates have implemented additional frameworks for private school fee increases, as set out below.

The principal regulators of education in Dubai are the UAE Ministry of Education, in respect of nurseries, government schools and onshore universities, and the KHDA, in respect of private schools, early learning centers, training institutes and free zone university campuses. The KHDA is responsible for the growth and quality of private education in Dubai. The KHDA’s aims and objectives are to ensure the continuous development of, and investment in, the education sector and to improve the quality and outcomes of education at all stages. Executive Council Resolution No (2) of 2017 establishes a legal framework to improve and strengthen the private schools sector in the interests of parents, school operators and investors in Dubai. The resolution provides an open and transparent framework for how private schools in Dubai are regulated. It clearly sets out KHDA requirements for opening and maintaining a school, as well as offering details on associated costs. Our transport activities and security activities in Dubai are regulated by the Roads and Transport Authority and the Security Industry Regulatory Agency, respectively. Furthermore, across the UAE, the Telecommunications Regulatory Authority regulates our security and surveillance business in relation to its school transport activities and the UAE Ministry of Human Resources and Emiratization regulates our employment activities.

The Dubai School Inspection Bureau (“DSIB”) was established by the Executive Council of the Government of Dubai in 2007 to produce a comprehensive assessment of educational standards and school performance for both public and private sector schools in Dubai. The DSIB’s mandate includes: - ensuring that the educational quality of all schools in Dubai has been assessed using an authoritative inspection method; - developing a high-caliber local workforce capable of building and sustaining a world-class inspection organization; - assisting with the improvement of all schools through school inspection; - ensuring that effective remedial action is taken when an inspection identifies schools which have serious weaknesses; 149 ----- - giving parents useful and reliable information about school quality which will assist parents in the school selection choice; and - providing policy-makers and others with an authoritative account of school quality in Dubai. The evaluation of every school in Dubai is based on certain key criteria that are used to judge the overall performance of a school. Such criteria are based on the Unified Schools Inspection Framework and include, but are not limited to, how well the students are progressing in key subjects, how well the students are developing on a personal and social level, the standard of teaching, learning and assessment at the relevant school, how closely the curriculum meets the educational needs of the student, the arrangements in place for the care and support, and health and safety (including protection and safeguarding) of students and the standard of leadership and management of the school. In Dubai, inspection outcomes are published by the KHDA in both English and Arabic, and are made readily available to prospective parents.

In Dubai, the price point of new schools is established on purely commercial grounds. The price point of a school forms part of our initial application to the KHDA for a new school license, but the opening price point is not regulated. Thereafter, fees are governed by the KHDA School Fees Framework which applies to all private schools in Dubai. The School Fees Framework applies to all tuition fees and to any fees or costs related to services that are provided directly by the schools, and generally governs the mechanism by which school fees can be increased each year. The School Fees Framework has evolved since it was first introduced, and was most recently revised in July 2019 with effect from the 2019-2020 academic year. Once a school is established, the operator is not permitted to increase that school’s tuition fees in the three years following the date of commencement of educational activity. Thereafter, schools cannot increase fees without prior approval from the KHDA. In Dubai, school tuition fees are regulated by the KHDA based on two factors: an annually-adjusted inflation benchmark, the ECI, and a multiplier. Prior to the 2019 revision, the KHDA framework permitted schools to raise fees by a multiplier of ECI linked to the then-prevailing DSIB score of the school. This generally allowed us to raise fees by an amount in excess of inflation. Following the 2019 revision, the multiplier is driven by whether the school has achieved positive or negative changes in its rating from the DSIB. The multiplier is structured to incentivize school operators to invest in their schools in order to raise their ratings. If a school’s rating is upgraded, it can increase fees by the multiplier set out in the following table. If the school’s rating is downgraded, the school will not be able to increase fees by any amount in the coming year. The following table sets out the multiplier applicable to various ratings movements:

Eligible schools that have maintained the same rating of the previous ECI year[(1)] Schools that have improved their rating from[(1)]: ECI x 2 Very Weak to Weak Weak to Acceptable Acceptable to Good Schools that have improved their rating from[(1)]: ECI x 1.75 Good to Very Good Schools that have improved their rating from: ECI x 1.5 Very Good to Outstanding Schools that have dropped in performance (from their current rating to a No increase in school fees lower one)[(1)] Note: (1) For profit schools in Dubai, the last inspection rating conducted by DSIB will be considered while implementing the fee increase as per the above table. 150 ----- The ECI is determined annually by the DSC and is based on historically observed inflation in the costs of operating a school, as determined by the DSC. The applicable ECI is typically announced in advance of an academic year, allowing school operators to communicate fee increase guidance to parents prior to seeking parental re-enrollment intentions. The ECI was 2.9% for the 2015–2016 academic year, 3.2% for the 2016–2017 academic year, 2.4% for the 2017–2018 academic year. No ECI was formally communicated for the 2018-2019 academic year, and in accordance with a directive from Dubai’s Executive Council, school operators were not permitted to raise fees for Dubai Schools in that academic year, at which point the school fee framework was reviewed and revised. In April 2019, the Dubai Statistics Centre announced that the ECI relevant for fee increases for academic year 2019-2020 is 2.07%. Schools with performance ratings “Acceptable” and lower are required to submit (as part of their application), a KHDA approved action plan detailing how the school will invest in the educational process to improve the quality of education in the school. If a school chooses to restructure its tuition fees to a lower fee structure, they cannot then revert back to the previous fees, and all fee increases (according to the fee framework) will be applicable to the restructured fees. Fee increases meant for a particular academic year can only be implemented in that year and cannot be carried forward to upcoming academic years. In the interest of transparency, the KHDA now requires private schools to enter into a parent-school contract for every student prior to the beginning of each academic year, which lists out all fees charged by the school during the academic year. The KHDA has also historically considered applications for exceptions to the general framework for fee increases (subject to certain conditions laid out in the framework).

The principal regulator of education in Abu Dhabi is the Abu Dhabi Department of Education and Knowledge (“ADEK”). ADEK seeks to: (a) develop education and educational institutions in Abu Dhabi; (b) implement innovative educational policies, plans and programs that aim to improve education; and (c) support educational institutions and staff to achieve the objectives of national development in accordance with the highest international standards. Operators wishing to open a new school must apply to ADEK for a provisional license. New schools are inspected after they have obtained their provisional licenses and have started operation. If the inspection confirms that the school is operating at least satisfactorily in relation to ADEK’s inspection standards, ADEK will issue the school with a full license. In addition, ADEK has laid out specific guidelines for the opening of new schools and evaluates all new school applications based on this set of guidelines. The school owner in respect of the third party private education schools managed by us in Abu Dhabi is responsible for obtaining the required licensing, fee and other operational approvals.

The Private Schools and Quality Assurance Sector was established in 2010 to assist ADEK in regulating, licensing, inspecting and supporting private schools in order to achieve ADEK’s standards, requirements and expectations. All private schools are required by law to register with ADEK and be inspected. ADEK applies the Unified Schools Inspection Framework, however, unlike Dubai, private schools are inspected generally every 18-24 months. The Private Schools and Quality Assurance Sector’s Inspection and Monitoring Division oversees an inspection and school improvement programme that ensures that all schools are meeting safety, wellbeing and educational quality standards in line with the Schools Inspection Framework. 151 ----- In order to provide a rating for each school, inspectors use the UAE Performance Indicators to express judgements on the overall performance of a school. As in Dubai, inspection outcomes are published by ADEK in both English and Arabic, and are made readily available to prospective parents.

In addition to the operational rules of the UAE Ministry of Education (as detailed above), ADEK has also implemented procedures for schools in the Emirate of Abu Dhabi to follow when applying for fee increases. For new schools, fees are approved by the regulator in advance of opening. ADEK will take into account the school’s supporting materials, a comparison of the requested fee level with the fee levels in similar schools providing an equivalent educational service, and the cost of the relevant school’s facilities and services. Under the current fee framework, which was introduced in February 2019, Schools in Abu Dhabi that are eligible to apply for a fee increase for the 2019-20 academic year are those that have: - operated for more than three years; - had a valid license at the start of the 2019-2020 academic year; and - submitted IFRS-compliant audited financial statements for the 2016-2017 and 2017-2018 academic years. Fee increases for the 2019-2020 academic year will be granted based on two factors: the Abu Dhabi Education Cost Index (“ADECI”) (set at 2.31% in the 2019-2020 academic year) and a school’s rating, as set out in the following table:

Outstanding . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ADECI x 1.75 Very Good . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ADECI x 1.50 Good . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ADECI x 1.25 Acceptable . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ADECI x 1 Weak . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ADECI x 1 Very Weak . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ADECI x 1 In March 2019, ADEK introduced an exceptional fee increase framework for the 2019-2020 academic year. If a school has made a loss, based on Adjusted EBITDA, for the last two academic years (as validated by the school’s independent auditors), and the school has occupancy levels of 80% of greater, then it will be eligible to apply for an exceptional fee increase, in addition to the ADECI-linked increase. A school cannot be awarded an exceptional fee increase for two years in a row. The actual quantum of exceptional fee increase would be decided by the ADEK committee on a school-by-school basis.

Education in Sharjah is regulated by a newly established regulator; the Sharjah Private Education Authority (“SPEA”); which replaced the previous administrative entity the Sharjah Education Zone in November 2018. The SPEA aims to organize private education in the emirate of Sharjah, raise the quality of private education through the application of best educational practices and encourage the provision of distinguished services in the field. The SPEA is responsible for developing public policies and strategic plans for private education, proposing the necessary legislation to regulate and develop private education in the Emirate, approving penalties for violating the regulations and requirements related to private education and presenting this legislation to the council for adoption. The SPEA has the authority to grant a license to operate private education facilities in Sharjah in coordination with other relevant authorities. It also receives complaints and submits proposals related to private education policy.

Private schools are required to obtain approval from the SPEA, and to file annual comprehensive reports with the SPEA. In the 2018-2019 academic year, the SPEA has started to implement an 152 ----- inspection regime similar to that employed in Dubai and Abu Dhabi. Provisional results have been provided to operators, although inspection results have not yet been publicly made available.

Private schools in Sharjah are required to request proposed fee increases directly from the UAE Ministry of Education. Any proposed fee increases are subject to the maximum permitted increase of 10% one year after the last increase, 20% two years after the last increase and 30% three years after the last increase. The SPEA also has the authority to unilaterally approve tuition fee increases of schools in Sharjah. We believe the new process under the SPEA is likely to remain largely unchanged.

Private schools in Fujairah and Ras Al Khaimah are required to request proposed fee increases from the UAE Ministry of Education through the FEZ and RAKEZ, respectively. Any proposed fee increases are subject to the maximum permitted increase of 10% one year after the last increase, 20% two years after the last increase and 30% three years after the last increase. Schools are inspected by the FEZ or RAKEZ, as applicable, and fee increases are permitted on the basis of bilateral negotiations between school operators and the relevant authorities on a case-by-case basis

Education in Fujairah is regulated by the Fujairah Education Zone (“FEZ”) and in Ras Al Khaimah by the Ras Al Khaimah Education Zone (“RAKEZ”), which are administrative bodies of the UAE Ministry of Education. The quality assurance and inspection and fee framework regimes in Fujairah and Ras Al Khaimah follow the guidelines set by the UAE Ministry of Education with the aim of: - advancing the national educational objectives and participating in the development of a national educational system for the benefit of the whole society; - providing appropriate educational opportunities for the children of non-citizens who live in the UAE; - providing a quality alternative to the public school system; and - encouraging competition among private schools that will lead to improved educational quality. Beginning in academic year 2018-2019, schools in Ras Al Khaimah and Fujairah were inspected by the UAE Ministry of Education using an inspection regime and framework similar to that employed in Dubai and Abu Dhabi. Inspection outcomes for schools in these areas were made confidentially available to school operators for the first time in academic year 2018-2019 but have not been publicly disclosed by the MoE.

Subsection Title: UAE regulations on transfers of foreign exchange
Subsubsection Text: Neither the federal government of the UAE nor the individual Emirates impose foreign exchange controls.

The key legislation governing and regulating the education sector and private schools in Qatar (together, the “Qatar Education Laws”) includes: (i) Law No. (23) of 2015 (“Private Schools Law”); (ii) Emiri Decree No. (16) of 2014, as amended, setting out the mandates of various Qatar ministries (“Ministries Decree”); (iii) Emiri Decree No. (9) of 2016 on the organizational structure of the Qatar Ministry of Education and Higher Education (“Qatar MoE”) (“Qatar MoE Decree”); (iv) Ministerial Resolution No. (40) of 2017 issuing the Executive Regulations of the Private Schools Law (“Executive Regulations”); and (v) Law No. (12) of 2017 concerning the amendment of some provisions in the education laws in Qatar. Pursuant to the Qatar Education Laws, the education sector in Qatar is overseen and regulated by the Qatar MoE. The Ministries Decree provides that the Qatar MoE has the authority (amongst others) to: (i) oversee education affairs in Qatar; (ii) set out the various educational stages, including putting together the curricula and the examination rules; and (iii) license and oversee schools and higher education institutions. 153 ----- In accordance with the Qatar MoE Decree, the following departments within the Qatar MoE are involved in the oversight and supervision of private schools in Qatar: - Private Schools’ Affairs Department, which oversees the affairs of students in private education, sets rules and guidelines on students’ admission and registration, monitors the implementation of the curricula, processes the imposition of penalties and proposes policies relating to school fees; - Private Schools’ Licensing Department, which makes assessments on the need for private schooling in Qatar and develops standards and requirements for licensing (including receiving and evaluating licensing applications and issuing licenses); - Students’ Assessment Department, which deals with putting together the timing of academic years and determines regulations for the assessment of students; - Schools’ Assessment Department, which regulates educational and disciplinary processes in schools, assesses private schools and grants appropriate accreditation.

Private school standards are outlined in both the Private Schools Law and the Executive Regulations, which govern the licensing and operation of private schools, including areas such as curriculum, staffing and employment policies, facilities, school building standards, bank guarantee requirements, record keeping and penalties. The Private Schools Law and the Executive Regulations collectively set out the requirements with which private schools must comply in order to obtain and maintain their license(s), granted by the Private Schools Licensing Department at the Qatar MoE. The above-mentioned law and regulations are also from time to time supplemented by instructions which are issued directly by the Qatar MoE or the relevant departments to private school operators. Unlike in the UAE, there is no inspection regime or regulatory body which assesses the quality of private schools operating in Qatar.

Fees are approved and regulated by the Qatar MoE, both on commencement of a school’s operation and on an ongoing basis. All fees to be imposed by a private school operator (including any increases from time to time) must be approved by the Qatar MoE. Currently, fees are classified by the Qatar MoE as: (i) tuition fees which are paid at the beginning of each academic term and must not be amended during such term; (ii) additional fees (to cover, for example, seat reservation, entrance exams and registration); and (iii) additional optional fees (to cover, for example, transportation fees or stationery costs).

Subsubsection Title: Regulations on Transfers of Foreign Exchange
Subsubsection Text: With the exception of certain transfers or dealings involving the Israeli Shekel, Qatar does not generally impose foreign exchange controls. Whilst we are not currently aware of any restrictions being imposed by the Qatar Central Bank or any other competent authority in Qatar in connection with transferring funds from Qatar to entities incorporated elsewhere in the GCC, there may be restrictions imposed by authorities in the jurisdiction of the relevant receiving bank(s). As at the date of this Prospectus, we are not aware of any such restrictions being imposed by authorities in the UAE. Equity capital, loan capital, interest, dividends, branch profits, royalties and management fees can be freely remitted, subject to payment of any applicable taxes. Additionally, in accordance with the guidance provided by the Qatar Central Bank, there are no restrictions on foreign exchange or on the repatriation or remittance of any monies from Qatar, provided that the source to which the monies are being transferred is clearly identified. 154 -----

The following table lists the names, positions and ages of the members of the board of directors (the “Board”) (the “Directors”) of GMHL upon completion of the CVC Consortium acquisition of a 30.5% stake in GMHL. The Shareholders of GMHL and GMCL intend to appoint an independent chairman to the board shortly following the Offering. The Board comprises 11 seats, of which CVC has a right to appoint up to three, GEMS Global has the right to appoint up to five, DJ PledgeCo has the right to appoint up to two, and one is independent. CVC has appointed Rolly Van Rappard, Jan Reinier Voûte and Özgür Önder to represent its three seats on the board, GEMS Global has appointed Sunny Varkey and Sir Michael Locket to together represent its five seats on the board, and DJ PledgeCo has appointed Dino Varkey to represent its two seats on the board. Sir Michael Peat shall be the independent director.

Sir Michael Peat . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 69 Non-Executive Chairman 23 April 2018 Sunny Varkey . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 62 Founder and Executive Vice To be appointed Chairman[(1)] Dino Varkey . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 38 Chief Executive Officer[(2)] 25 July 2014 Jay Varkey . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 35 Non-Executive Director[(2)] 25 July 2014 Rolly Van Rappard . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 58 Non-Executive Director To be appointed Jan Reinier Voûte . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 46 Non-Executive Director To be appointed Özgür Önder . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 42 Non-Executive Director To be appointed Sir Michael Locket . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 71 Non-Executive Director To be appointed Notes: (1) Sunny Varkey, the Founder and Executive Vice Chairman, is the father of Dino Varkey, the Chief Executive Officer of the Group, and Jay Varkey, a Non-Executive Director. (2) Dino Varkey, the Chief Executive Officer of the Group, and Jay Varkey, a Non-Executive Director, are brothers. The business address of each of the Directors is GEMS Education, GEMS Education Building, Sheikh Zayed Road, Dubai, United Arab Emirates, P.O. Box 8607. The management experience and expertise of each of the Directors is set out below.

Sir Michael Peat has been the Chairman of our Company since July 2014. He was re-appointed to this role on 23 April 2018. Sir Michael studied law at Oxford, qualified as a Chartered Accountant in 1975 and obtained an MBA at INSEAD in 1977. He became a partner in KPMG (London) in 1985. He led a consultancy study into the management and finances of the Royal Household during 1986-87 and was subsequently asked to implement his recommendations. He did this initially on secondment from KPMG, before joining the Royal Household in 1993. Positions held in the Royal Household included Keeper of the Privy Purse and Treasurer to The Queen, Receiver General of The Duchy of Lancaster, Principal Private Secretary to The Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall, member of the Duchy of Cornwall’s Council and chairman of The Prince’s Charities Foundation. He retired from the Royal Household in 2011. He is now chairman of CQS, senior independent non-executive director of Evraz plc, an independent non-executive director of M&C Saatchi plc and an independent non-executive director of Arbuthnot Latham & Co Ltd. Sir Michael was a fellow of Eton College from 2002 to 2011, is an honorary fellow of Trinity College Oxford and is the 2018 recipient of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales Outstanding Achievement Award.

Subsection Title: Sunny Varkey—Founder and Executive Vice Chairman
Subsubsection Text: As its founder, Mr. Sunny Varkey has been with the Group since its inception. He developed the Group from a single school in Dubai into one of the world’s largest providers of high quality private education and related services. 155 ----- Mr. Varkey is also a trustee of the Varkey Foundation. The Varkey Foundation is a not-for-profit organization established to improve standards of education for underprivileged children throughout the world. Recent major initiatives by the Varkey Foundation include the Global Teacher Prize and the Global Education and Skills Forum. Prior to founding the Group, Mr. Varkey was involved in several entrepreneurial ventures, including the establishment of Emirates Healthcare Ltd, a group of high quality hospitals and primary care centers in Dubai, which at the time of sale to Mediclinic International was the largest private healthcare company in the UAE. Under Mr. Varkey’s stewardship, the Group has won numerous local, regional, and international awards. Mr. Varkey’s personal contribution to the development of the education sector of the UAE has also been recognized on numerous occasions, including in 2011 when the United Arab Emirates Ministry of Education conferred an award of distinction on him for his service to education. His contribution to education was further recognized in 2012 when he was named a UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador for Education Partnerships in recognition of his contribution to forging innovative public and private partnerships to ensure that underprivileged children across the world receive good-quality education. The Indian Government honored him in 2009 with the Padmashri Award, one of the highest civilian honors, and the Rajiv Gandhi Award for Eminent Educationist in 2008.

Subsection Title: Dino Varkey—Chief Executive Officer and Board Member
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Dino Varkey joined the Group in 2003 and, as Chief Executive Officer of the Group, spearheads the global strategic development of the Group. He is the third generation of an education family, driven by providing access to quality education for over 55 years. Mr. Varkey has been active in the ongoing development of strategic relationships, including government, regulatory, sector specialists and business partners—to ensure the achievement of the organization’s growth aspirations and continued sector leadership. He is responsible for providing vision, leadership and direction across the Group as it looks to fulfil its mission to be the world’s leading provider of quality education, enriching the lives of millions of children. Mr. Varkey graduated from GEMS Modern Academy in 1992 and is an Honors graduate with a Bachelor’s Degree in Business Studies from the University of Sheffield, UK, a Young Presidents’ Organization (“YPO”) member, and the Education Co-chair of the YPO Dubai Chapter.

Mr. Van Rappard is the co-founder and co-chairman of CVC and joined CVC in 1989. He is on the board of the CVC Capital Partners advisory business and is also a member of the CVC Credit Partners Advisory Board. He is a member of the Europe/Americas, CVC Strategic Opportunities and Asia investment committees. Prior to joining CVC, Mr. Van Rappard worked for Citicorp in corporate finance in London and Amsterdam. Mr. Van Rappard holds an MA Degree in Economics from Columbia University, New York, and an LLM from the University of Utrecht, Netherlands.

Mr. Voûte is a partner and co-head of CVC’s Strategic Opportunities investment platform. He joined CVC in 1999. Mr. Voûte co-founded CVC Strategic Opportunities, is currently co-head and sits on CVC’s Strategic Opportunities Board. He is based in Amsterdam. Prior to joining CVC, he worked as a consultant for McKinsey & Company. Mr. Voûte holds an MBA from INSEAD and a Master’s Degree in Econometrics from Erasmus University, Rotterdam.

Mr. Önder is a managing director of CVC. He joined CVC in 2008. Mr. Önder is based in London. Prior to joining CVC, Mr. Önder worked at UBS Investment Bank. Mr. Önder holds an MBA from Harvard Business School, as well as a BA Degree in Economics and BAS in Systems Science from University of Pennsylvania where he was a Simon Kuznets Fellow. 156 -----

Mr. Jay Varkey is the executive director of the Varkey Group and is responsible for the development of the Europe, Americas and Edtech ventures of the Varkey Group. Mr. Varkey is passionate about education and as such serves as Chairman of the Board of trustees for Varkey Foundation, which supports teacher training in underdeveloped markets as well as the Global Teacher Prize which recognizes excellence in teaching through its $1 million annual award. Mr. Varkey holds an MBA from Columbia Business School and London Business School along with an MA from the University of Edinburgh.

Sir Michael’s career began in advertising and has spanned marketing, high-level campaigning, event management and reputation building. His first business was LIVE, a live marketing company. He was involved in London’s successful bid to host the 2012 Olympic Games, as well as the winning campaigns for the Sochi Winter Olympics in 2014 and Rio de Janeiro in 2016. In 2012, Sir Michael directed the Thames Diamond Jubilee River Pageant and chaired the companies which handled the Royal launch of The Shard, the Opening and Closing Ceremonies for the London Olympics and Paralympics, and the 2013 G8 summit. He is currently the chairman and director of Audley, a business which focuses on leadership consultancy, he is also one of the founding directors of Populus, a director of the CTN Group and a director of Grace Blue. He is a trustee of The Oracle Cancer Trust, The Varkey Foundation, and the International Rescue Committee. Sir Michael was a member of the board of directors of GMCL from January 2015 until April 2018.
The Group’s current senior management, in addition to the Executive Directors listed above, is as follows:

Sir Christopher Stone . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 61 Chief Education Officer Edward Senior . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 40 Acting Chief Financial Officer Elmarie Ventner . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 46 Chief Enrolment, Marketing, Communications and Corporate Relations Officer Asad Zafar . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 54 Head of M&A[(1)] Rupert Brown . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 43 Chief People Officer Paul Scarr . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 49 Interim General Counsel Notes: (1) Mr Asad Zafar is a secondee to GEMS from the Varkey Group. The management experience and expertise of each of the Senior Management team is set out below.

Sir Christopher Stone joined the Group as the Chief Education Officer in 2015. He is responsible for overseeing the quality of teaching, learning and curricula across all the Group schools across the UAE. He is also Deputy Chief Academic Officer for the Group Academic Council and is a member of the senior management committee. First appointed as a principal in the UK in 1995, Sir Christopher went on to lead a number of schools and was made a National Leader of Education by the UK’s National College of School Leadership in 2008. Prior to joining the Group, he was CEO of the Arthur Terry Learning Partnership, a multiacademy trust in the UK, from 2009. Sir Christopher received a knighthood in 2013, in recognition of his outstanding service to education.

Mr. Senior joined the Group in 2016. He is the Deputy Chief Financial Officer, and since November 2018, has been the acting Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Senior was formerly Head of Corporate Finance and Investor Relations for the Group. Prior to joining the Group, Mr. Senior worked as an investment banker with Morgan Stanley from 2006 until 2016, working in the company’s Sydney, Hong Kong, Dubai and London offices. Mr. Senior started his investment banking career at ABN AMRO in New Zealand in 2004. 157 ----- Mr. Senior holds a Bachelor’s degree (Honors) in Middle Eastern studies from the School of Oriental & African Studies, University of London, and undertook further postgraduate studies at the University of Adelaide.

Subsection Title: Elmarie Ventner—Chief Enrolment, Marketing, Communications and Corporate Relations Officer
Subsubsection Text: Mrs. Elmarie Venter is the Chief Enrolments, Marketing, Communications & Corporate Relations Officer. She joined GEMS in 2006 and has held various senior roles in the business. Mrs. Ventner and her team focus on developing and implementing strategies to meet the enrolment targets and to provide world-class brand strategy and standards, communications, media relations, customer insight and digital tools and assets. Mrs. Ventner has more than 25 years of extensive experience in product and business development. Prior to working for GEMS, she held key positions in several multi-national companies where she was responsible for business development, driving revenue and building relationships with external businesses.

Mr. Zafar joined the Varkey Group, a GEMS shareholder, as Global Head of M&A in 2018 and is currently seconded to GEMS, where he is responsible for overseeing the group’s business development and M&A activities globally. Previously, he was Managing Director and Head of Investments at Fajr, a leading private equity investment firm based in Dubai that he helped to establish in 2009. Prior to Fajr, Mr. Zafar gained experience in advisory, corporate banking, corporate finance, project finance and investment banking in roles at Bank of America, CIBC, Deloitte and HSBC

Rupert Brown joined the Group as the Chief People Officer in 2019. He is responsible for leading the development and execution of the group wide people strategy at GEMS to support continued growth and quality improvements. Before joining GEMS Education, Mr. Brown has overseen human resources teams for major global companies across a variety of business sectors, including in the education sector as Vice President of HR for Knowledge Universe, a pre-school education group. Mr. Brown joined GEMS from A.P. Moller Maersk, and has served as Global Head of Commercial HR. Prior to this he worked with Gillette Group and Procter & Gamble in international human resources roles. Mr. Brown holds a Master’s degree in Personnel Management and Industrial Relations from the University of Manchester, UK and is a fellow of the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development.

Mr. Paul Scarr has been the Group’s Interim General Counsel since December 2018, and initially joined the Group as a senior legal consultant in January 2018. Mr. Scarr is responsible for managing the legal function of the Group, including advising senior management and the board on legal issues and risk, supporting the Group on strategic projects and M&A and providing legal support in relation to the day-to-day operations of the business. Prior to joining the Group Mr. Scarr spent 22 years as a corporate lawyer in leading international law firms, including 13 years at Herbert Smith Freehills where he as was a partner in the global corporate practice. Mr. Scarr holds a Bachelor of Laws and Diploma in Legal Practice from the University of Edinburgh.

The U.S. Co-Issuer is controlled by its sole member, the Cayman Co-Issuer. The Cayman Co-Issuer, in its capacity as sole member has appointed a President to have general executive charge, management and control of the business and operations of the U.S. Co-Issuer and a Secretary to have charge of the U.S. Co-Issuer’s books. On June 11, 2019 Dino Varkey was appointed President of the U.S. Co-Issuer and Alexandra Alvarez Minoff was appointed Secretary of the U.S. Co-Issuer. The business address of Dino Varkey and Alexandra Alvarez Minoff is GEMS Education, GEMS Education Building, Sheikh Zayed Road, Dubai, United Arab Emirates, P.O. Box 8607. 158 -----

The regulatory frameworks that apply in each of the markets within which we currently operate, and each of its target markets, differ in both scope and approach. In certain markets, regulators are authorized to influence and/or determine key inputs of our schools (such as school fees). Our schools are subject to regular inspections and in some cases inspection reports are published on the relevant regulator’s website. Below is a summary of the regulatory regimes prevailing in the key markets in which we operate.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: We have entered into, and expect to continue to enter into, transactions with certain of our significant shareholders and other entities owned by, or affiliated with, our direct and indirect shareholders and with certain of our directors in the ordinary course of business under market conditions. These transactions have included (among other things) the provision of construction services, the provision of IT services, the sharing of employees and the provision of certain online and vocational education courses. See note 8 to our consolidated financial statements as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2016, note 8 to our consolidated financial statements as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2017, note 8 to our consolidated financial statements as at and for the twelve months ended 31 August 2018 and note 6 to our interim condensed consolidated financial statements as at and for the nine months ended 31 May 2019. 159 -----

In connection with, among other things, the financing of the Acquisition, GMCL, on July 10, 2019, entered into the Senior Facilities Agreement with, among others, Goldman Sachs Bank USA, Citigroup Global Markets Limited, Credit Suisse Loan Funding LLC, Credit Suisse AG, London Branch and HSBC Bank Middle East Limited as mandated lead arrangers. The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for a revolving credit facility in a principal amount of $200.0 million (the “Revolving Credit Facility”) and senior term loan facility in a principal amount of $850.0 million (“Facility B”) (the Revolving Credit Facility and Facility B are collectively referred to as the “Senior Credit Facilities” for the purposes of this description). Facility B may be utilized by GMCL, the U.S. Co–Issuer and certain restricted subsidiaries of GMCL which accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers of Facility B (the “Facility B Borrowers”). Facility B may be applied in or towards amongst other things: (i) any payment to be made by GMCL (whether directly or indirectly, including via GMHL) to fund the acquisition of shares in Maarif for Education and Training by GEMS Education KSA Holding, such payment in an aggregate principal amount not exceeding $50,000,000 (the “KSA Acquisition Payment”); (ii) any payment to be made by GMCL (whether directly or indirectly, including via GEMS FinCo Limited) to GMHL in an aggregate amount not exceeding $65,000,000 (the “GMHL Payment”); (iii) satisfaction of the consideration payable for the Acquisition; (iv) financing the payment of certain fees, costs and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement), and (v) (to the extent of any cash overfunding, but only following the application of the relevant amounts for the purposes contemplated above) the general corporate purposes of the Group), in each case, in a manner consistent in all material respects with the funds flow statement. The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by GMCL and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers (the “RCF Borrowers”). The Revolving Credit Facility may be used for the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Group (including, without limitation, payment of the Transaction Costs, funding of capital expenditure, restructuring costs, acquisitions, purchase price adjustments, any original issue discount and fees, costs and expenses and backstopping and/or replacing existing letters of credit (or similar instruments) of the Group), providing that the aggregate principal amount of the Revolving Credit Facility utilised on the Closing Date may not exceed an amount equal to $75,000,000. In addition to the Revolving Credit Facility and Facility B, the Senior Facilities Agreement includes (in addition to other permissions under the limitation on indebtedness covenant) the ability (without double counting against the limitation on indebtedness covenant) to incur additional indebtedness (including under one or more uncommitted additional facilities within the Senior Facilities Agreement and/or any additional notes and/or other facilities or notes documented outside the Senior Facilities Agreement) up to an aggregate amount of the greater of USD 300.0 million and 100% of LTM Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement and subject to certain customary additions), plus an unlimited amount, provided that, pro forma for the incurrence of such additional facilities or permitted alternative debt: (i) if such indebtedness is secured on the Collateral, and subject to the Intercreditor Agreement such that such liabilities rank pari passu with Facility B, the First Lien Net Leverage Ratio (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) does not exceed 5.25:1; or (ii) if the Indebtedness (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) does not fall within paragraph (i), the Total Net Leverage Ratio (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) would not exceed 6.25:1.00, or (for unsecured debt) the Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) does not exceed 2.00:1,and in each case, subject to certain other conditions being met. 160 -----

Facility B will be available on and from the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement up to (and including) the earliest of: (i) the date on which GMCL notifies Goldman Sachs Bank USA (as agent) that any Sponsor Acquisition Agreement (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) has been terminated in accordance with its terms (such notice to be provided as soon as reasonably practicable following such termination); (ii) 11.59pm (London time) on the Closing Date; and (iii) 30 September 2019. The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized from (and including) the period from and including the Closing Date until the date falling one month prior to the Termination Date (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) in relation to the Revolving Credit Facility.
Utilizations of the Senior Credit Facilities are subject to customary conditions precedent.

Loans under the Senior Credit Facilities will initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR for loans denominated in Euro, EIBOR for loans denominated in AED or, for loans denominated in all other currencies, LIBOR (or local equivalent where LIBOR is not available), plus an applicable margin, which, in each case, will be subject to a margin ratchet based on the ratio of Consolidated Senior Secured Net Debt (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) of GMCL and its Restricted Subsidiaries (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) to LTM Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) of GMCL and its Restricted Subsidiaries (the “First Lien Net Leverage Ratio”). If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under Facility B or the Revolving Credit Facility (as applicable). If EIBOR is less than zero, EIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under Facility B or the Revolving Credit Facility (as applicable). If LIBOR is less than zero: (a) LIBOR shall be deemed to be 1% per annum in respect of loans in U.S. dollar made under Facility B or the Revolving Credit Facility (as applicable); and (b) LIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans in any other case. A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving Credit Facility from the Closing Date to the end of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of 35% of the applicable margin for the Revolving Credit Facility. Commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears and on the date the Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled in full or on the date on which the relevant lender cancels its commitment. Default interest will be calculated as an additional 2% on the defaulted amount.

The loans made under Facility B will be repaid in full on the date that is seven years from the Closing Date. In respect of the Revolving Credit Facility, each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to an ability to roll over cash drawings. All outstanding amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility will be repaid on the date falling six years from the Closing Date. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility may be reborrowed, subject to certain conditions.

The Senior Facilities Agreement will permit voluntary prepayments to be made (subject to de minimis amounts) and will require mandatory prepayment in full or in part in certain circumstances, including: - on the sale of all or substantially all of the business and/or assets of the Group (whether in a single transaction or a series of transactions); - as at 11.59pm (London time) on the first Business Day to occur after the Closing Date, the Sponsor Acquisitions (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) have not been consummated; 161 ----- - from certain net cash proceeds received by the Group from certain asset disposals, to the extent not otherwise applied for a permitted purpose and required to be applied in prepayment of the Senior Credit Facilities and subject to a de minimis amount; and - unless otherwise agreed by the majority lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement, for each financial year (commencing with the first full financial year following the Closing Date), a percentage of excess cash flow in the event that excess cash flow exceeds a minimum threshold amount (subject to certain adjustments based on anticipated debt service and certain other expenses), which percentage decreases as the First Lien Net Leverage Ratio decreases (an “Excess Cash Flow Prepayment”). The occurrence of a Change of Control (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) is an event of default. A Change of Control shall include: - at any time prior to Listing, the Relevant Holders (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement), taken together, cease to control and beneficially own (directly or indirectly) more than 50 per cent. of the issued share capital of GMCL; - at any time prior to Listing, a person or a group of persons acting in concert (other than the Relevant Holders) (directly or indirectly) acquire and control more than 50% of the issued share capital of GMCL; - at any time prior to Listing, GEMS FinCo Limited ceasing to directly own 100% of the total issued share capital of GMCL; and - upon and at any time after a Listing (i) the Relevant Holders (each as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement), taken together, cease to control and beneficially own (directly or indirectly) more than 30 per cent. of GMCL; (ii) GEMS FinCo Limited ceases to control and own (directly) the entire issued share capital in GMCL; or (iii) a person or persons acting in concert (other than the Relevant Holders (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement)) controls or beneficially owns (directly or indirectly) more than 30 per cent. of GMCL or a greater percentage of GMCL than is controlled or beneficially owned by the Relevant Holders, taken together.

The Senior Credit Facilities are currently guaranteed by the US Co–Issuer and GMCL. The Senior Credit Facilities are (or will be) secured by first ranking pledges over, among other assets, (i) the entire issued share capital of GMCL held by GEMS FinCo Limited; (ii) the master bank account of GMCL held in the UAE; (iii) the intercompany receivables owed to GEMS FinCo Limited by GMCL; and (iv) the share capital of the US Co–Issuer held by GMCL; and (v) all assets of the U.S. Co-Issuer. Subject to certain adjustments and agreed security principles in the Senior Facilities Agreement, GMCL is required to ensure that members of the Group that generate at least 80% of Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) are guarantors under the Senior Facilities Agreement (i) initially, on or before the date which is 60 days after the Closing Date; and (ii) thereafter, on the date each year when the annual financial statements of GMCL are required to be delivered to the agent under the Senior Facilities Agreement. The provision and the terms of the security and guarantees set forth above will in all cases be subject to certain limitations and are at all times and in all cases subject to the requirements of applicable law and the other matters set forth in the Senior Facilities Agreement.

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain representations and warranties (subject to certain agreed qualifications and with certain representations being repeated), including: status, binding obligations, non-conflict with other obligations, power and authority, validity and admissibility in evidence, governing law and enforcement, consents, filings and laws applicable to operations and _pari passu ranking, no insolvency, no litigation, tax liabilities, filing and stamp taxes, no default,_ financial statements, group structure and Qualifying Nominee Arrangements (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement), and no misleading information, legal and beneficial ownership, holding company activities (for the U.S. Co-Issuer and GEMS FinCo Limited only), intellectual property, shares, Federal Reserve Regulations, Investment Company Act, USA Patriot Act, Anti–Corruption Laws, OFAC, Anti–Terrorism and ERISA. 162 ----- Certain representations and warranties were made on the Closing Date and will be repeated on the date of each utilization, on the first day of each interest period and at certain other times.

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain incurrence covenants, information undertakings and related definitions (with, in each case, certain adjustments), including: (i) limitations on indebtedness; (ii) limitations on restricted payments; (iii) limitations on liens; (iv) limitations on investments; (v) limitations on fundamental changes; (vi) limitations on dispositions; (vii) limitations on change in nature of business; (viii) no burdensome agreements; and (ix) limitations on affiliate transactions. In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement also requires GMCL and certain of its restricted subsidiaries to observe certain other customary positive and negative covenants, subject to certain exceptions and grace periods, including covenants relating to: (i) prepayments, etc. of indebtedness; (ii) designation of subsidiaries; (iii) qualifying nominee arrangements; (iv) authorizations and consents; (v) compliance with laws; (vi) pari passu ranking; (vii) insurances; (viii) payment of taxes; (ix) pension schemes; (x) maintenance of centre of main interests; (xi) provision of guarantees and security and further assurance; (xii) maintenance of a corporate rating (but no requirement to maintain any specific rating); (xiii) holding company; and (xiv) security provider. Solely for the benefit of the lenders participating in the Revolving Credit Facility, the Senior Facilities Agreement requires that, in the event that the aggregate amount of all cash loans drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility (excluding any utilizations by way of letters of credit, or bank guarantees, or amounts utilized by way of a non–cash utilisation of an ancillary facility) exceeds 40 per cent of the total commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility on the relevant testing date (the “Revolving Test Condition”), the First Lien Net Leverage Ratio must not exceed 8.50 to 1.00. The First Lien Net Leverage Ratio is based on the definitions and adjustments in the Senior Facilities Agreement, which may differ from similar or equivalent definitions described in this offering memorandum. The Senior Facilities Agreement contains an equity cure provision enabling the shareholder of GMCL to make shareholder injections by way of debt and/or equity to GMCL to (i) increase the consolidated pro forma EBITDA under the Senior Facilities Agreement, (ii) decrease consolidated senior secured net debt as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement, or (iii) prepay the Revolving Credit Facility so that the Revolving Test Condition is no longer satisfied. The equity cure right may not be exercised on more than five occasions during the term of the Senior Credit Facilities and may not be utilized in consecutive quarters.

The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for substantially the same events of default as under the Notes. In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement provides for additional events of default, subject to customary materiality qualifications and grace periods, including (i) breach of the financial covenant (for the benefit of lenders under the Revolving Facility only); (ii) inaccuracy of a representation or statement when made; (iii) invalidity and unlawfulness of the Senior Credit Facilities financing documents; and (iv) material failure to comply with the Intercreditor Agreement.

The Senior Facilities Agreement and any non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection with it, are governed by, construed in accordance with and will be enforced in accordance with English law.

To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements, GMCL and certain Guarantors are party to and certain other Guarantors and the Trustee will accede to an Intercreditor Agreement between, among others, the agent, arrangers and lenders under our Senior Facilities Agreement and the Security Agent. By accepting a Note, holders of the Notes will be deemed to have agreed to, and accepted the terms and conditions of, the Intercreditor Agreement. 163 ----- The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law and sets out various matters governing the relationship of the creditors to our group including the relative ranking of certain debt of GMCL, the Guarantors and any other person that becomes party to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Debtor or Security Provider, when payments can be made in respect of debt of the Debtors or Security Providers, when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that debt, the terms pursuant to which certain of that debt will be subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover provisions and provisions related to the enforcement of shared security. The following description is a summary of certain provisions contained in the Intercreditor Agreement. It does not restate the Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety and we urge you to read that document because it, and not the discussion that follows, defines certain rights of the holders of the Notes and of the Trustee. Capitalized terms used but not defined herein have the meanings given to them in the Intercreditor Agreement. For the purposes of this description: References to the “Senior Secured Notes” shall include the Senior Secured Notes and any other notes, securities or other debt instruments issued or to be issued by or in relation to which a New Debt Financing has been made available to or by a member of the Group which are designated by GMCL as Senior Secured Notes under the Intercreditor Agreement. The Intercreditor Agreement uses the term “the Company” to refer to GMCL and “Senior Secured Notes Liabilities” to refer to indebtedness under the Senior Secured Notes and certain other indebtedness of GMCL.

_Priority of Debts_ The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities owed by GMCL and each other debtor (under the Intercreditor Agreement (together, the “Debtors”) (other than any member of the Group which is designated as a Senior Unsecured Borrower under the Intercreditor Agreement (a “Senior Unsecured Borrower”)) shall rank in right of priority and payment in the following order and are postponed and subordinated to any prior ranking liabilities as follows: (i) first, liabilities owed to (i) the lenders, issuing banks and ancillary lenders in relation to the Senior Facilities Agreement or any future secured facilities agreements (a “Permitted Senior Facilities Agreement”) (the “Senior Lender Liabilities”), (ii) the Trustee and any trustee in relation to future senior secured notes (each a “Senior Secured Notes Trustee”) (other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as trustee), the holders of the Notes or future senior secured notes (the “Senior Secured Notes”) and the Security Agent in relation to the Senior Secured Notes (the “Senior Secured Notes Liabilities”), (iii) the arrangers, agents, issuing banks and lenders under any cash management facility (a “Cash Management Facility” and the liabilities under a Cash Management Facility being the “Cash Management Facility Liabilities”), (iv) the hedge counterparties in relation to any hedging agreements (the “Hedging Liabilities”), (v) the lenders in relation to any second lien facility agreement (a “Second Lien Facility Agreement” and the liabilities to the lenders under a Second Lien Facility Agreement being the “Second Lien Lender Liabilities”), (vi) any second lien notes trustee (other than certain amounts paid to it in its capacity as trustee), the holders of any second lien notes and the Security Agent in relation to any second lien notes (such second lien notes being “Second Lien Notes” and the liabilities in respect of such Second Lien Notes being the “Second Lien Notes Liabilities” and together with the Second Lien Lender Liabilities, the “Second Lien Liabilities”), (vii) any agent or trustee under any finance documents relating to any of the aforementioned liabilities, any agent or trustee under the Senior Unsecured Liabilities (as defined below) and to any agent or trustee in relation to certain other unsecured liabilities (together the “Agent Liabilities”); and (viii) the Security Agent (and, in each case, together with the applicable Arranger Liabilities in respect thereof), pari passu and without any preference between them; and (ii) second, all liabilities owed (i) to the holders of any future notes issued by or in relation to which a New Debt Financing has been made available to or by a Senior Unsecured Borrower and designated by GMCL as Senior Unsecured Notes and the Security Agent in relation to such Senior Unsecured Notes (the “Senior Unsecured Notes Liabilities”), (ii) under any future loan 164 ----- facility made available to any Senior Unsecured Borrower (the “Senior Unsecured Facility Liabilities” and together with the Senior Unsecured Notes Liabilities, the “Senior Unsecured Liabilities”) (and, in each case, together with the applicable Arranger Liabilities in respect thereof), and (iii) the liabilities owed under any future loan (a “Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan”) made by any Senior Unsecured Borrower for the purpose of on lending the proceeds of any Senior Unsecured Notes or Senior Unsecured Loans (the “Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan Liabilities”), _pari passu and without any preference between them._ The Intercreditor Agreement provides that Liabilities owed by any Senior Unsecured Borrower shall rank pari passu in right and priority of payment and without any preference between them in respect of (i) the Senior Lender Liabilities, (ii) the Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, (iii) the Cash Management Facility Liabilities, (iv) the Hedging Liabilities, (v) the Second Lien Lender Liabilities, (vi) the Second Lien Notes Liabilities, (vii) the Senior Unsecured Lender Liabilities, (viii) the Senior Unsecured Notes Liabilities, (ix) the Agent Liabilities and (x) the liabilities owned to the Security Agent (and, in each case, together with the applicable Arranger Liabilities in respect thereof). The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the intra-group liabilities owed by one member of the Group to another member of the Group (other than any Senior Secured Proceeds Loan Liabilities) (the “IntraGroup Liabilities”) will be subordinated and postponed to the liabilities owed by the Debtors and Security Providers to the creditors under the Senior Lender Liabilities, Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, Cash Management Facility Liabilities, Hedging Liabilities, Second Lien Lender Liabilities, Second Lien Notes Liabilities and Agent Liabilities (such creditors, together with the Security Agent, any receiver or delegate, any creditor of the Agent Liabilities and any arranger with respect to the Secured Liabilities, the “Secured Parties”) and the Independent Liabilities (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement). The Intercreditor Agreement also provides that the liabilities owed by any member of the Group (other than any Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan Liabilities) to a holding company of GMCL or to any other person who becomes a subordinated creditor (a “Subordinated Creditor”) under the Intercreditor Agreement (the “Subordinated Liabilities”) will be subordinated to the liabilities owed by the Debtors and Security Providers to the Primary Creditors and the Independent Creditors (in each case, as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement). The Intercreditor Agreement uses the term “Investor” to refer to “Subordinated Creditor” and “Investor Liabilities” to refer to “Subordinated Liabilities”. The Intercreditor Agreement does not purport to rank any of the Independent Liabilities, Intra-Group Liabilities and Subordinated Liabilities as between themselves. _Priority of Security_ The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the Transaction Security (other than the Senior Unsecured Shared Security) shall, subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, rank and secure the secured obligations in the case of any Transaction Security (but only to the extent that such Transaction Security is expressed to secure those Liabilities) in the following order (in each case subject to the relevant provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement): (i) first, liabilities owed to the Security Agent, the Agent Liabilities, the Senior Secured Liabilities, (and, in each case, together with the applicable Arranger Liabilities in respect thereof), pari passu and without any preference between them; and (ii) second, the Second Lien Lender Liabilities and the Second Lien Notes Liabilities (and, in each case, together with the applicable Arranger Liabilities in respect thereof), pari passu and without any preference between them. The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the Senior Unsecured Shared Security shall, subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, rank and secure the secured obligations in the case of any Senior Unsecured Shared Security (but only to the extent that such Senior Unsecured Shared Security is expressed to secure those Liabilities) in the following order (in each case subject to the relevant provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement): (i) first, Liabilities owed to the Security Agent, the Agent Liabilities, the Senior Secured Liabilities, (and, in each case, together with the applicable Arranger Liabilities in respect thereof), pari passu and without any preference between them; 165 ----- (ii) second, the Second Lien Lender Liabilities and the Second Lien Notes Liabilities (and, in each case, together with the applicable Arranger Liabilities in respect thereof), pari passu and without any preference between them; and (iv) third, the Senior Unsecured Lender Liabilities and the Senior Unsecured Notes Liabilities (and, in each case, together with the applicable Arranger Liabilities in respect thereof), pari passu and without any preference between them. For the purposes of this description only: “Debt Documents” means the Intercreditor Agreement and the documents creating or evidencing the Cash Management Facility Liabilities, the Hedging Liabilities, the Second Lien Liabilities, the Senior Secured Liabilities, the Senior Unsecured Liabilities, the Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan Liabilities, the unsecured liabilities of any unsecured creditors who are party to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Subordinated Liabilities and the Intra-Group Liabilities (each as defined in this description) and any other document designated as such by the Security Agent and GMCL. “Finance Documents” means the Senior Facilities Agreement, any Permitted Senior Facilities Agreement, the indenture in respect of any Senior Secured Notes, any Second Lien Facility Agreement, the indenture in respect of any Second Lien Notes, the facility documenting any Senior Unsecured Facility, the indenture in respect of any Senior Unsecured Notes, any facility agreement indenture or instrument under which Independent Liabilities are (or are to be) made available and any document designated by GMCL as an unsecured finance document under and in accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement. “Secured Creditors” means the Senior Secured Creditors, Second Lien Creditors and the Senior Unsecured Creditors (each as defined below). “Secured Debt Documents” means the documents relating to the Senior Secured Liabilities, Second Lien Liabilities and the Senior Unsecured Liabilities. “Security Provider” means the Original Security Provider (being GEMS FinCo Limited) and any person that is not a member of the Group that has provided Transaction Security (including Senior Unsecured Shared Security) but is not a Debtor in respect of any direct borrowing or guarantee liabilities of the applicable secured obligations to which that Transaction Security relates (other than, as the case may be, any Senior Unsecured Liabilities) and which becomes a party to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Security Provider in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. “Senior Unsecured Only Security” refers to security (other than Transaction Security) which is created, or expressed to be created over: (i) shares of (or any other ownership interests in) any Senior Unsecured Borrower, (ii) any Investor Document giving rise to any Subordinated Liabilities from any Senior Unsecured Borrower to any Subordinated Creditor, (iii) any bank account(s) of any Senior Unsecured Borrower, (iv) any other any assets, accounts or rights of any Senior Unsecured Borrower, or, as the case may be, any receivables payable to any Senior Unsecured Borrower, but excluding (a) any rights of, or any receivables payable to, any Senior Unsecured Borrower by any member of the Group, (b) shares (or any other ownership interests) held by that Senior Unsecured Borrower directly in any member of the Group, (v) any escrow account(s) relating to the proceeds of any Senior Unsecured Liabilities, and/or (vi) shares of (or any other ownership interests in) and/or any assets or accounts of, or in respect of (including rights against, or receivables payable by), any other person who is not a member of the Group, in each case to the extent provided for by the Senior Unsecured Only Security Documents at any time and designated as Senior Unsecured Only Security by the relevant Senior Unsecured Borrower (acting in its sole discretion) by written notice to the Security Agent provided that no such designation may be made to the extent that the relevant asset, account, right or, as the case may be, receivable is, at that time, subject to Senior Unsecured Shared Security. Senior Unsecured Only Security shall secure the Senior Unsecured Finance Parties under or pursuant to the Senior Unsecured Only Security Documents. “Senior Unsecured Shared Security” refers to security at any time which is created, or expressed to be created, over each of (i) the shares (or any other ownership interests) in GMCL, (ii) any rights of, or any receivables payable to, any Senior Unsecured Borrower under any document creating or evidencing Senior Unsecured Proceeds Loan Liabilities or (if such rights are against, or such receivables are payable by, GMCL) any document creating or evidencing Subordinated Liabilities, (iii) any assets of any Security Provider which is not a member of the Group (to the extent not 166 ----- prohibited by the terms of any Senior Secured Finance Document or Second Lien Finance Document); and/or (iv) any other assets, accounts, rights or, as the case may be, receivables referred to in the definition of “Senior Unsecured Only Security Documents”, in each case to the extent provided for by the Senior Unsecured Finance Documents at any time and designated as Senior Unsecured Shared Security by GMCL and the relevant Senior Unsecured Borrower (each acting in its sole discretion) by written notice to the Security Agent provided that no such designation may be made in respect of any asset, account, right or, as the case may be, receivable referred to in paragraph (iv) above to the extent that the relevant assets, accounts, rights or, as the case may be, receivables is, at that time, subject to Senior Unsecured Only Security. Senior Unsecured Shared Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of each Senior Unsecured Borrower that is not a member of the Group and each of its Restricted Subsidiaries (as defined in the documents governing the relevant Senior Unsecured Notes or Senior Unsecured Facility (as the case may be)), each Debtor and each Security Provider to the Secured Parties under the Secured Debt Documents. “Transaction Security” refers to security (from the Group, any Security Provider and Senior Unsecured Shared Security (but excluding, for the avoidance of doubt, Senior Unsecured Only Transaction Security and any Independent Security)) which to the extent legally possible and subject to any Agreed Security Principles and the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement is created, or expressed to be created, in favour of the Security Agent as agent, “agent des sûretés” or trustee for the applicable Secured Parties (or class of Secured Parties) in respect of the applicable Secured Obligations (or if such trustee arrangements are not legally possible, in favour of all the Secured Parties or in favour of the Security Agent under a parallel debt or similar structure). The Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be Senior Secured Notes Liabilities for the purposes of the Intercreditor Agreement. On the Issue Date, no Second Lien Lender Liabilities, Second Lien Notes Liabilities or Senior Unsecured Liabilities are currently expected to be outstanding. Such liabilities and liabilities in respect of other new debt financings may only be incurred and/or designated if not prohibited under the terms of the Debt Documents, including, without limitation, the covenants applicable to the Notes described under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain _Covenants”. Guarantees and Security: Senior Unsecured Creditors_ The creditors in respect of the Senior Unsecured Liabilities (the “Senior Unsecured Creditors”) have the right to take, accept or receive the benefit of: (i) any Senior Unsecured Shared Security from Debtor, any member of the Group or from a Security Provider in respect of the Senior Unsecured Liabilities if (except for any Security falling under paragraph (iii) below) and to the extent legally possible and subject to any Agreed Security Principles, at the same time it is also offered either: (A) to the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof) in respect of their Liabilities; or (B) to the Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof) in respect of their liabilities; or (C) to the Security Agent as joint and several creditor of the Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof); or (D) in the case of any jurisdiction in which effective security cannot be granted in favour of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof): (I) to the other Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof) in respect of their Liabilities; or (II) to the Security Agent under a parallel debt structure, joint and several creditor structure or agency structure for the benefit of the other Secured Parties (or applicable class thereof), and ranks in the same order of priority as described under “Priority of Debts” or “Priority of Security” above, provided that all amounts received or recovered by any Senior Unsecured Creditor with respect to such Senior Unsecured Shared Security are paid to the Security Agent for application as set out under “Application of Proceeds” below; (ii) any guarantee, indemnity or other assurance against loss from any Debtor, Security Provider and/or any member of the Group in respect of any Senior Unsecured Liabilities in addition to any 167 ----- guarantee, indemnity or assurance in the original form of any Senior Unsecured Finance Documents or the Intercreditor Agreement, or given to all the Secured Parties, each Debtor and any Security Provider to the Secured Parties under the Debt Documents if, subject to any agreed security principles: (A) (except for any guarantee, indemnity or other assurance under paragraph (iii) below), the Secured Parties other than the Senior Unsecured Creditors (the “Priority Secured Parties”) already benefit from such a guarantee, indemnity or other assurance or at the same time it is also offered to the Priority Secured Parties and ranks in the same order of priority as described under “—Priority of Debts” above, as applicable; and (B) all amounts received by any Senior Unsecured Creditor with respect to such guarantee, indemnity or assurance are paid to the Security Agent for application as set out under “—Application of Proceeds” below; and (iii) any security, guarantee indemnity or other assurance from any Debtor, Security Provider or member of the Group: (A) which constitutes Senior Unsecured Only Security or which is a guarantee, indemnity or other assurance against loss from any person who is not a member of the Group; (B) in any engagement, mandate, commitment, syndication or fee letter (or equivalent, analogous, ancillary or related document) entered into in connection with any actual or potential Senior Unsecured Finance Document or, as the case may be, Senior Unsecured Liabilities; (C) in connection with any escrow or similar or equivalent arrangements entered into in respect of amounts which are being held (or will be held) pursuant to an arrangement with a person who is not a member of the Group prior to the release of those amounts to a member of the Group; (D) pursuant to the terms of any certain funds interim facility agreement (or similar or equivalent agreement) in connection with any actual or potential acquisition or investment, which interim facility has a maturity of not more than 75 days and is made available (or is to be made available) to a special purpose vehicle incorporated for the purposes of the relevant acquisition or investment and which has no subsidiaries (other than as may arise pursuant to the relevant acquisition or (as applicable) investment), provided that the only Security, guarantee, indemnity or other assurance against loss which may be permitted under this paragraph (D) shall be Security, guarantees, indemnities or other assurances against loss granted only by that special purpose vehicle or Security granted over the shares of (or other investments in), or rights against or receivables owing by, that special purpose vehicle; and/or (E) in connection with any actual or proposed defeasance, redemption, prepayment, repayment, purchase or other discharge of any Senior Secured Liabilities, Second Lien Liabilities or Senior Unsecured Liabilities (provided such defeasance, redemption, prepayment, repayment, purchase or other discharge is not prohibited by the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement at such time). No security (other than pursuant to the secured documents relating to Senior Unsecured Only Security or Senior Unsecured Shared Security or as otherwise described in the Intercreditor Agreement) shall be granted by a member of the Group in respect of any Senior Unsecured Liabilities. _Guarantees and Security: Independent Creditors_ The Independent Creditors may take, accept or receive the benefit of: (i) any Security (other than Senior Unsecured Shared Security) from any Debtor, Security Provider and/or any member of the Group in respect of any of the Independent Liabilities if, and to the extent legally possible and subject to any Agreed Security Principles, at the same time it is also offered either: (A) to the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the Senior Secured Creditors and the Second Lien Creditors (or applicable class thereof) in respect of their Liabilities; (B) to the Senior Secured Creditors and the Second Lien Creditors (or applicable class thereof) in respect of their Liabilities; 168 ----- (C) to the Security Agent as joint and several creditor of the Senior Secured Creditors and the Second Lien Creditors (or applicable class thereof); or (D) in the case of any jurisdiction in which effective Security cannot be granted in favor of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the Senior Secured Creditors and the Second Lien Creditors (or the applicable class thereof): (I) to the Senior Secured Creditors and the Second Lien Creditors (or applicable class thereof) in respect of their Liabilities; or (II) to the Security Agent under a parallel debt structure, joint and several creditor structure or agency structure for the benefit of the Senior Secured Creditors and the Second Lien Creditors (or applicable class thereof), and the claims of the Senior Secured Creditors and the Second Lien Creditors in respect of such Security will rank pari passu with the claims of the Independent Creditors and provided further that all amounts received or recovered by any Independent Creditor with respect to any such Security are paid to the Security Agent pursuant to the turnover provisions in the Intercreditor Agreement;
